Editor's note- Ord. No. G-17-01 , § I, adopted May 9, 2017, repealed § 26-50, which pertained to prohibited acts and derived from Ord. No. G-09-07, § 2, 10-27-2009. 
Secs. 26-51-26-66. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NOXIOUS WEEDS AND GRASSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Weeds generally, K.S.A. 2-1314; authority for cities to eradicate weeds, K.S.A. 12-1617f. 

Sec. 26-67. - Weeds to be removed. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, agent, lessee, tenant, or other person having legal title to, occupying, or having charge or control of any real property within the city to permit weeds to remain upon the property or any area between the property lines of the property and the center line of any adjacent street or alley, including, but not specifically limited to, sidewalks, streets, alleys, easements, rights-of-way and all other areas, public or private. All weeds as hereinafter defined are hereby declared a nuisance and are subject to abatement as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Property, or portions thereof, designated by the city as controlled natural or native grass planting areas are exempt from the provisions of this section. Such areas may include, without limitation, golf courses, forested areas, property within flood zones or stormwater drainage areas, abandoned rail spurs, and undeveloped commercial or industrial parcels. 
(2)  Inaccessible drainage ways, easements, and rights-of-way, as determined by the public officer, are exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(3)  Property in excess of three acres under single ownership are exempt from the provisions of this section, except as to the areas within 200 feet of any public street or within 100 feet of any adjacent, improved property. The public officer, in consultation with the city manager, and with the written agreement of all affected property owners, may deviate from the stated distances to allow for special circumstances that would otherwise not be effectively covered by this section. 
(Code 1965, § 12-201; Code 1977, § 27-16; Ord. No. G-99-01, § 1(27-16), 3-18-1996; Ord. No. G-96-04, § 2(27-16), 5-14-1996; Ord. No. G-15-06, § 1(27-16), 11-24-2015) 
Sec. 26-68. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Calendar year means that period of time beginning January 1 and ending December 31 of the same year. 
    Improved property means real property containing any permanent structure thereon, which increases its value. 
    Weeds . 
(1)  The term "weeds" means any of the following: 
a.  Brush and woody vines shall be classified as weeds; 
b.  Vegetation and indigenous grasses which may attain such large growth as to become, when dry, a fire menace to adjacent improved property; 
c.  Vegetation which bears or may bear seeds of a downy or wingy nature; 
d.  Vegetation which is located in an area which harbors rats, insects, animals, reptiles, or any other creature which either may or does constitute a menace to health, public safety, or welfare; 
e.  Vegetation and indigenous grasses on or about property which, because of its height, has a blighting influence on a neighborhood. Any such vegetation and indigenous grasses shall be presumed to be blighting if they exceed 12 inches in height. 
(2)  The term "weeds" shall not include cultivated flowers or plants, ornamental grasses, or gardens. 
(Code 1965, § 12-203; Code 1977, § 27-17; Ord. No. G-99-01, § 1(27-17), 3-18-1996; Ord. No. G-96-04, § 2(27-17), 5-14-1996; Ord. No. G-15-06, § 1(27-17), 11-24-2015) 
Sec. 26-69. - Public officer; notice to remove. 
(a)  The city manager shall designate a public officer to be charged with the administration and enforcement of this article. The public officer shall notify in writing the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of any property in the city upon which weeds exist in violation of this article, by first class mail or by personal service, once per calendar year. Such notice shall include the following: 
(1)  That the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property is in violation of the city weed control law; 
(2)  That the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property is ordered to cut the weeds within ten days of the date of issuance of notice; 
(3)  That the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property may request a hearing before the city manager, or the city manager's designee, within five days of the issuance of notice; 
(4)  That if the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property does not cut the weeds, the city or its authorized agent will cut the weeds and assess the cost of the cutting or otherwise destroying the weeds, including a reasonable administrative fee in accordance with the city's fee schedule adopted by separate resolution, against the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property; 
(5)  That the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property will be given an opportunity to pay the assessment, and, if it is not paid, it will be added to the property tax as a special assessment, and become a personal debt; 
(6)  That no further notice shall be given prior to removal of weeds during the current calendar year. 
(b)  If there is a change in the record owner of title to real property subsequent to the giving of notice pursuant to this section, the city may not recover any costs or levy an assessment for the costs incurred by the cutting or destruction of weeds on such property against the new record owner of the real property, unless such owner is provided notice as required by this section. 
(Code 1965, § 12-204; Code 1977, § 27-18; Ord. No. G-99-01, § 1(27-18), 3-18-1996; Ord. No. G-96-04, § 2(27-18), 5-14-1996; Ord. No. G-15-06, § 1(27-18), 11-24-2015) 
Sec. 26-70. - Abatement; assessment of costs. 
(a)  Upon the expiration of the ten-day period established in section 26-69, and in the event that the owner, occupant or agent in charge of the property shall neglect or fail to comply with the requirements of this article, the public officer shall cause to be cut, destroyed, and/or removed all weeds and abate the nuisance created thereby at any time during the current calendar year. 
(b)  The public officer shall give notice to the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property, by first class mail, of the costs of abatement of the nuisance. The notice shall state that the payment is due and payable within 30 days following mailing of the notice. 
(c)  The city shall give notice to the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property, by first class mail, of the costs of work performed. The notice shall state that the payment is due and payable within 30 days following mailing of the notice. If the costs remain unpaid after 30 days following mailing of notice, a record of the costs shall be certified to the city clerk who shall cause such costs to be assessed against the particular lot or parcel of land on which the work was performed. The city clerk shall certify the assessment to the county clerk at the time other special assessments are certified for spreading on the tax rolls of the county. In addition to remedies available to the city to collect assessments levied against property, if any assessments for costs levied by the city in accordance with this section remain unpaid by the owner of a lot or parcel of ground, the city may collect the amount due in the same manner as a personal debt of the property owner to the city, by bringing an action in the appropriate district court. 
(Code 1965, § 12-205; Code 1977, § 27-19; Ord. No. G-99-01, § 1(27-19), 3-18-1996; Ord. No. G-96-04, § 2(27-19), 5-14-1996; Ord. No. G-15-06, § 1(27-19), 11-24-2015) 
Sec. 26-71. - Right of entry. 
    The public officer, and the public officer's authorized assistants, employees, contracting agents or other representatives are hereby expressly authorized to enter upon private property at all reasonable hours for the purpose of cutting, destroying and/or removing weeds in a manner consistent with this article. 
(Ord. No. G-15-06, § 1(27-20), 11-24-2015) 
Sec. 26-72. - Unlawful interference; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, or to attempt to prevent, the public officer or the public officer's authorized representative from entering upon any lot or parcel of land, or from proceeding with cutting and destruction of weeds. Such interference shall constitute an ordinance violation. 
(b)  A violation of subsection (a) of this section shall be punishable as follows: upon a first conviction, a person shall be fined $100.00; for a second conviction within a five-year period of time, a fine of $300.00; and for a third and subsequent conviction within a five-year period of time, a fine of $500.00 shall be imposed. 
(Ord. No. G-15-06, § 1(27-21, 27-22), 11-24-2015) 
Sec. 26-73. - Noxious weeds. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall affect or impair the rights of the city under the provisions of K.S.A. 2-1314b et seq., relating to the control and eradication of certain noxious weeds. 
(b)  For the purpose of this action, the term "noxious weeds" means kudzu (Pueraria lobata), field bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis), Russian knapweed (Centaurea picris), hoary cress (Lepidium draba), Canada thistle (Cirsium arvense), quackgrass (Agropyron repens), leafy spurge (Euphorbia esula), burragweed (Franseria tomentose and discolor), pignut (Hoffmannseggia densiflora), musk (nodding) thistle (Carduus nutans L.), and Johnson grass (Sorghum halepense). 
(Ord. No. G-15-06, § 1(27-23), 11-24-15) 
Secs. 26-74-26-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TREES, SHRUBBERY AND HEDGES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Trees and shrubbery generally, K.S.A.12-3201 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-86. - Purpose and intent. 
    This article is intended to provide for the regulation of planting, maintenance, treatment or removal of trees, shrubbery and hedges upon all streets of the city as a municipal function. 
(Code 1977, §§ 27-34, 27-35; Ord. No. 5464, art. 1, §§ 1, 2, 10-23-1968) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-3201, 12-3202. 
Sec. 26-87. - City manager's duties and authority. 
(a)  The city manager or the city manager's designee shall enforce this article and shall have complete jurisdiction, regulation, supervision and control over all trees, shrubbery and hedges growing in the city. 
(b)  If the foliage, boughs or limbs of trees, shrubbery or hedges adjacent to streets or sidewalks obstruct the free and convenient travel or vision along the streets or sidewalks, the city shall have the authority to cut and trim, or cause to be cut and trimmed, such trees, shrubbery and hedges when it is necessary for the safety and convenience of the traveling public to do so. 
(c)  Any tree or growth which by reason of the lay of the land or the location of same is a safety hazard or obstructs the view of drivers to observe traffic entering a street from an intersecting street may be cut down and removed by the city. 
(Code 1965, § 20-701; Code 1977, §§ 27-38, 27-39; Ord. No. 5464, art. 2, § 3, 10-23-1968) 
Sec. 26-88. - Violations; abatement by city. 
(a)  If any property owner or occupant whose duty it is to keep trees, shrubbery and hedges trimmed or cut, as provided in this article, fails to do so, the city shall cause notice to be served on such owner or occupant requiring the obstruction to be trimmed or cut forthwith. 
(b)  When the owner or occupant fails to trim or cut or cause such obstruction to be trimmed or cut as required by the notice within ten days after receipt of such notice, the city may trim such trees, shrubbery or hedges or cut down and remove the same. 
(c)  In the event the owner of the property is unknown or the property is unoccupied, the notice herein-before required shall be posted on the property, in a conspicuous manner, at least ten days before the work is done. 
(d)  All work performed by the city in accordance with this section shall be done in a careful and workmanlike manner so as not to unreasonably injure or destroy any such trees, shrubbery or hedges. 
(e)  If there exists great danger to life or property by reason of any obstruction referred to in this section, the same shall be removed immediately by the city without any notice. 
(f)  The city shall give notice to the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property, by first class mail, of the costs of work performed. The notice shall state that the payment is due and payable within 30 days following mailing of the notice. If the costs remain unpaid after 30 days following mailing of notice, a record of the costs shall be certified to the city clerk who shall cause such costs to be assessed against the particular lot or parcel of land on which the work was performed. The city clerk shall certify the assessment to the county clerk at the time other special assessments are certified for spreading on the tax rolls of the county. In addition to remedies available to the city to collect assessments levied against property, if any assessments for costs levied by the city in accordance with this section remain unpaid by the owner of a lot or parcel of ground, the city may collect the amount due in the same manner as a personal debt of the property owner to the city, by bringing an action in the appropriate district court. 
(Code 1977, §§ 27-37, 27-45; Ord. No. 5464, art. 2, §§ 4, 5, 10-23-1968) 
Secs. 26-89-26-119. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLANTING AND GENERAL MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 26-120. - Duty of owner or occupant to maintain vegetation. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every owner or occupant of lots abutting upon any street, sidewalk or public way of the city or adjacent to the street parking to cultivate trees, shrubbery or hedges in such a manner that the same shall not interfere with persons or travel upon or along the streets, sidewalks or public ways. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of all such persons to cut or trim any such trees, shrubbery or hedges so that the branches or limbs thereof shall not extend over the sidewalk lower than ten feet from the surface thereof, over the portion of any highway connecting link or designated truck route lower than 16 feet six inches or over the portion of any other street used for vehicles lower than 14 feet from the surface thereof. 
(c)  Every owner or occupant of any lot shall remove all dead trees or the branches thereof which shall be in the parking or close enough thereto to fall on any portion of any street or sidewalk. All limbs or branches of dead trees overhanging any public way of the city contrary to the provisions of this section or close enough thereto to be dangerous to public travel thereon may be removed as provided in section 26-88. 
(Code 1977, § 27-44; Ord. No. 5464, art. 2, § 2, 10-23-1968; Ord. No. G-99-07, § 1(27-44), 11-23-1999) 
Sec. 26-121. - Location of trees or shrubbery along city travel ways. 
    No trees, shrubs or bushes shall be planted within the city's right-of-wayor planted or maintained where they would obstruct a driver's vision of other vehicles or pedestrians at any intersection or where they would otherwise constitute a traffic hazard. 
(Code 1977, § 27-42; Ord. No. 5464, art. 2, § 3, 10-23-1968) 
Sec. 26-122. - Location of vegetable gardens. 
    All vegetable gardens within the city shall be located in the side or rear yard of a residence, regardless of the size or number of plants. If planted on a vacant lot, the garden shall not be located within the applicable setback areas for any residence. 
Sec. 26-123. - Maximum height of hedge or shrub bordering on street or sidewalk. 
    It is unlawful for any person owning or controlling any hedge fence or other type of bush or shrub bordering on any of the streets or sidewalks of the city to permit the same to grow to a height of more than three feet above the center line grade level of such adjacent or adjoining street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1965, § 20-702; Code 1977, § 27-47) 
Sec. 26-124. - Prohibited trees and shrubbery. 
    No owner or occupant of real property shall plant or grow any mulberry or thorny-locust tree in the parking adjacent to such property, nor shall any such owner or occupant of real property permit any mulberry or thorny-locust tree or branches of any such tree to overhang any street or sidewalk of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 20-705; Code 1977, §§ 27-49, 27-50; Ord. No. 5464, art. 2, § 2, 10-23-1968) 
Sec. 26-125. - Obstruction of public rights-of-way prohibited. 
(a)  It is unlawful for the owner or occupant of any lot abutting upon any street or public way in the city to plant, care for, grow, keep or cultivate any tree, shrubbery or hedge on such lot which interferes with public travel, public safety or use of the streets or public ways or which constitutes a menace or danger by reason of the location of such tree, shrubbery or hedge to any person using or upon the sidewalks or traveling upon the streets or public ways by vehicle. 
(b)  It is unlawful to plant or grow any tree or other vegetative growth that will grow to a height that will interfere with the safe use of the streets, parking or public ways of the city or electric lighting, power or telephone wires, or which will litter the streets or sidewalks adjacent to the parking where the same are grown and become a nuisance by reason of fruit or other substance falling therefrom upon such streets or sidewalks. 
(c)  Any person that has the lawful right to use public utility easements, streets or other public rights-of-way (either by authority of a franchise from the city or by reason of any other lawful source of authority to use the rights-of-way) may cut or trim any such obstructions without the necessity of procuring the verbal or written consent of the contiguous property owner, if there is one. 
(Code 1977, §§ 27-16, 27-40, 27-48; Ord. No. 5464, art. 2, §§ 1, 3, 6, 10-23-1968) 
Secs. 26-126-26-148. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - STORAGE OF CERTAIN MATERIAL, EQUIPMENT AND VEHICLES 

Sec. 26-149. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Inoperable means in a condition of being junked, wrecked, wholly or partially dismantled, abandoned, unlicensed, or unable to perform the functions or purposes for which it was originally intended. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, association, corporation, or their agent as owner, lessee, tenant or occupant. 
    Vehicle means any automobile, truck, tractor, or motorcycle which as originally designed contained an engine, regardless of whether it now contains an engine. 
(Code 1977, § 17-242; Ord. No. G-119, § 2, 11-10-1971; Ord. No. G-01-01, § 1(17-242), 4-10-2001) 
Sec. 26-150. - Findings. 
    The board of commissioners finds that junked, wrecked, dismantled, inoperative, discarded and abandoned vehicles, building material and equipment, and automotive parts in and upon real property within the city is a matter affecting the health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of the city for the following reasons: 
(1)  Such vehicles, materials and equipment serve as breeding ground for flies, mosquitoes, rats and other insects and rodents; 
(2)  They are a danger to persons, particularly children, because of broken glass, sharp metal protrusions, insecure mounting on blocks, jacks or supports, and because they are a ready source of fire and explosion; 
(3)  They encourage pilfering and theft and constitute a blighting influence upon the area in which they are located, thereby causing a loss in property value to surrounding property; and 
(4)  They constitute a fire hazard in that they block access for fire equipment to adjacent buildings and structures. 
(Code 1977, § 17-243; Ord. No. G-119, § 1, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 26-151. - General administrative procedure. 
(a)  Whenever there exists an apparent violation of this article, the city shall serve a written notice of the violation upon the occupant of the real property upon which such inoperable vehicle or other condition is located. The notice may be served personally, or by posting the notice on the inoperable vehicle or some other conspicuous place upon the real property. The notice shall inform such person of the violation and request that compliance with this article be accomplished within 14 days after service of the notice. 
(b)  In the event such person fails to comply with the provisions of this article within 14 days after service of the notice, the city may cause the inoperable vehicle to be removed. The person in possession of such vehicle and any personal property therein shall be responsible only for the reasonable care of such property. 
(c)  Any inoperable vehicle which has been impounded as provided in this section shall be disposed of as an abandoned vehicle in accordance with state statutes or in any other lawful manner. 
(Code 1977, § 17-244; Ord. No. G-119, § 6, 11-10-1971; Ord. No. G-88-02, § 1, 2-8-1988; Ord. No. G-01-01, § 2(17-244), 4-10-2001) 
Sec. 26-152. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No person shall park, maintain or store building materials, construction equipment, work machinery or automotive parts of any kind, particularly refuse or salvage, upon any lot, tract or parcel of land, other than in such districts as are permitted by ordinance within the city, except during actual construction or repair operations upon the premises, unless such articles are enclosed in a fence. 
(b)  No person shall park, maintain, deposit or store an unlicensed or inoperable vehicle on any street, alley or other public property, or on the adjacent yard or driveway of any residence within the city or upon any lot or land within the city unless: 
(1)  The vehicle is enclosed in a garage or other building; or 
(2)  The vehicle is enclosed behind a fence. 
(c)  No vehicle which is parked adjacent to any commercial service station or commercial garage and awaiting repairs shall be considered inoperable unless such vehicle remains so parked for 30 or more days. 
(d)  As used in this section, the term "fence" or "fencing" shall mean either artificial or natural screening which obstructs and prevents the view of the articles subject to this section and prohibits ready access to the area by children. The fence shall be of sufficient and uniform height so that no such articles can be seen from the surrounding area and shall be constructed of material which is compatible with the character of the neighborhood in which it is located. The "fence" or "fencing" shall comply with the city's fence regulations. 
(Code 1977, § 17-25; Ord. No. G-119, §§ 3, 4, 11-10-1971; Ord. No. G-87-08, § 1, 9-14-1987; Ord. No. G-88-02, § 2, 2-8-1988; Ord. No. G-01-01, § 3(17-245), 4-10-2001; Ord. No. G-17-01 , § J, 5-9-2017) 
Sec. 26-153. - Presumption that vehicle is inoperable. 
    Any one of the following conditions shall raise the presumption that a vehicle is inoperable: 
(1)  Absence of current or lawful registration plate upon such vehicle; 
(2)  Placement of the vehicle or parts thereof upon jacks, blocks, chains or other supports; 
(3)  Absence of one or more parts of the vehicle necessary for the lawful operation of the vehicle upon the streets; 
(4)  Vehicle in a condition or state of disrepair rendering it incapable of being driven in its condition or that has not been moved or used for seven consecutive days or more. 
(Code 1977, § 17-246; Ord. No. G-119, § 5, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 26-154. - Exemptions from article. 
    This article shall not be applicable to any junkyard or salvage yard being legally operated in conformity with the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 17-247) 
Sec. 26-155. - Penalty. 
(a)  Every person who violates the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not less than $50.00 or more than $500.00 or be confined to jail not to exceed three months, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(b)  A second conviction for a violation of this article within a 12-month period shall result in a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $500.00 or confinement in jail not to exceed six months, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(c)  A third conviction for a violation of this article within a 12-month period shall result in a fine of not less than $250.00 or more than $1,000.00 or confinement in jail not to exceed one year, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(d)  Each day a violation of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1977, § 17-248; Ord. No. G-77-10, §§ 1, 2, 8-10-1977; Ord. No. G-01-01, § 4(17-248), 4-10-2001) 
Secs. 26-156-26-178. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 26-179. - Enforcement officer. 
    The city manager shall designate a code enforcement officer to be charged with the administration and enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. G-09-07, § 2, 10-27-2009) 
Sec. 26-180. - Enforcement standards. 
    No person shall be found in violation of this chapter unless the code enforcement officer, after a reasonable inquiry and inspection of the premises, believes that conditions exist of a quality and appearance not commensurate with the character of the neighborhood. Such belief must be supported by evidence of a level of maintenance significantly below that of the rest of the neighborhood. Such evidence shall include conditions declared unlawful under in this chapter but shall not include conditions which are not readily visible from any public place or from any surrounding private property. 
(Ord. No. G-09-07, § 2, 10-27-2009) 
Sec. 26-181. - Applicability of procedure. 
    The abatement and other enforcement procedure provided in this article shall apply to all nuisance abatement within the city other than with regard to nuisances for which this Code specifically provides a different abatement procedure. 
Sec. 26-182. - Reserved.

Sec. 26-189. - Other remedies preserved. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to abrogate or impair the powers of the courts or of any department of the city to enforce any provisions of its laws nor to prevent or punish violations thereof. The powers conferred by this chapter shall be in addition to and supplemental to the powers conferred by any other law or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. G-09-07, § 2, 10-27-2009) 
Chapter 28 - OFFENSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes and punishments, K.S.A. Ch. 21. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - Unlawful to commit offenses; penalty. 
    It is unlawful for any person to commit any of the offenses prohibited by this chapter or other chapters of this Code within the city limits, and any person so offending shall be deemed guilty of having committed a public offense, and, after conviction therefor, shall be punished as provided herein. If no penalty is specifically provided in this chapter or required by state law, penalties for violation shall be as provided in section 1-12. 
(Code 1977, § 17-3) 
Sec. 28-2. - Incorporation by reference of Uniform Public Offense Code. 
    There is hereby incorporated by reference, as provided by law, for the purpose of providing a comprehensive public offense code within the City of Coffeyville, the Uniform Public Offense Code for Kansas Cities, Edition of 2017, prepared and published in book form by the League of Kansas Municipalities, Topeka, Kansas. The provisions of said uniform public offense code shall be controlling with respect to all subjects and matters therein contained within the City of Coffeyville. 
(Ord. No. G-15-05, § 2, 10-13-2015; Ord. No. G-17-04 , §§ 2, 3, 8-22-2017) 
Note- Per Ord. No. G-17-04 , § 3, adopted August 22, 2017, Section 10.13 of said Uniform Public Offense Code, relating to barbed wire, is hereby omitted and deleted. 
Sec. 28-3. - When arrest by law enforcement officer authorized. 
(a)  A law enforcement officer may arrest a person if the officer has a warrant commanding that the person be arrested or probable cause to believe that: 
(1)  A warrant for the person's arrest has been issued in this state or in another jurisdiction for a felony committed therein; 
(2)  The person is committing or has committed a felony; 
(3)  The person is committing or has committed a misdemeanor and the officer also has probable cause to believe that the person: 
a.  Will not be apprehended or evidence of the crime will be irretrievably lost unless the person is immediately arrested; 
b.  May cause injury to self or others or damage to property unless immediately arrested; or 
c.  Has intentionally inflicted bodily harm to another person. 
(b)  A law enforcement officer may also arrest a person if any crime, except a traffic or a cigarette or tobacco infraction, has been or is being committed by the person in the officer's view. 
(Code 1977, § 1-6; Ord. No. G-85-05, § 1, 6-24-85) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions, K.S.A. 22-2401. 
Sec. 28-4. - When detention by law enforcement officer authorized; service of complaint; release. 
(a)  A law enforcement officer may detain a person when: 
(1)  He has a warrant commanding that such person be arrested; 
(2)  He has reason to believe that a warrant for the person's arrest has been issued by any municipal court; 
(3)  He has probable cause to believe that the person is committing or has committed a violation of an ordinance, and the law enforcement officer has probable cause to believe that such person will not be apprehended or evidence of the violation of the ordinance will be irretrievably lost unless such person is immediately detained, or such person may cause injury to himself or others or damage to property unless immediately detained; or 
(4)  Any violation of an ordinance has been or is being committed by such person in his view. 
(b)  A law enforcement officer having detained a person pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, except subsection (1) or (2) of this section, may release the person or may prepare and serve upon such person a complaint and notice to appear, as provided by K.S.A. 12-4204 and shall then release such accused person from such detention, except in such instances where the law enforcement officer has power and authority to arrest such accused person as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 1-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-4211. 
Sec. 28-5. - Persons under arrest; procedures; right to post bond; release on personal recognizance. 
(a)  Any person arrested by a law enforcement officer shall be taken immediately by the law enforcement officer to the police station of the city or the office in the city designated by the municipal judge. At that time, the person shall have the right to post bond for the person's appearance, in accordance with K.S.A. 12-4301 and 12-4302, and amendments thereto, except as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  A law enforcement officer may detain a person arrested for violation of a municipal ordinance in protective custody for a period not to exceed six hours, including custody in a city or county jail, if such officer has probable cause to believe that: 
(1)  Such person may cause injury to oneself or others, or damage to property; and 
(2)  There is no responsible person or institution to which such person might be released. Any person so held in protective custody shall be permitted to consult with counsel or other persons who may act on such person's behalf. Such person held in protective custody for six hours shall be given an opportunity to post bond for such person's appearance in the municipal court. 
(c)  Any person held in custody pursuant to the provisions of this section, and who has not made bond for such person's appearance, may be held in custody until the earliest practical time for such person's appearance in municipal court upon a warrant being issued by the municipal court in accordance with K.S.A. 12-4209, and amendments thereto. 
(d)  Any person who remains in custody for 48 hours pursuant to the provisions of this section after arrest, and who is awaiting a first appearance before a municipal judge in the absence of a warrant being issued, shall be released on the person's personal recognizance. Bond shall be set within 18 hours of the person being placed in custody. 
(Code 1977, § 1-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-4213. 
Sec. 28-6. - Imprisonment. 
    Whenever in this chapter the penalty shall consist of imprisonment, such imprisonment shall be at and under the authority of the city police chief in such suitable and lawful place as he shall provide for such imprisonment. 
(Code 1977, § 17-4) 
Secs. 28-7-28-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ANTICIPATORY OR ANCILLARY OFFENSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Anticipatory crimes, K.S.A. 21-5301 et seq. 

Sec. 28-29. - Aiding and abetting. 
(a)  A person is criminally responsible for a crime committed by another if such person, acting with the mental culpability required for the commission thereof, advises, hires, counsels or procures the other to commit the crime or intentionally aids the other in committing the conduct constituting the crime. 
(b)  A person liable under subsection (a) of this section is also liable for any other crime committed in pursuance of the intended crime if reasonably foreseeable by such person as a probable consequence of committing or attempting to commit the crime intended. 
(c)  A person liable under this section may be charged with and convicted of the crime although the person alleged to have directly committed the act constituting the crime lacked criminal or legal capacity, has not been convicted, has been acquitted, or has been convicted of some other degree of the crime or of some other crime based on the same act. 
(Code 1977, § 17-17) 
State Law reference- Liability for crimes of another, K.S.A. 21-5210. 
Secs. 28-30-28-46. - Reserved.

Sec. 28-47. - Possession of dangerous or narcotic drug. 
    Any person found to be in possession of any dangerous or narcotic drugs in violation of the Uniform Controlled Substances Act, K.S.A. 65-4101 et seq., shall be guilty of a public offense within the meaning of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 17-72)

ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes against property, K.S.A. 21-3701 et seq. 

Sec. 28-68. - Fraudulently obtaining execution of document. 
(a)  Fraudulently obtaining execution of a document is causing another, by deception or threat, to execute a document disposing of property or a document by which a pecuniary obligation is incurred. 
(b)  Fraudulently obtaining execution of a document is a public offense within the meaning of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 17-90) 
Sec. 28-69. - Causing an unlawful prosecution for worthless check. 
(a)  Causing an unlawful prosecution for a worthless check is filing a complaint before a magistrate or supplying information upon which a prosecution for giving a worthless check is commenced with knowledge that the check, draft or order upon which such prosecution was based was post-dated or when the payee had knowledge, when he accepted such check, draft or order, that there were no funds or insufficient funds in the hands of the drawee to pay such check, draft or order upon presentation. 
(b)  Causing an unlawful prosecution for a worthless check is a public offense within the meaning of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 17-92) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 21-5822. 
Sec. 28-70. - Criminal use of noxious matter. 
(a)  Criminal use of noxious matter is the possession, manufacture or transportation of any noxious matter with intent to use such matter for an unlawful purpose, or the use or attempt to use noxious matter to the injury of persons and property, or the placing or depositing of such matter upon or about the premises of another person without the consent of such person. 
(b)  The term "noxious matter," as used in this section means any bomb, compound or substance which may give off dangerous or disagreeable odors or cause distress to persons exposed thereto. 
(c)  Criminal use of noxious matter is a public offense within the meaning of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 17-99) 
Sec. 28-71. - Molesting unfinished paving. 
    Any person who shall walk, drive or ride over, upon or across any pavement or sidewalk, or deface or damage the same, in course of construction before the same has been opened for public travel shall, upon conviction thereof, be deemed guilty of a public offense within the meaning of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 17-105) 
Secs. 28-72-28-94. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AFFECTING GOVERNMENTAL FUNCTIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes affecting governmental functions, K.S.A. 21-5901 et seq. 

Sec. 28-95. - Failure to appear. 
(a)  Failure to appear is willfully incurring a forfeiture of an appearance bond and failing to surrender oneself within 30 days following the date of such forfeiture by one who is charged with a misdemeanor and has been released on bond for appearance before any court of this state, for trial or other proceeding prior to conviction, or willfully incurring a forfeiture of an appearance bond and failing to surrender oneself within 30 days after his conviction of a misdemeanor has become final by one who has been released on an appearance bond by any court of this state. 
(b)  Any person who is released upon his own recognizance, without surety, or who fails to appear in response to a summons or traffic citation, shall be deemed a person released on bond for appearance within the meaning of subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to any person who forfeits a cash bond supplied pursuant to law upon an arrest for a traffic offense. 
(d)  Failure to appear in a public offense within the meaning of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 17-125) 
State Law reference- Failure to appear, K.S.A. 21-5915. 
Sec. 28-96. - Attempting to influence a judicial officer. 
(a)  Attempting to influence a judicial officer is communicating with any judicial officer in relation to any matter which is or may be brought before such judicial officer with intent improperly to influence such officer. 
(b)  Attempting to influence a judicial officer is a class two offense. 
(Code 1977, § 17-126) 
Sec. 28-97. - Commissioners interfering with city department. 
(a)  No member of the board of commissioners shall directly interfere with the conduct of any city department except at the express direction of the board. For purposes of this section, interference shall not include conversing with a department head or requesting information from a department head that is readily available, so long as such activities do not hinder the department head's ability to perform his job duties. Any request for information that requires research by any department head or other employee shall be referred to the city manager for handling, unless a majority of the board directs otherwise. 
(b)  Interfering with a city department is a public offense within the meaning of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 1-109; Code 1977, § 17-133) 
Secs. 28-98-28-122. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AFFECTING PUBLIC TRUST[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes affecting public trust, K.S.A. 21-6001 et seq. 

Sec. 28-123. - Official misconduct. 
(a)  Official misconduct is any of the following acts committed by a public officer or employee in the officer or employee's public capacity or under color of the officer or employee's office or employment: 
(1)  Using confidential information acquired in the course of and related to the officer's or employee's office or employment for the private benefit or gain of the officer or employee or another or to intentionally cause harm to another; 
(2)  Except as authorized by law, with the intent to reduce or eliminate competition among bidders or prospective bidders on any contract or proposed contract: 
a.  Disclosing confidential information regarding proposals or communications from bidders or prospective bidders on any contract or proposed contract; 
b.  Accepting any bid or proposal on a contract or proposed contract after the deadline for acceptance of such bid or proposal; or 
c.  Altering any bid or proposal submitted by a bidder on a contract or proposed contract; 
(3)  Except as authorized by law, knowingly destroying, tampering with or concealing evidence of a crime; or 
(4)  Knowingly submitting to a governmental entity a claim for expenses which is false or duplicates expenses for which a claim is submitted to such governmental entity, another governmental or private entity. 
(b)  Official misconduct is a public offense within the meaning of this chapter. Upon conviction of official misconduct, a public officer or employee shall forfeit such officer or employee's office or employment. 
(c)  As used in this section, the term "confidential" means any information that is not subject to mandatory disclosure pursuant to K.S.A. 45-221, and amendments thereto. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 21-6002. 
Sec. 28-124. - Presenting a false claim; permitting a false claim. 
(a)  Presenting a false claim is, with the intent to defraud, presenting a claim or demand which is false in whole or in part, to a public officer or body authorized to audit, allow or pay such claim. 
(b)  Permitting a false claim is the auditing, allowing or paying of any claim or demand made upon the state or any subdivision thereof or other governmental instrumentality within the state by a public officer or public employee who knows such claim or demand is false or fraudulent in whole or in part. 
(c)  Presenting or permitting a false claim is a public offense within the meaning of this chapter. Upon conviction of presenting or permitting a false claim, a public officer or employee shall forfeit such officer or employee's office or employment. 
(Code 1977, § 17-148) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 21-6004. 
Secs. 28-125-28-146. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes against public peace, K.S.A. 21-4101 et seq. 

Sec. 28-147. - Curfew hours for minors. 
(a)  Definitions . The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Curfew hours means: 
(1)  11:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day; and 
(2)  12:01 a.m. until 6:00 a.m. on any Saturday or Sunday. 
    Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term "emergency" includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, or automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
    Establishment means any privately-owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including, but not limited to, any place of amusement or entertainment. 
    Guardian means: 
(1)  A person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor; or 
(2)  A public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by a court. 
    Minor means any person under 18 years of age. 
    Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. The term "operator" includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a corporation. 
    Parent means a person who is: 
(1)  A natural parent, adoptive parent, or step-parent of another person; or 
(2)  At least 18 years of age and authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of a minor. 
    Public place means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities, and shops. 
    Remain means to: 
(1)  Linger or stay; or 
(2)  Fail to leave premises when requested to do so by a police officer or the owner, operator, or other person in control of the premises. 
    Serious bodily injury means bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of death or that causes death, serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. 
(b)  Offenses . 
(1)  A minor commits an offense if he remains in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours. 
(2)  A parent or guardian of a minor commits an offense if he knowingly permits, or by insufficient control allows, the minor to remain in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours. 
(c)  Defenses . It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (b) of this section that the minor was: 
(1)  Accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian; 
(2)  On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, without any detour or stop; 
(3)  In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
(4)  Engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any detour or stop; 
(5)  Involved in an emergency; 
(6)  On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the residence of a next-door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the police department about the minor's presence; 
(7)  Attending an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor; 
(8)  Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right of assembly; or 
(9)  Married or had been married or had disabilities of minority removed in accordance with K.S.A. 38-108 et seq. 
(d)  Enforcement . Before taking any enforcement action under this section, a police officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and reason for being in the public place. The officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest under this section unless the officer reasonably believes that an offense has occurred and that, based on any response and other circumstances, no defense in subsection (c) of this section is present. 
(e)  Penalties . 
(1)  A person who violates a provision of this chapter is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued, or permitted. Each offense, upon conviction, is punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00, or a definite sentence in the city jail for a term not to exceed six months, or by a combination of any such fine and imprisonment. 
(2)  When required by the state juvenile offenders code, as amended, the municipal court shall waive original jurisdiction over a minor who violates subsection (b)(1) of this section and shall refer the minor to juvenile court. 
(Ord. No. G-94-05, § 1(17-176), 6-27-1994) 
Secs. 28-148-28-177. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes against public safety, K.S.A. 21-6301 et seq. 

Sec. 28-178. - Obstructing streets, sidewalks, public or unoccupied grounds, etc. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, it is unlawful for any person to obstruct any street, alley, sidewalk, crossing, public or unoccupied ground in the city with any kind of vehicle, or with any box, lumber, wood or any other thing; or to place or to cause to be placed in any street or alley or upon any public or unoccupied ground in the city, or in any mine, well, cistern, tank, excavation or reservoir, or in any watercourse, ditch or gutter, any earth, dirt, carcass, filth, trash, rubbish, refuse or other unwholesome or injurious matter. 
(b)  Merchants in the downtown area shall be permitted to display wares, goods and merchandise on the sidewalks so long as the items are displayed in a manner that does not hinder or obstruct pedestrian travel. For purposes of this section, "downtown area" means that area bounded on the north by 7th Street; on the west by Elm Street; on the south by 11th Street; and on the east by Patterson Boulevard. 
(Code 1965, § 20-401; Code 1977, § 17-196) 
Secs. 28-179-28-209. - Reserved.

(Code 1977, § 17-215)

ARTICLE X. - OFFENSES AFFECTING BUSINESS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes affecting business, K.S.A. 21-6501 et seq. 

Sec. 28-237. - Deceptive commercial practices. 
(a)  A deceptive commercial practice is the act, use or employment by any person of any deception, fraud, false pretense, false promise, or knowing misrepresentation of a material fact, with the intent that others shall rely thereon in connection with the sale of any merchandise, whether or not any person has in fact been misled, deceived or damaged thereby. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Merchandise means any objects, wares, goods, commodities, intangibles, real estate or services. 
    Person means any natural person or his legal representative, partnership, corporation (domestic or foreign), company, trust, business entity or association, and any agent, employee, salesman, partner, officer, director, member, stockholder, associate, trustee or cestui que trust thereof. 
    Sale means any sale, offer for sale or attempt to sell any merchandise for any consideration. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to the owner or publisher of any newspaper, magazine, or other printed matter wherein an advertisement appears, or to the owner or operator of a radio or television station which disseminates an advertisement, when such owner, publisher or operator had no knowledge of the intent, design or purpose of the advertisement. 
(d)  Deceptive commercial practice is a public offense within the meaning of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 17-230) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 21-6503. 
Secs. 28-238-28-296. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - HANDBILLS 

Sec. 28-297. - Prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to tack, paint or place in any manner whatsoever any handbills, posters, signs or advertisements upon any utility pole, sidewalk or public property or to throw or scatter any handbills, leaflets, advertisements or other printed matter upon any street, alley, sidewalk, public property or vacant lot within the city. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in any sum not exceeding $50.00. 
Sec. 28-298. - General regulations. 
(a)  Littering is recklessly depositing or causing to be deposited any object or substance into, upon or about: 
(1)  Any public street, highway, alley, road, right-of-way, park or other public place, or any lake, stream, watercourse, or other body of water, except by direction of some public officer or employee authorized by law to direct or permit such acts; or 
(2)  Any private property without the consent of the owner or occupant of such property. 
(b)  Littering is a public offense punishable as follows: 
(1)  Upon a first conviction by a fine of not less than $250.00 nor more than $1,000.00; 
(2)  Upon a second conviction by a fine of not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $2,000.00; and 
(3)  Upon a third or subsequent conviction by a fine of not less than $2,000.00 nor more than $4,000.00. 
(c)  In addition to the fines in subsection (b) of this section, a person convicted of littering shall be required to pick up litter for a time prescribed by and at a place within the jurisdiction of the court. 
Chapter 30 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Fees for use of certain city property. 
(a)  The city may, from time to time, rent certain city-owned facilities to persons, subject to reasonable rules and conditions to be established by the city manager and subject to the payment of rental fees pursuant to the city's fee schedule. 
(b)  The fees set out in the city fee schedule shall be paid to the city clerk, or the clerk's agent, at the time written application is made on the forms provided. 
(c)  Any renters using rented facilities for, or events advertised to or attended by the public, shall provide proof of liability insurance in the amount of $500,000.00 covering each day of the rental period. The insurance shall be obtained from an insurance company authorized to do business in the state. The city shall be named as an additional insured on the policy and the policy shall require the city be given ten days' written notice of cancellation. 
(d)  Camping limit. A maximum parking limit of two weeks is hereby established for the use of the camping facilities. All camping fees are payable in advance. 
(Ord. No. G-79-07, § 1, 10-10-1979; Ord. No. G-80-06, § 1, 5-14-1980; Ord. No. G-82-05, § 9, 5-12-1982; Ord. No. G-83-03, § 1, 2-23-1983; Ord. No. G-86-09, § 1, 10-27-1986; Ord. No. G-96-05, §§ 1, 2, 10-9-1989; Ord. No. G-93-17, § 1(18-1), 12-27-1993; Ord. No. G-94-02, § 1(18-1), 3-14-1994; Ord. No. G-08-06, § 1(18-1), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 30-2. - Special events. 
    Persons or companies wanting to host special events on public streets or property shall complete a special event application and file it with the city clerk. The special event shall meet all requirements set out in the city's special event checklist. 
Secs. 30-3-30-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS 

Sec. 30-23. - Enumeration of specific rules and regulations. 
    The city manager may establish rules and regulations for the management and control of the public parks or the use of other public facilities in the city. 
Chapter 32 - SIGNS AND OTHER ADVERTISING 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Banner means a strip of cloth or other material displaying a design, picture, logo or other writing and intended to be hung or displayed. 
    Ground sign means any sign supported by uprights or braces placed upon or in the ground and not attached to any part of any building. 
    Imprint means the name of a sign erection or outdoor advertising licensee imprinted on a sign. 
    Inspector means the code enforcement officer or such other person as may be designated by the city manager to oversee enforcement of this chapter. 
    Marquee sign means any sign affixed to any marquee hood or canopy on any building extending wholly or in part across the sidewalk, street or alley and supported wholly or in part by such building or marquee. 
    Projecting sign means any sign attached to and supported wholly or in part by any wall of any building and projecting outward from any such wall more than 12 inches. 
    Roof sign means any sign placed on and supported by the roof of any building or the fire walls of any such building and projecting above the walls of such building. Signs on or supported by marquees are not roof signs. 
    Sign means any structure or device erected, constructed or maintained out-of-doors for the purpose of displaying advertising messages, imparting any information or attracting attention for any purpose by means of neon tubes, electric lights, painted pictures or designs, letters, posters, models or replicas, etc., although in the trade various kinds of signs are designated as signs, displays, bulletins, posters, panels or wall signs. 
    Sign hanging and sign erection are synonymous and either term shall refer to any form of installing or constructing any exterior sign. 
    Wall sign means any sign attached to any wall of any building and projecting no more than 12 inches from such wall. 
(Code 1977, § 24-1; Ord. No. G-123, § 1, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-2. - Exemptions from chapter. 
(a)  Painting, cleaning or servicing of existing signs, replacing or changing the lettering on existing signs, painting signs on walls, windows or other surfaces or billposting are expressly exempt from all requirements of this chapter only if no scaffolding or other work rigging is required to be hung or set up over any street or sidewalk, or if the requirements of section 36-6 are complied with. 
(b)  Ground signs or wall signs advertising real estate for sale or rent, or contractor's job site signs not exceeding 36 square feet in area, when placed on the premises advertised for sale or lease or on contractor's job site, are exempt from all provisions of this chapter, provided in the opinion of the inspector or chief of police such signs do not constitute a public hazard by obscuring the view of an intersection or other public thoroughfare. 
(c)  Political signs on private property or the unpaved right-of-way for city streets on private property during the 45-day period prior to any election and the two-day period following any such election; provided, such signs shall not impede sight lines or sight distance for safety reasons. 
(Code 1977, § 24-2; Ord. No. G-123, § 11, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-3. - Inspection of signs generally. 
    The inspector shall have the right to inspect every ground sign, roof sign, wall sign, projecting sign and marquee sign at least once each calendar year. 
(Code 1977, § 24-4; Ord. No. G-123, § 13, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-4. - Notice of improperly installed, erected or maintained sign; corrective action required; removal. 
    Signs and banners shall be maintained in good and readable condition. Missing or damaged parts shall be replaced or repaired in a timely manner. Faded or frayed banners shall be replaced or removed from display. In case any sign or banner shall be installed, erected, maintained or displayed in violation of any of the terms of this chapter, the inspector shall notify by certified mail or by written notice personally served on the owner or lessee of the premises or the owner of such offending sign or banner, or both, to alter or repair such sign or banner so as to comply with this chapter and to secure the necessary permit therefor, if applicable, or to remove the same. If compliance efforts are not initiated within 20 days after notice has been sent to or served upon the owner or lessee, and completed within 90 days from said date, the inspector shall remove such sign at the expense of the owner or lessee of the premises. The city shall give notice to the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property, by first class mail, of the costs of work performed. The notice shall state that the payment is due and payable within 30 days following mailing of the notice. If the costs remain unpaid after 30 days following mailing of notice, a record of the costs shall be certified to the city clerk who shall cause such costs to be assessed against the particular lot or parcel of land on which the work was performed. The city clerk shall certify the assessment to the county clerk at the time other special assessments are certified for spreading on the tax rolls of the county. In addition to remedies available to the city to collect assessments levied against property, if any assessments for costs levied by the city in accordance with this section remain unpaid by the owner of a lot or parcel of ground, the city may collect the amount due in the same manner as a personal debt of the property owner to the city, by bringing an action in the appropriate district court. 
(Code 1977, § 24-5; Ord. No. G-123, § 14, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-5. - Notice of unsafe sign; corrective action required; removal. 
    If, in the opinion of the inspector, any sign becomes insecure or in danger of falling or otherwise unsafe, the owner thereof or the person maintaining the same shall, upon receipt of written notice from the inspector, and in any case within ten days after notice, secure the same in a manner to be approved by the inspector in conformance with the provisions of this chapter. If the owner or lessee of the premises fails to comply with the order within ten days after notice to such person, the inspector shall remove the sign at the expense of such person. 
(Code 1977, § 24-6; Ord. No. G-123, § 15, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-6. - Structural change or relocation of existing sign considered new installation. 
    Any structural change or relocation of any existing sign shall be considered the same as a new installation and subject to all requirements of this chapter as such. 
(Code 1977, § 24-7; Ord. No. G-123, § 9, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-7. - Required materials for projecting signs. 
    All projecting signs of more than 400 square inches in area and/or weighing more than ten pounds must be of metal construction but may have glass or plastic facing if supported by metal frame and supporting members. 
(Code 1977, § 24-8; Ord. No. G-123, § 7, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-8. - Required materials for roof signs. 
    Every roof sign shall be constructed of materials equal to or better than the combustible classification of the supporting roof structure. Paper posters pasted to faces of roof, wall or ground signs designed and maintained for that purpose are exempt from any requirements for noncombustible material. 
(Code 1977, § 24-9; Ord. No. G-123, § 7, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-9. - Location. 
    No sign may be placed or maintained so as to obstruct or prevent the use of any door, window or fire escape or to create or constitute a traffic hazard. No roof sign shall be placed or maintained on any building so as to prevent the free passage from one part of the roof to any other part thereof or interfere with any openings in such roof. All roof signs shall be so constructed and maintained as to leave a clear space of not less than six feet between the roof level and the lowest part of the structure, except necessary supports and braces; and every roof sign shall be set back at least three feet from the inside face of any exterior or fire wall. 
(Code 1977, § 24-10; Ord. No. G-123, § 7, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-10. - Installation of roof, marquee or projecting sign not to increase stresses on supporting members beyond allowable limits. 
    No roof sign, marquee sign or projecting sign may be installed or maintained in such a manner as to increase the stresses on any supporting members of the building walls, roof or marquee beyond the limits allowed by the building code of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 24-11; Ord. No. G-123, § 7, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-11. - Attaching or anchoring signs. 
    No wooden plugs shall be permitted for attaching or anchoring any sign to any building. All signs must be safely and adequately constructed and maintained and if attached to any other structure, such fastenings must be adequate and safe. 
(Code 1977, § 24-12; Ord. No. G-123, § 7, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-12. - Wind loads. 
(a)  Every roof sign or projecting sign must be constructed and braced to withstand a horizontal wind pressure of not less than 30 pounds for every square foot of surface exposed and shall be securely attached in an approved manner. 
(b)  Every ground sign must be constructed and braced to withstand a horizontal wind pressure of not less than 20 pounds for every square foot of surface exposed and shall be supported and anchored in an approved manner. 
(c)  The building code of the city shall be the engineering reference for computing supports and stress members of any sign structure. 
(Code 1977, § 24-13; Ord. No. G-123, § 8, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-13. - Erecting, altering, maintaining signs or structures under canopies on public ground. 
    It shall be unlawful to keep, construct, erect, alter or maintain any sign or structure under the canopies or public ground on: the south side of Eighth Street between Walnut and Maple Street; the west side of Walnut between Eighth Street and the alley south of Ninth Street; both sides of Ninth Street between Walnut and Maple Streets; the east side of Maple Street between Eighth Street and the alley south of Ninth Street; provided, however, each building owner may locate signs beneath the canopies subject to the following requirements and approval of the building inspector: 
(1)  All signs shall be situated at right angles to the canopy fronts; 
(2)  There shall be a minimum of eight feet from the sidewalk to the bottom of each sign; 
(3)  All signs shall not be longer than six feet in length, shall not be more than 12 inches in height and shall not be more than two inches in thickness; 
(4)  All signs shall be made of wood and shall be nonilluminated, and all sign brackets shall be twisted wrought iron and black, brass or copper in color; and 
(5)  The outer end of each sign shall be at least two feet in from the inside edge of the upright column. 
(Code 1977, § 24-14; Ord. No. G-123, § 16(b), 11-10-1971; Ord. No. G-144, § 1, 6-13-1973; Ord. No. G-147, § 2, 7-11-1973; Ord. No. G-74-03, § 1, 4-10-1974; Ord. No. G-74-10, § 1, 9-11-1974) 
Sec. 32-14. - Height and distance requirements for projecting standards. 
(a)  No sign, or any part thereof, may project beyond the curbline or encroach upon any adjacent property and no sign projecting over any sidewalk shall, at its lowest point, be less than eight feet above the sidewalk level. For purposes of this subsection, guy cables, braces and other parts and components of a sign shall be considered a part of such projecting sign. 
(b)  No part of any wall sign may, at any point, extend more than 12 inches from the plane of the wall, except that if the sign is illuminated, the lighting fixtures may extend up to seven feet beyond the face of the sign, but no part of such lighting equipment may be less than eight feet above any sidewalk. 
(c)  Marquee signs may extend to within 24 inches of the curbline, but no part of any such sign shall be less than eight feet above the level of the sidewalk. 
(Code 1977, § 24-15; Ord. No. G-123, §§ 12, 16(a), (c), 11-10-1971; Ord. No. G-147, § 2, 7-11-1973) 
Sec. 32-15. - Sandwich board signs. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions contained within this chapter, any business located in the downtown business district shall be permitted to place a sandwich board sign on the sidewalk, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The sign shall not exceed 36 inches in height or 36 inches in width; 
(2)  The sign shall be displayed only during hours when the business is open to the public; 
(3)  The sign shall be displayed on the sidewalk adjacent to the business premises only. 
Sec. 32-16. - Prohibited signs. 
(a)  Unless expressly permitted elsewhere in this chapter, the following signs are prohibited: 
(1)  Vehicle signs, trailer signs, signs affixed to automobiles, trucks, trailers, or other vehicles parked on any property within the city for the principal purpose of advertising or sign display. This section does not prohibit any form of permanent signage normally attached to a motor vehicle for the purposes of identifying the owner or operator of the vehicle and goods or services it contains or provides, or signs that may be displayed on vehicles or trailers during official parades. The following shall constitute a prima facia violation of this section: 
a.  The advertising or display medium utilized on the vehicle is a sign, device, or structure separate from the vehicle, even though it may be attached thereto; 
b.  The copy or item displayed is readily changeable, including but not limited to repainting such sign, device, or structure; 
c.  The sign, devise, or structure exceeds nine square feet in area; 
(2)  Abandoned signs; 
(3)  Any sign which imitates or resembles an official sign or traffic control device; 
(4)  Any sign which interferes with the safe use of the street by pedestrians, cyclists or vehicles, impedes traffic or interferes with the use or visibility of any traffic control device or other equipment installed by the city or by a utility company; and 
(5)  Signs which obstruct a parking space or utilize such parking space for purposes of locating a sign. 
(b)  Every prohibited or abandoned sign shall be deemed to constitute a public nuisance. The city manager, or his designee, is authorized to abate all prohibited or abandoned signs pursuant to the procedures set forth in article IV of chapter 26. Prohibited signs posted in the public right-of-way or upon public property may be removed by the city code enforcement officer without notice or complying with any abatement procedures of this code. Said signs shall be retained by the city for a period of not less than three working days. Thereafter, any unclaimed signs may be discarded. Should the city be required to remove any prohibited or abandoned sign pursuant to this chapter, the reasonable cost of such removal shall be assessed against the owner of such sign or against the property upon which the sign was located. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall constitute a public offense. 
Sec. 32-17. - Maintenance of roof and projecting signs. 
    Every roof sign and/or projecting sign and all the supports, braces, guys and anchors thereof shall be kept in good repair and, unless made of non-corroding material, shall be thoroughly and properly painted at least once every three years. The inspector may order the removal of any such signs that are not maintained in compliance with the conditions of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 24-18; Ord. No. G-123, § 7, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-18. - Violation to place advertisement on street, sidewalk, tree, etc. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to place any advertisement upon any sidewalk, hydrant, lamppost, tree, utility pole or fence on public property, or in any public street, right-of-way or place within the city, except as provided in sections 32-13, 32-14, 32-43. 
(Code 1977, § 24-19; Ord. No. G-123, § 14, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-19. - Premises near ground signs to be properly maintained. 
    Any person occupying any vacant lot or premises with a ground sign thereon shall be subject to the same duties and responsibilities as the owner of the lot or premises with respect to keeping the same clean, sanitary, inoffensive and free and clear of all noxious substances in the vicinity of such ground sign. 
(Code 1977, § 24-20; Ord. No. G-123, § 16(i), 11-10-1971; Ord. No. G-147, § 2, 7-11-1973) 
Secs. 32-20-32-41. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES 

Sec. 32-42. - Required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of outdoor advertising or sign hanging by erecting or maintaining ground signs, roof signs, wall signs, projecting signs or marquee signs within the corporate limits of the city without first having procured a license from the city clerk to conduct such business. 
(Code 1977, § 24-32; Ord. No. G-123, § 3, 11-10-1971; Ord. No. G-75-02, § 1, 1-22-1975) 
Sec. 32-43. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Any person doing business in the city may be exempted from obtaining a license and insurance for the purpose of erecting, maintaining, removing or relocating his own signs on the premises occupied by his regular business, but he must first obtain a permit as required of licensed sign hangers and meet all other requirements of this article. 
(b)  Any general contractor employed in the removing of an existing sign in connection with remodeling or repair of an existing structure, provided he meets all insurance requirements of this article, shall be exempted from securing a license as a sign erector. 
(c)  The fee required by section 32-45 shall be waived for any person doing his own erection, maintenance, repair or removing of a sign or for any general contractor removing a sign in connection with remodeling or repair of an existing structure, which sign is not to be replaced or relocated. 
(d)  No such exempt person may hire outside help or subcontract any part of the work covered by the permit as a subterfuge to circumvent the licensing of sign hangers, but the work must be done by regular employees of the person obtaining the exemption. 
(Code 1977, § 24-33; Ord. No. G-123, § 16(e), 11-10-1971; Ord. No. G-147, § 2, 7-11-1973) 
Sec. 32-44. - Insurance requirements. 
    No person shall engage within the corporate limits of the city in the business of outdoor advertising or sign erecting, by erecting and/or maintaining ground signs, projecting signs, wall signs, roof signs or marquee signs, without first filing with the city clerk a certificate of insurance evidencing proof of commercial general liability insurance coverage of not less than $1,000,000.00, issued by a reputable insurance company authorized to do business in Kansas. 
(Code 1977, § 24-35; Ord. No. G-123, § 16(g), 11-10-1971; Ord. No. G-147, § 2, 7-11-1973) 
Sec. 32-45. - License requirements. 
    No person shall engage within the corporate limits of the city in the business of outdoor advertising or sign erecting, by erecting or maintaining ground signs, projecting signs, wall signs, roof signs or marquee signs, without first obtaining a contractor's license as required by section 8-391. 
(Code 1977, § 24-36; Ord. No. G-123, § 3, 11-10-1971; Ord. No. G-75-02, § 1, 1-22-1975; Ord. No. G-82-05, § 11, 5-12-1982) 
Sec. 32-46. - Licenses to be signed; issuance. 
    All licenses required by this article shall be signed by the city clerk. No such license shall be issued until the fees herein prescribed have been paid, and until the provisions of section 32-44 have been complied with. 
(Code 1977, § 24-37; Ord. No. G-123, § 3, 11-10-1971; Ord. No. G-75-02, § 1, 1-22-1975) 
Secs. 32-47-32-67. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PERMITS 

Sec. 32-68. - Permit required to erect signs. 
    No ground sign, roof sign, wall sign, projecting sign or marquee sign shall be erected within the corporate limits of the city by any person until a permit therefor has been issued by the inspector. 
(Code 1977, § 24-53; Ord. No. G-123, § 4, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-69. - Conditions precedent to issuance of permit. 
    No permit required by this article shall be granted until after an application therefor has been filed with the inspector showing the plans and specifications, including dimensions, material and pertinent details of construction of proposed structure, until all of the provisions of this article relating to such structure have been complied with and until the prescribed fee for such permit has been paid to the city. 
(Code 1977, § 24-54; Ord. No. G-123, § 4, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-70. - Fees. 
    The fees for permits required by this article shall be in accordance with the city's fee schedule. 
(Code 1977, § 24-55; Ord. No. G-123, § 4, 11-10-1971) 
Sec. 32-71. - Inspection of premises. 
    It shall be the duty of the inspector to inspect premises within the city and to determine whether the person found erecting or altering any sign or banner has a proper permit therefor. 
(Code 1977, § 24-57; Ord. No. G-123, § 6, 11-10-1971; Ord. No. G-147, § 1, 7-11-1973) 
Chapter 34 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Refuse collection and disposal generally, K.S.A. 12-2101; authority to compel and regulate the removal of garbage and filth, K.S.A. 13-436. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial waste means all solid waste emanating from establishments engaged in business including, without limitation, stores, markets, office buildings, restaurants, and multiple family (larger than single- and double-family) dwelling units. 
    Dwelling unit means single- and double-family residential dwellings. 
    Garbage means all kitchen and table refuse and every accumulation of animal, vegetable and other material that attends the preparation, consumption, decay or dealing in or storage of meat, fish, fowl, birds, grain, fruits, vegetables or other types of foods of whatever character and shall include all animal and vegetable refuse from kitchens and all household wastes that shall have resulted from the preparation of food including tin cans and bottles. Dead animals, dishwater and wastewater are not included under the term "garbage." 
    Residential means any enclosure, building, structure or portion thereof occupied by one or more persons for and as living quarters and containing: 
(1)  Two or less individual dwelling units; 
(2)  Roominghouses having no more than four persons in addition to the family of the owner or operator; and 
(3)  Mobile homes, manufactured homes and residential-designed manufactured homes. 
    Rubbish, trash or refuse means all waste materials such as paper, tin cans, bottles, glass containers, paper sacks, boxes, packing materials, rags, ashes, lawn trimmings, tree trimmings, tree branches, limbs, tree trunks and stumps, household waste, and like materials from dwellings and business or industrial establishments, except garbage, sewage and animal excrement, dirt, accumulations from mud traps and settling basins, and salvage materials. 
    Salvage materials means wastepaper, manure and other materials that may be separated and re-used, which might otherwise be disposed of as solid waste, and which, when stored upon any premises or when being hauled over the streets of the city, may result in creating a condition detrimental to the public health and safety 
    Solid waste means garbage, rubbish, trash and refuse. 
    White goods means household appliances, including, but not limited to, televisions, dishwashers, washers, dryers and refrigerators. 
    Yard waste means grass clippings, tree trimmings, shrub and brush trimmings, leaves, limbs, tree trunks and stumps. 
(Code 1965, § 18-201; Code 1977, § 13-1; Ord. No. G-128, § 2(e), 6-30-1972) 
Sec. 34-2. - Placement of garbage into containers required; covering of containers. 
    All garbage accumulated in any household or business establishments in the city shall be placed in suitable metal or plastic containers on the premises of the owner or occupant of such premises. Said container when outside of a building shall be tightly closed and covered at all such times except when removing or depositing garbage, provided that nothing herein shall prevent the disposal of properly shredded garbage by means of a garbage disposal unit properly connected to the sanitary sewer in accordance with the regulations therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 18-106(c); Code 1977, § 13-2) 
Sec. 34-3. - Unlawful deposits.
