    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, place, deposit, leave, or cause to be thrown, placed, deposited or left, in or upon any road, street, highway, alley, park, public ground, vacant lot, or along the banks of or in any creek, stream, or drainage ditch within the city, any solid waste, except in proper containers made and lawfully placed for that purpose. 
Sec. 34-4. - Disposal of substances at rear of building between rear of building and alley line. 
    The space in the rear of any business lot, house or mercantile establishment, between the rear of the building and the alley line, if there is any such vacant space, shall, at all times, be kept clean and clear of all the substances set out in section 34-3 and the occupant of the ground floor of any such business house or mercantile establishment, as set forth hereinbefore, shall be, and is, hereby charged with the duty of keeping said space clean, except such refuse or filth deposited by other occupants of said building whose duty it shall be to remove the same. 
(Code 1965, § 18-103; Code 1977, § 13-5; ) 
Sec. 34-5. - Alley in rear of building to be kept clean. 
    The owner of the ground floor of a dwelling house or the occupant thereof, if the same is not occupied by the owner of said ground floor or dwelling house, shall be charged with the duty of keeping the alley in the rear of such ground floor or dwelling house clean and free from the substances set out in section 34-3. 
(Code 1965, § 18-104; Code 1977, § 13-6) 
Sec. 34-6. - Burning leaves, grass, etc., in the open; approved trash burners. 
(a)  No person shall conduct, cause or permit the open burning of: 
(1)  Refuse, trash, garbage, solid waste and salvage material, including wood, cardboard, shingles or other construction material; 
(2)  Motor oil, rubber, plastics, chemically treated materials or other materials, which produce excessive or noxious smoke, including tires, railroad ties, wiring, oils, paint or similar items; 
(3)  Any hazardous material or waste; or 
(4)  Solid waste generated from an industrial or manufacturing process or from a service or commercial structure. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to set on fire or burn in the open any brush, hay, straw, leaves, grass, weeds or similar material within the city limits, except under the following conditions: 
(1)  Permission shall first be procured from the officer in charge at the city fire department; 
(2)  The burning hours permitted shall be 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. or such other times as may be designated by the officer in charge; 
(3)  Items shall be burned so as not to create a traffic hazard; 
(4)  The use of accelerants is strictly prohibited; 
(5)  The fire shall be constantly attended until completely extinguished and the attendee shall have a continuous supply of water on hand in order to extinguish the fire, if necessary. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit: 
(1)  The chief of the fire department from burning, or causing to be burned, dry weeds or grass from vacant lots anywhere within the limits of the city when, in his opinion, the same is a hazard to other property; 
(2)  Open burning for firefighter training purposes when conducted under the direction, control and supervision of the fire department; 
(3)  Open burning for other special purposes or occasions with approval of the fire chief or his designated representative and subject to such conditions as may be imposed by such person; and 
(4)  Campfires and fires contained in a charcoal grill, camp stove or other cooking or heating device when used for its designed purpose. 
(Code 1965, § 18-306; Code 1977, § 13-10; Ord. No. G-80-14, § 1, 8-27-1980; Ord. No. G-04-05, § 13-10, 6-8-2004) 
Sec. 34-7. - Certain accumulations declared a nuisance; abatement. 
    Any accumulation of rubbish, trash or salvage materials affecting the public health and safety shall constitute a nuisance and may be abated as by law and ordinances provided. 
(Code 1965, § 18-202; Code 1977, § 13-23) 
Sec. 34-8. - Operational requirements of vehicles transporting or hauling trash or rubbish. 
    Any person transporting or hauling solid waste within the city shall, at all times, secure such solid waste in such a manner that none of the contents being transported or hauled will be allowed or permitted to escape. 
(Code 1965, § 18-204; Code 1977, § 13-25) 
Sec. 34-9. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person who violates the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 or be confined in the city jail not to exceed three months, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(b)  A second conviction for a violation of this chapter within a 12-month period shall result in a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $500.00 or confinement in the city jail not to exceed six months, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(c)  A third conviction for a violation of this chapter within a 12-month period, shall result in a fine of not less than $250.00 nor more than $1,000.00 or confinement in the city jail not to exceed one year, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(d)  Each day a violation of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. G-77-10, §§ 1, 2, 8-10-1977) 
Secs. 34-10-34-62. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL OF RUBBISH, TRASH OR SALVAGE MATERIALS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Refuse collection and disposal generally, K.S.A. 12-2101 et seq. 

Sec. 34-63. - Solid waste collection. 
(a)  The city shall provide for the collection and disposal of all solid waste from dwelling units within the city limits and no other person shall collect and dispose of solid waste from dwelling units within the city unless authorized by license or other formal agreement with the city. The city may provide the collection and disposal service by contracting with a person, firm, corporation or any combination thereof, for the entire city or portions thereof, as deemed to be in the best interests of the city, and may limit collection to pick up at the curb in the discretion of the board of commissioners. 
(b)  The collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste shall be, at all times, under the general supervision of the city manager or director of public works as the manager's duly authorized agent who shall have the authority to make additional rules and regulations not inconsistent with the terms and provisions of this article. Exceptions to these rules must be approved by the director of public works. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit any person from transporting his own solid waste, but intervals of disposal shall be not less than that prescribed for the solid waste collection system of the city, and the disposal shall be in the same manner and place prescribed for the city system. Those persons transporting or otherwise disposing of their own solid waste shall not be relieved from the minimum charge imposed in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any residence, institution, professional, commercial, or business establishment, or for contractors or builders engaged in construction or remodeling projects, to deposit or accumulate solid waste in or upon any lot, parcel of land, public or private drive, alley, street or other place in the city. No person shall permit or allow any solid waste to be scattered about in his yard, or upon the premises occupied by him, except yard waste, or to throw or deposit any solid waste upon the premises of any other person or upon any of the streets, alleys or other public places in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 13-32; Ord. No. G-04-02, § 13-32, 1-13-2004) 
Sec. 34-64. - Prohibited materials. 
    The following materials shall not be collected: 
(1)  Dangerous material such as hot ashes, radioactive materials, acids, caustics, diseased or infected materials, highly volatile materials, or explosives; 
(2)  Sod, dirt, sand, rocks, bricks, or other masonry unless packaged in accordance with this article, or placed in roll-off containers designated for such purpose; 
(3)  Any item posing unusual risk of injury to personnel or damage to the collection vehicle; 
(4)  Commercial waste; 
(5)  Cold ashes, sawdust, sand, dirt, powdery material, small gravel or material whose particles are less than one inch in diameter, herbicides, insecticides, other home and garden chemicals, animal manure, and litter box refuse, unless such items are sealed in a durable, disposable container prior to being placed out for collection; 
(6)  Materials defined as hazardous or infectious by federal or state agencies; 
(7)  Boxes or cartons larger than 30 inches per side unless collapsed or otherwise reduced in size so the item will easily fit into the collection vehicle; 
(8)  Yard waste, except as provided in section 34-67; or 
(9)  White goods, except as provided by rules established by the director of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 18-213; Code 1977, § 13-39; Ord. No. G-04-02, § 13-39, 1-13-2004) 
Sec. 34-65. - Providing containers. 
    The city or its contractor will provide each dwelling unit with one portable container adequate to contain the amount of solid waste ordinarily accumulated at such place during the intervals between collections. Lost, stolen or damaged containers, or containers deemed no longer usable due to the placement of prohibited materials therein, will be replaced at the customer's cost. The customer will be responsible for clean-up of solid waste scattered or spilled by animals, wind or other causes before arrival of the collection crew. 
(Code 1965, § 18-207; Code 1977, § 13-34; Ord. No. G-82-05, § 8, 5-12-1982; Ord. No. G-04-02, § 13-34, 1-13-2004) 
Sec. 34-66. - Size and weight restrictions. 
    No solid waste container, when loaded, shall weigh more than 100 pounds, and no separate item of solid waste manually collected shall weigh more than 65 pounds, nor shall it be of such a size, volume or shape as to exceed what one person can reasonably be expected to lift and empty into a collection vehicle. 
(Code 1965, § 18-209; Code 1977, § 13-34; Ord. No. G-04-02, § 13-35, 1-13-2004) 
Sec. 34-67. - Yard, shrub, or tree trimmings; grass; leaves. 
    Yard, shrub, or tree trimmings not bundled or placed in approved containers will not be collected. Bundles must be tied securely, shall not be more than 18 inches in diameter, not more than four feet long nor more than 65 pounds in weight. Yard, shrub, and tree trimmings placed in cans, bags, or roll-out carts are not to extend more than 12-inches above the top of the can, bag or cart, or be so tightly packed that they must be pulled from the container by hand. 
(Code 1965, § 18-210; Code 1977, § 13-36; Ord. No. G-04-02, § 13-36, 1-13-2004) 
Sec. 34-68. - Placement of containers for collection. 
(a)  Unless another pickup point has been approved by the director of public works, all portable containers containing solid waste, upon days of collection thereof, shall be placed by the occupant outside of any existing yard fence and within six feet of the curb adjacent to the dwelling unit. 
(b)  Collection at the door or other agreed location may be authorized by the director of public works for hardship cases arising from physical impairment upon written application. Such special collection service shall be provided for a specified period, subject to renewal. 
(c)  Containers shall be placed in a clearly accessible and uncluttered area to minimize risk of injury to the collector. Dogs tethered near solid waste containers must be where they cannot interfere with the collection of solid waste. 
(d)  To ensure collection on the scheduled day, containers and other properly packaged solid waste must be placed at the designated point of collection before 5:00 a.m. on the scheduled day of collection, but not earlier than 24 hours before that time. 
(e)  After collection, the crew shall return the reusable containers to the spot where they were set out. Containers shall be removed from the curb by the customer within 24 hours after collection. Solid waste left by the collection crew due to improper packaging must be removed from the curb as promptly as possible after the collection crew has departed. The city shall not be responsible for the security of containers after the collection crew has departed. 
(Code 1965, § 18-214; Code 1977, § 13-37; Ord. No. G-04-02, § 13-37, 1-13-2004; Ord. No. G-04-05, § 3, 6-8-2004) 
Sec. 34-69. - Unlawful acts. 
    Unless authorized hereby to collect and dispose of solid waste, it shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Remove any portion of the contents of any solid waste container; 
(2)  Upset, turn over, remove or carry away a solid waste container, or lid thereto, or to damage such container or lid in any manner; 
(3)  Place or deposit solid waste in a dwelling unit container other than one that has been provided for his use, or a container provided and marked for public use; 
(4)  Set out, or cause to be set out, solid waste for collection that does not originate from the premises where it is set out unless specifically approved by the director of public works in each case; 
(5)  Place any material other than solid waste in any city-provided container except with prior authorization by the director of public works; or 
(6)  Place solid waste in any container in such a manner as to prevent proper closure of the container lid. 
(Code 1965, § 18-212; Code 1977, § 13-38; Ord. No. G-04-02, § 13-38, 1-13-2004) 
Sec. 34-70. - Bulky pickup. 
    The city may provide for the pickup of bulky items within the city, which may include items such as furniture, carpeting, appliances, televisions, mattresses, hot water tanks, fencing, and do-it-yourself remodeling project waste. Any person disposing of such items through the bulky pickup process shall comply with the rules and regulations adopted by the city relative to such process. A copy of such rules and regulations shall be kept on file and available for inspection at the city clerk's office. All bulky items shall be placed at the curb for pickup not more than 72 hours prior to the scheduled pickup day. A violation of this ordinance shall constitute a public offense." 
Sec. 34-71. - Collection charges. 
    The board of commissioners shall, by resolution, prescribe charges for the service of collection and disposal of solid waste. Such charges shall be paid to the city finance department and shall be billed each month. The solid waste collection charge shall be levied against every dwelling unit within the city limits which is receiving city water, sewer or electric service and every occupied premises even though water, sewer or electric service is not provided at the premises concerned, or when the water, sewer and/or electric service is paid for by other parties. Should the charge for solid waste collection become delinquent, the water and/or electric service shall be discontinued under the terms as provided for failure to pay for such water and/or electric service, unless otherwise prohibited by law. Other appropriate legal means are authorized for delinquent accounts where water service is not provided. Recipients of bills for solid waste disposal charges which they believe to be erroneous must report the possible error to the city finance department's utility billing office within 30 days so that any required corrections may be made. The city manager will make recommendations to the board of commissioners concerning solid waste collection charges as often as necessary. 
(Code 1965, § 18-208; Code 1977, § 13-40; Ord. No. G-04-02, § 13-40, 1-13-2004) 
Sec. 34-72. - License required; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to collect, transport or haul over any of the streets of the city or dispose of any solid waste accumulated in the city without a proper license for such collection and disposal. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed to apply to the street department or other departments of the city, nor to persons who collect and transport rubbish and trash produced on premises owned or occupied by them, nor to tree trimmers or tree surgeons who do not dispose of tree trimmings or tree trunks at the city dump facilities; provided, however, such persons, owners or producers shall comply with all regulations provided by this division for the transportation of refuse over the streets. 
(Ord. No. G-04-05, § 4, 6-8-2004) 
Sec. 34-73. - Application and license fees. 
(a)  Each person required by this division to be licensed to collect or remove rubbish or trash within the city shall file with the city clerk an application for such license in such form as shall be prescribed by the city clerk and pay the applicable license fee in accordance with the city's fee schedule. 
(b)  No license to collect or remove rubbish or trash within the city shall be issued until the vehicle to be licensed and operated under the rated license applied for shall be inspected and approved by the police department to ensure compliance with city ordinances and state statutes relating to equipment and operation of motor vehicles. 
(c)  The city clerk, upon recommendation of the police department, shall issue a license to persons qualified under the provisions of this division to collect or remove rubbish or trash within the city in the manner and upon the conditions of this division. 
(Ord. No. G-04-05, § 4, 6-8-2004) 
Sec. 34-74. - Transferability. 
    No license to collect or remove rubbish or trash within the city issued under the provisions of this division shall be assigned or transferred by the licensee. Any such licensee may, however, change the registration of the vehicle operated under his license upon the following conditions: 
(1)  The vehicle to be newly registered shall be inspected and approved by the police department in the manner provided in section 34-73; and 
(2)  The registration of the vehicle theretofore operated under such license shall be surrendered. 
(Ord. No. G-04-05, § 4, 6-8-2004) 
Sec. 34-75. - Revocation; right of appeal. 
    In the event any person licensed pursuant to this division fails to comply with any provision of this division, the city clerk may, upon 48 hours' written notice to such licensee, revoke and cancel such license. Any licensee feeling aggrieved at such revocation may appeal, within five days, the action of the city clerk to the board of commissioners of the city. In no event will any portion of the license fee be refunded to the licensee upon revocation of such license. 
(Ord. No. G-04-05, § 4, 6-8-2004) 
Sec. 34-76. - Vehicle construction and equipment requirements. 
    All vehicles licensed for operation to collect and remove rubbish or trash within the city under the provisions of this division shall be constructed and equipped as follows: 
(1)  Construction of the vehicle shall be such that trash or rubbish loaded therein or transported thereby shall be securely contained; and 
(2)  All vehicles shall be equipped with a permanently attached cover, either of rigid construction or a fabric material. 
(Ord. No. G-04-05, § 4, 6-8-2004) 
Secs. 34-77-34-93. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LITTERING 

Sec. 34-94. - Placement of litter in receptacles. 
    Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1977, § 13-71; Ord. No. G-77-02, § 4,1-26-1977) 
Chapter 36 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Sidewalks generally, K.S.A. 12-1801 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 36-1. - Setting or erecting poles or placing obstructions on or in streets or sidewalks prohibited except with permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to set or erect any pole or post or place any other obstruction, or in any manner direct, aid or assist in setting or erecting such pole or post or in placing any obstruction, in or on any street or sidewalk except: 
(1)  As may be authorized under a permit issued in accordance with ordinances of the city relating to signs or sidewalk dining; 
(2)  In zoning districts in which the display of goods upon a sidewalk is permitted; or 
(3)  In areas where the sidewalk abuts the curb and a pole is necessary to support a mailbox. 
(Code 1965, § 20-404; Code 1977, § 25-1) 
Sec. 36-2. - Encroaching on streets, sidewalks or public grounds with building, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to encroach upon, into or over any street, sidewalk or public ground in the city with any house, building, fixture or display of goods or other things except: awnings; signs as may be authorized in accordance with the ordinances of the city relating thereto; or the display of goods in zoning districts permitting the same. 
(Code 1965, § 20-402; Code 1977, § 25-2) 
Sec. 36-3. - Transporting materials over streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drag any tree, tree limb or branch, shrub, vine, pole or other material on, over or along any street or public way. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to transport any of the material named in subsection (a) of this section on, over or along any street or public way, except when such material is properly loaded on or in a vehicle in such a manner that no part of the material shall drag upon the surface of the street or public way. 
(Code 1965, §§ 20-407, 20-408; Code 1977, § 25-3) 
Sec. 36-4. - Filling in gutters or ditches. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fill in or obstruct any gutter or ditch in the city with any dirt, ashes, rock, debris, concrete, cinders, shale or any other substance or to, in any manner, obstruct the natural flow of water down any such gutter or ditch. 
(b)  This section shall not prohibit a person from placing a tile or culvert in any such gutter or ditch for the purpose of making a driveway or walk from any street or alley into private property in such a manner as not to interfere with the natural flow of water down any such gutter or ditch, and in such a manner as not to create a hazard or dangerous defect in such street or alley; provided, however, any person desiring to place a tile or culvert in such gutter or ditch shall place the same under the directions of the public works director. 
(Code 1965, § 20-403; Code 1977, § 25-5) 
Sec. 36-5. - Crossing, cutting, breaking curbs, gutters or sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully drive, or cause or permit to be driven, any vehicle or machinery over or across any curb or sidewalk in any street of the city or to damage, break or cut any curb, gutter or sidewalk, except as may be authorized under a permit issued in accordance with ordinances of the city relating to street parking, curbs and gutters and as hereinafter provided in article III of this chapter for the construction of driveway entrances. 
(Code 1965, § 20-202; Code 1977, § 25-7; Ord. No. G-82-09, § 1, 6-9-82) 
Sec. 36-6. - Temporary scaffolding; barricades. 
    No scaffolding or other work rigging may be placed over any sidewalk or street under which pedestrians or vehicles may pass without first notifying the city and securing authorization to do so from the director of public works, or his designee. The person performing the work shall provide the city with a certificate of insurance evidencing proof of commercial general liability insurance coverage of not less than $1,000,000.00, issued by a reputable insurance company authorized to do business in Kansas. It shall be the responsibility of the person performing the work to erect temporary barricades to protect pedestrians and vehicles around the scaffolding or rigging, until removal of the same. 
(Code 1977, § 24-17; Ord. No. G-123, § 10, 11-10-1971) 
Secs. 36-7-36-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-29. - Compliance with plans and specifications required; permit required. 
    All public sidewalks hereafter constructed, repaired or reconstructed within the city shall be in accordance with the plans and specifications adopted by ordinances by the board of commissioners. A copy of the plans and specifications shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and the city engineering department. It shall be unlawful to construct, reconstruct or repair any sidewalk within the city until the plans first have been approved by the engineering department and a permit issued for such work. 
(Code 1965, § 20-101; Code 1977, § 25-18) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt sidewalk plans and specifications by reference, K.S.A. 12-1802. 
Sec. 36-30. - General duties of engineering department; approval of construction required. 
    The engineering department shall have the authority to oversee and supervise the construction of all sidewalks in the city, whether built by the property owners or the city, and to inspect all materials used in the construction of sidewalks under this article. For the purpose of making the inspection of any material used or about to be used in the construction of any sidewalk, the engineering department or its designee shall have the right to take a sufficient amount thereof for testing purposes, and retain the same in its possession, and to prevent the use of any materials which do not conform with the provisions of this article. No sidewalks shall be constructed without prior approval of the engineering department, and the same shall be subject to the final approval of the engineering department. 
(Code 1965, § 20-107; Code 1977, § 25-19) 
Sec. 36-31. - Alignment and grade. 
    All sidewalks constructed or reconstructed in the city shall be constructed on the established grade and in compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act. Where no grade has been established, the owner of abutting property may construct a sidewalk on the natural grade. If the grade has been established, the city's engineering department shall furnish the property owner with the official grade. 
State Law reference- Establishment of street grade, K.S.A. 12-1807. 
Sec. 36-32. - Width and location. 
    All sidewalks shall be of single-course construction and shall be constructed and laid in accordance with standard plans and specifications hereby adopted by reference and filed in the office of the city clerk as provided by K.S.A. 12-1802. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to construct, reconstruct or repair any sidewalk, except as provided by this article. 
Sec. 36-33. - Steps. 
    No steps in the sidewalk will be allowed except at the curb, and then only by permission of the engineering department. 
(Code 1965, § 20-105; Code 1977, § 25-24) 
Sec. 36-34. - Construction by city generally. 
    All sidewalks constructed by the city shall be built by contract on bids based on plans, specifications and estimates prepared by the engineering department in the same manner as those prepared for other public improvements carried on by the city; provided, however, the city may utilize the public works department for purposes of constructing or repairing any sidewalk without observing the bid process. 
(Code 1965, § 20-108; Code 1977, § 25-25) 
Sec. 36-35. - Property owner or occupant to repair sidewalk. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of real property adjoining a public sidewalk to keep the same in a good and proper state of repair. The repair shall be made with material having quality equal to that required for new construction. 
(Code 1965, § 20-109; Code 1977, § 25-26) 
State Law reference- Repairs of sidewalks by owners of property abutting the sidewalks, K.S.A. 12-1808. 
Sec. 36-36. - Repairs by city; costs. 
    If the owners or occupants of land adjoining public sidewalks shall refuse, neglect or fail to repair the same, the city engineering department shall have the authority, after giving five days' written notice to each owner or his agent, if known, of the necessity of repair, and without such notice if the lot or parcel of land is unoccupied, to make repairs at any time, keeping an accurate account of the cost thereof and reporting the same to the board of commissioners. The board shall levy a special assessment against the lot or parcel of land abutting on the sidewalk so repaired for the costs of such repairs, which shall be collected as other special assessments according to law. 
(Code 1965, § 20-110; Code 1977, § 25-27) 
State Law reference- Authority for city to make repairs and levy special assessment to recover costs, K.S.A. 12-1808. 
Sec. 36-37. - Condemnation and reconstruction. 
    When any sidewalk, in the opinion of the board of commissioners, becomes inadequate or unsafe for travel thereon, the board may adopt a resolution condemning such walk and providing for the construction of a new walk in place of the walk condemned. The resolution providing for the reconstruction of a sidewalk shall give the owner of the abutting property not less than 30 days nor more than 60 days after is publication one time in the official city newspaper in which to commence reconstruction of the sidewalk at the owner's expense. If the sidewalk is not reconstructed by the property owner within the time specified, the board of commissioners shall cause the work to be done by contract. The board shall levy a special assessment against the lot or parcel of land abutting on the sidewalk for the costs of such reconstruction, which shall be collected as other special assessments according to law. 
(Code 1965, § 20-111; Code 1977, § 25-28) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1804. 
Sec. 36-38. - Opening of cellar door through sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, provide, cause or allow any cellar door to be opened through the sidewalk which is not properly protected and guarded with grating or properly railed and guarded subject to the approval of the city engineering department. 
(Code 1965, § 20-106; Code 1977, § 25-29) 
Secs. 36-39-36-64. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL 

Sec. 36-65. - Snow removal by city. 
    During snow removal operations, the accumulated windrow of snow will be deposited to the shoulder, curb or ditch. Driveways along the route may be impacted by the windrow. The city assumes no responsibility or liability for the removal of snow deposited on driveways as a result of snow removal operations. 
Sec. 36-66. - Mailboxes. 
    It is the policy of the city to repair or replace only those mailboxes that have been damaged due to direct contact with the city's snow plow. Damages to mailboxes caused by the movement of snow are not compensable. Mailboxes struck directly by the city's snow plow will be temporarily repaired within a reasonable time and permanently repaired or replaced when weather conditions are suitable and city personnel is available. Replacement mailboxes will consist of a standard sized metal mailbox mounted on a suitable post. 
Sec. 36-67. - Turf/landscaping. 
    Landscaping and lawns, including, but not limited to, grass, shrubs, trees, yard art and other objects may be damaged or destroyed during snow removal operations. All vegetation and objects within the snow plow's path or the windrow created by the plow are there at the owner's or possessor's risk. Damages to such vegetation or objects is not compensable. 
Secs. 36-68-36-92. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SIDEWALK DINING LICENSE 

Sec. 36-93. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means a hospitality establishment, or a person authorized to act on its behalf, that has filed with the city clerk an application for a sidewalk dining license. 
    Hospitality establishment means any business, however organized, that sells food, beverages, or both for consumption by patrons on the premises. 
    Licensee means any hospitality establishment licensed by the city under this division to use a sidewalk for sidewalk dining. 
    Sidewalk means the public right-of-way or easement adjoining the property line of a hospitality establishment. 
    Sidewalk dining means the consumption of food, beverages, or both by patrons of a hospitality establishment outdoors on a specific area of a sidewalk set aside for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. G-13-02, § 1(25-73), 5-28-2013) 
Sec. 36-94. - Required; license fee. 
(a)  No hospitality establishment shall permit sidewalk dining without first obtaining a sidewalk dining license. The sidewalk dining license shall contain the seal of the city, the name and mailing address of the licensee, and the expiration date of the license. The sidewalk dining license shall be valid until December 31 at 12:00 midnight of the year it was issued. 
(b)  The fee for a sidewalk dining license shall be as provided in the city's fee schedule. The fee shall be considered to be in the nature of a lease payment for the commercial use of the sidewalk. The sidewalk dining license fee shall not be pro-rated and shall not be refunded in the case of suspension or revocation of a sidewalk dining license. 
(Ord. No. G-13-02, § 1(25-74), 5-28-2013) 
Sec. 36-95. - Application. 
    Application for a sidewalk dining license shall be made to the city clerk on a form provided by the city clerk for that purpose. The applicant shall complete the form in full and shall provide, at the least, the following: 
(1)  The name of the hospitality establishment to be licensed, including its email address, business address, business telephone, and mailing address. 
(2)  If the hospitality establishment to be licensed is a corporation, partnership, or other business organization, the names, addresses, and dates of birth of all officers, directors, partners, or members. 
(3)  The name of the manager of the hospitality establishment, his telephone number, mailing address, and e-mail address. 
(4)  Remittance of the sidewalk dining license fee in the amount established at section 36-94. 
(5)  A copy of a certificate of insurance, in accordance with section 36-97(3), establishing that the applicant has procured appropriate liability insurance and that the insurance is current. 
(6)  A copy of the applicant's state food establishment license. 
(7)  A copy of the applicant's state sales and liquor tax reports, if any, for the preceding 12 months. 
(8)  A statement that the applicant has submitted a site plan to the city planning office for approval. 
(9)  The applicant's signature and the date. 
(Ord. No. G-13-02, § 1(25-75), 5-28-2013) 
Sec. 36-96. - Issuance; denial. 
(a)  The city clerk shall review each application for a sidewalk dining license. Within a reasonable time thereafter, the city clerk shall submit the application to the board of commissioners for approval unless: 
(1)  The application is incomplete; or 
(2)  The hospitality establishment has had a sidewalk dining license revoked by the city for any reason within the preceding two years. 
(b)  If the application is incomplete, then the city clerk shall notify the applicant and shall allow the applicant additional time to complete the application. Within a reasonable time after its completion, the city clerk shall submit the completed application to the board of commissioners for approval. 
(c)  If the hospitality establishment has had a sidewalk dining license revoked within the two previous years under section 36-100, then the city clerk shall deny the application by giving notice of denial to the applicant. notice of denial shall be in writing, shall be mailed to the applicant at his given address, shall inform the applicant of the reason for denial, and shall inform the applicant that he has 14 days from the date of the notice of denial within which to submit to the city clerk, in writing, a request for a public hearing before the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. G-13-02, § 1(25-76), 5-28-2013) 
Sec. 36-97. - Conditions. 
    Each sidewalk dining license issued by the board of commissioners shall be subject to the following conditions and requirements: 
(1)  The use of the sidewalk shall be in conformance with the zoning regulations governing the real property upon which the licensee is located. The use shall be limited to the sale, possession, and consumption of food, beverages, or both as part of the business of the licensee. 
(2)  In conjunction with its application for a sidewalk dining license, the applicant shall submit a site plan to the city planning office for approval. The site plan shall include the following: 
a.  Architectural elevation drawings. 
b.  The square footage of sidewalk dining area. 
c.  A drawing or diagram showing: 
1.  The seating configuration within the sidewalk dining area; 
2.  A minimum of four feet width of unobstructed sidewalk reserved for pedestrian use within the sidewalk dining area; and 
3.  Any umbrellas proposed to be maintained within or overhanging the sidewalk dining area or the sidewalk, which shall maintain a minimum distance of 80 inches between the sidewalk surface and the lowest part of the umbrella's canopy. 
(3)  The licensee shall carry an insurance policy issued by a reputable insurance company licensed to do business in the state. The policy shall insure the licensee in an amount not less than $500,000.00 per single incident for any liability associated with the failure of the licensee, its employees, agents, servants, invitees, or patrons, to exercise reasonable care and diligence in the use of the sidewalk. Proof of insurance shall be submitted to the city clerk on a standard ACORD form, or substantially similar form as approved by the city clerk, and shall establish that the licensee maintains the requisite insurance and that it is current. The certificate shall also require the insurance carrier to notify the city at least 30 days in advance of any change in terms and conditions of the policy, including cancellation for any reason, and in advance of any expiration of the policy term. 
(4)  The city may require, at any time and for any reason, the removal of any fixtures placed on the sidewalk pursuant to this division. The licensee shall be responsible for any costs incurred in the removal of fixtures and shall return the sidewalk to applicable sidewalk standards. If the licensee is no longer the tenant of the real property at the time that removal is required, then the owner of record of the real property shall be responsible for any costs incurred in removing the fixtures and in returning the sidewalk to applicable sidewalk standards. 
(5)  The board of commissioners may permit the licensee to serve and the licensee's patrons to purchase, possess, and consume alcoholic liquor and/or cereal malt beverages within the licensee's sidewalk dining area in accordance with this Code. The licensee shall also comply with all state and city laws and ordinances governing the sale, possession, and consumption of alcoholic liquor and cereal malt beverages. 
(6)  A licensee shall retain the sidewalk dining license on the premises and shall make it readily accessible for viewing by city personnel. 
(7)  No sidewalk dining license issued in accordance with the provisions of this division shall be used by any person other than the licensee to whom it was issued. 
(Ord. No. G-13-02, § 1(25-77), 5-28-2013) 
Sec. 36-98. - Restrictions. 
    No sidewalk dining license will be issued under this division to any hospitality establishment that does not derive at least 50 percent of its gross receipts from the sale of food and non-alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. G-13-02, § 1(25-78), 5-28-2013) 
Sec. 36-99. - Notice of violation. 
    Any licensee determined by the city to be in violation of any provision of this division shall be sent a notice of violation. The notice of violation shall be sent by certified mail to the licensee, or personally served upon the manager of the hospitality establishment. The notice of violation shall state: 
(1)  The condition that has caused the violation; 
(2)  The time within which the licensee must cure the violation; and 
(3)  That the licensee shall have 14 days from the date of the notice of violation to request, in writing, a public hearing before the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. G-13-02, § 1(25-79), 5-28-2013) 
Sec. 36-100. - Suspension; revocation. 
    If the continued operation of the sidewalk dining is determined by the city to be injurious to the health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the city, or if the licensee has failed to cure a violation of this division, the city shall send to the licensee either a notice of suspension or a notice of revocation. 
(Ord. No. G-13-02, § 1(25-80), 5-28-2013) 
Sec. 36-101. - Public hearing. 
(a)  Any applicant or licensee, aggrieved by the action of the city in denying an application for a sidewalk dining license, in issuing a notice of violation, in suspending a sidewalk dining license, or in revoking a sidewalk dining license, shall have the right to a public hearing before the board of commissioners by requesting such a hearing within 14 days of the date of the notice of denial, notice of violation, notice of suspension, or notice of revocation. The request for hearing must be in writing, must be delivered to the city clerk, and must set forth why the applicant or licensee believes that the notice of denial, notice of violation, notice of suspension, or notice of revocation is in error. After the request for hearing is filed, the board of commissioners shall set a time and place for the hearing. notice of the hearing shall be given to the owner in the same manner as the notice of denial, notice of violation, notice of suspension, or notice of revocation. 
(b)  If the hearing involves a notice of denial, the board of commissioners shall not grant a sidewalk license unless the applicant establishes: 
(1)  That the notice of denial was issued in error; or 
(2)  That it is within the public's interest to approve the application for a sidewalk dining license. 
The board of commissioners shall base its decision on the credible evidence adduced at the public hearing and shall make findings of fact sufficient to support its determination. 
(c)  If the hearing involves a notice of violation, notice of suspension, or notice of revocation, the board of commissioners shall affirm, reverse, or modify the notice of violation, notice of suspension, or notice of revocation. The board of commissioners shall reverse the decision of city staff only if it finds that the notice of violation, notice of suspension, or notice of revocation was issued erroneously. The board of commissioners shall base its decision on the credible evidence adduced at the public hearing and shall make findings of fact sufficient to support its determination. 
(d)  In the event of a public hearing, the decision of the board of commissioners shall be the final decision of the city. If no hearing is requested, then the notice of denial, notice of violation, notice of suspension, or notice of revocation shall be the final decision of the city. 
(Ord. No. G-13-02, § 1(25-81), 5-28-2013) 
Sec. 36-102. - Administrative regulations. 
(a)  In order to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the community, the city manager or his designee shall have the power to promulgate reasonable administrative regulations governing a licensee's use of the sidewalk for sidewalk dining. Any regulations promulgated in accordance with this division shall be dated and shall be available for inspection by the public during reasonable business hours. A licensee shall receive a copy of any regulations at the time of the issuance of any sidewalk dining license or the renewal of a sidewalk dining license. 
(b)  The licensee shall comply with all regulations promulgated by the city manager or his designee in accordance with this division. Failure to abide with any regulation shall be grounds for notice of violation, notice of suspension, or notice of revocation pursuant to this division. 
(Ord. No. G-13-02, § 1(25-82), 5-28-2013) 
Secs. 36-103-36-132. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 36-133. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial driveway entrance means all such areaways affording access to private property upon which the conduct of a commercial business, or the affording of access to public property upon which a public function or convenience is conducted, involving the servicing, storing or parking of motor vehicles. 
    Corner means a point of intersection of the lines of two street faces extended into the street intersection. 
    Curb parking space means the length of the curb equal to 20 feet where an automobile or other vehicle can park parallel thereto. 
    Curb return means the portion of a curb nearest to a driveway entrance which includes the radius of curvature, or the ramp-type lug or commercial- or industrial-type pavements and which connects the driveway entrance to the street curb. 
    Driveway means a place on private property for the operation of automobiles and other vehicles. 
    Driveway entrance means an area, construction or facility between the roadway of the public street and private property intended to provide access for vehicles from the roadway of a public street to private property. 
    Outside sidewalk line means a line parallel to the property line along the edge of the sidewalk nearest the street, roadway or curb; or where no sidewalk exists, a line in the street parking parallel to and not less than four feet from the property line of adjacent lots. 
    Parcel of land means a lot or tract of land officially recorded under one ownership. 
    Permittee means a person to whom a permit required by section 36-135 is issued. 
    Private driveway entrance means every driveway entrance not constituting a commercial driveway entrance shall be classified as a private driveway entrance. 
(Code 1965, § 20-201; Code 1977, app. C, § 25-83) 
Sec. 36-134. - Engineering department to enforce article and supervise work. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineering department to enforce the provisions of this article and to supervise all work authorized by a permit issued pursuant to this article. Upon completion of any such work the engineering department's approval shall be entered on the permit. 
(Code 1965, § 20-206; Code 1977, § 25-84) 
Sec. 36-135. - Permit required to build or construct driveway entrance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to build or construct a driveway entrance across the curbing or sidewalk or sidewalk space of any street thoroughfare in the city without first obtaining a permit to construct and use such crossing or driveway for commercial purposes; and it shall be unlawful for any person to build or construct a driveway entrance across the curbing or sidewalk or sidewalk space of any street thoroughfare in the city without first obtaining a permit from the engineering department to construct and use such crossing or driveway for residential use. 
(Code 1965, § 20-213; Code 1977, § 25-85; Ord. No. G-82-09, § 2, 6-9-1982; Ord. No. G-83-11, § 1, 6-22-1983) 
Sec. 36-136. - General requirements for construction of driveway entrances. 
    The construction of driveway entrances by the cutting and removal of curbs or gutters shall be authorized upon the issuance of a permit by engineering department, in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  No driveway entrance shall be constructed which will interfere with public facilities, including street lighting poles, traffic-signal standards, signs, catch basins, hydrants, crosswalks, loading zones, utility poles, fire-alarm supports, underground pipes or ducts or other necessary street structures. 
(2)  No driveway entrance for a private driveway shall exceed 20 feet in width; and for a commercial driveway, more than 40 feet in width. 
(3)  No curb-cutting width for a private driveway shall exceed 32 feet, nor shall the radius of the curb return be less than four feet or more than six feet. No curb-cutting width for a commercial driveway shall exceed 60 feet, nor shall the radius of the curb return be less than six feet or more than ten feet. 
(4)  The sides, edges or curbs of driveway entrances shall be at right angles to the street curb except for the curb return. 
(5)  No driveway entrances shall be constructed across any sidewalk unless such sidewalk is constructed or reconstructed in accordance with specifications pertaining to the construction of sidewalks to be used as driveway entrances. 
(6)  No driveway entrance shall be constructed in a manner to change or interfere with the gutter flow line or sidewalk grade where such driveway entrance crosses any such gutter or sidewalk, except upon approval of the engineering department. 
(7)  The sidewalk and curb shall, insofar as possible, be cut and removed at the nearest joint, and, upon replacement and reconstruction of a sidewalk at an entrance, suitable joints shall be provided in the construction of the curb return and any pavement in connection with an entrance or driveway where the same come into contact; all such spaces shall be filled by a bituminous fiber or compound or in concrete in accordance with the specifications of the engineering department. 
(8)  No driveway entrance hereafter located, constructed or altered shall be located closer than 20 feet, measuring from the nearest end of the curb cut, to the intersection point of the extended curbline. 
(9)  No driveway entrance or curb cut shall hereafter be made, constructed, located or altered so as to be located outside the extended lot lines of the private property to which the driveway entrance affords access. 
(10)  There shall be a minimum distance at the curbline of 20 feet between commercial driveway entrances to be used for any one business or purpose. The 20 feet shall be measured from the two curb cut points. 
(11)  The cost of construction of all driveway entrances and necessary appurtenances thereto shall be borne by the permittee. 
(Code 1965, § 20-204; Code 1977, § 25-90; Ord. No. G-82-09, § 5, 6-9-1982; Ord. No. G-83-11, § 3, 6-22-1983) 
Sec. 36-137. - Permit application. 
    Any person desiring a permit required by this article shall make an application therefor to the engineering department. 
(Code 1965, § 20-204; Code 1977, § 25-86; Ord. No. G-82-09, § 3, 6-9-1982; Ord. No. G-83-11, § 2, 6-22-1983) 
Sec. 36-138. - Standard plans and specifications. 
    The engineering department is authorized and instructed to prepare standard plans and specifications for the construction of driveway entrances, sidewalk crossings and interior curbs which shall be furnished to any permittee upon application for a permit required by this article. 
(Code 1965, § 20-206; Code 1977, § 25-88) 
Sec. 36-139. - Variances. 
    The board of commissioners may grant, by resolution, variances from the strict application of the provisions of this article, upon determining that all of the following conditions are present: 
(1)  The exception or variance desired arises from peculiar physical conditions not ordinarily existing in similar districts in the city or is due to the nature of business and operations on the abutting property. 
(2)  The exception or variance desired is not against the public interest, safety, convenience and general welfare. 
(3)  The granting of the permit for the exception or variance will not adversely affect the right of adjacent property owners or tenants. 
(4)  The strict application of the provisions of section 36-136 will work unnecessary hardship on the property owner or tenant. 
(Code 1965, § 20-205; Code 1977, § 25-89; Ord. No. G-82-09, § 4, 6-9-1982) 
Sec. 36-140. - Construction, alteration or extension of entrance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, alter or extend or permit, or cause to be constructed, altered or extended, any driveway entrance which can be used only as parking space or area between the curb and adjacent property line, except in connection with a permit authorized by ordinance for the location and construction of parking areas by cutting and removal of curbs and widening the street upon the issuance of a permit therefor by the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1965, § 20-203; Code 1977, § 25-91) 
Sec. 36-141. - Paving and curbing by property owner or city. 
(a)  When any street is paved and curbed as provided by ordinance, any person owning land or lots abutting thereon and who may desire to construct a driveway from the curbline to his lot line may do so; provided, however, he shall pave and curb such driveway in the same or better manner and with the same kind or better material and with approved workmanship as that used in the paving and curbing of the street to which such driveway is connected. The driveway shall extend from the curbline to the lot line, and the paving and curbing thereof shall be done under the direction and approval of the engineering department and shall be done in such manner as not to change or interfere with the gutter or sidewalk grades where such driveway crosses any sidewalk. No bridge of any kind for the purpose of crossing the curb will be allowed to remain in or over the gutter. 
(b)  If a driveway connected to a paved street remains unpaved, the engineering department may, after giving 30 days' written notice to the owner or his agent, if known, of the necessity for paving such driveway, and without such notice if the lot or place of land is unoccupied, pave such driveway at any time. The engineering department shall keep an accurate account of the costs of paving in accordance with this subsection and shall report the same to the city clerk. The city clerk shall levy a special assessment against the lot or piece of land upon which such driveway is located to pay the costs of such paving, and the same may be collected as any other special assessment as provided by law. 
(Code 1965, §§ 20-208, 20-209; Code 1977, § 25-95) 
Sec. 36-142. - Restoration of curb, gutter and sidewalk. 
    In the event a driveway from a street to private property is used only for a parking space or such driveway ceases to be used for access to private property, or in the event that the construction of a building, the location thereof or the openings into such building renders it no longer necessary to have a driveway entrance for ingress or egress to such building, it shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of such property to eliminate such unused or unnecessary driveway entrance and to construct or restore the curb, gutter and sidewalk in accordance with the specifications on file in the office of the engineering department. 
(Code 1965, § 20-207; Code 1977, § 25-96) 
Secs. 36-143-36-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXCAVATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Wells and excavations generally, K.S.A. 19-2504 et seq. 

Sec. 36-170. - Permittee defined. 
    As used in this article, the term "permittee" shall mean any person to whom a permit required by section 36-173 has been issued. 
(Code 1977, § 25-134) 
Sec. 36-171. - Additional rules and regulations. 
    The city engineering department may prescribe such rules and regulations to be followed and performed by any person who shall excavate in public streets, sidewalks and public places as may be necessary for the safety and convenience of the public and the proper handling and dispatch of the work; provided, however no such rules or regulations shall be contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 20-311; Code 1977, § 25-135) 
Editor's note- All rules and regulations prescribed pursuant to this section are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 36-172. - All work subject to supervision and approval of engineering department. 
    All excavations, refills, resurfacing, replacements or protective measures covered by this article shall be subject to the supervision and approval of the engineering department. 
(Code 1965, §§ 20-309, 20-311; Code 1977, § 25-136) 
Sec. 36-173. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to excavate, dig, cut, open or break any hole, ditch, trench or tunnel through, in, over or under any street, park or parking, pavement, curb, sidewalk, crosswalk or public place in the city without first having obtained from the city clerk a contractor's license as provided in section 8-391, and from the engineering department a permit to make such excavation or cut; provided, however, public utilities may, in case of emergency, proceed to repair or restore broken mains, pipes or conduits beneath the surface of streets and sidewalks without first having procured the permit, but in case of such an emergency, such public utility shall, within 48 hours after the commencement of such emergency repairs, procure the permit required by this article. 
(Code 1965, § 20-302; Code 1977, § 25-137) 
Sec. 36-174. - Application for permit. 
(a)  To obtain a permit required by this article, the person desiring to do the work or his duly authorized agent shall sign and file an application therefor in writing with the city engineering department on a form furnished for that purpose. The application shall contain an agreement and promise on the part of the applicant to save and hold the city harmless because of any injury to person or property caused by the negligence of the applicant or permittee in operating under any of the provisions of this article. The application shall set forth: 
(1)  The location or place at which the work is to be performed; and 
(2)  The purpose for which the permit is intended. 
(b)  The application shall not be assignable or transferable, and no person shall allow his name to be used to obtain a permit for any other person. 
(Code 1965, § 20-303; Code 1977, § 25-138) 
Sec. 36-175. - Issuance of permit; contents and scope of permit; transferability. 
    If an application for a permit required by this article is approved by the engineering department, he shall issue the permit applied for. All permits shall be signed by the engineering department and shall specifically designate the place where and the purpose for which such excavation or cut is to be made. The permit shall cover only one specified piece of work and shall not be assignable or transferable. Such specified work shall be begun within six months from the date of issuance of the permit and, in default thereof, a new permit shall be required before the work shall be done. 
(Code 1965, § 20-304; Code 1977, § 25-140) 
Sec. 36-176. - Persons to whom permits may not be issued. 
    If any permittee persistently fails, refuses or neglects to comply with the provisions of this article or any reasonable orders or directions of the city engineering department in reference thereto, the engineering department may refuse to issue further permits to such person. 
(Code 1965, § 20-304; Code 1977, § 25-141) 
Sec. 36-177. - Duty of permittee or person performing work to refill, repair, clean up, etc. 
    It shall be the duty of every person who shall excavate, dig, cut, open or break any hole, ditch, trench or tunnel through, in, over or under any street, park or parking, pavement, curb, sidewalk, crosswalk or public place in the city, other than in such street, to make the refill and replace the sidewalk, curb or gutter at his own cost and expense subject to the supervision of the engineering department. The person making the refill of such excavation or cut shall be required to clean up and haul away all surplus earth, rock or rubbish within 24 hours after the refill has been completed and, in the event of default thereof, the engineering department shall have the right to order and cause the removal of the earth, rock or rubbish and charge the cost of such removal against the permittee or the person who commenced or performed the work. 
(Code 1965, § 20-308; Code 1977, § 25-142) 
Sec. 36-178. - Refilling and replacing of street surfaces following excavations. 
(a)  The refilling and replacing of surfaces following excavations in the streets shall be done, promptly upon completion of the work necessitating the excavation, by the permittee or person who made the excavation, using the same or better quality materials than those removed at the time of excavation, and at the same grade level as the adjacent street so as to make the refilled area smooth and level with the surrounding surface. If the permittee or person fails to refill and replace the street surface as required by this section, the city shall proceed to do so, and the cost thereof shall be assessed against the permittee or person who made the excavation. 
(b)  If any charge made under this section remains unpaid for 30 days, no further permit for any excavating shall be issued to such person until the delinquent charges have been paid. 
(c)  An exception to the materials requirement set forth in subsection (a) of this section may be made by the engineering department in cases where such materials are not readily available. In that event, the excavation may be temporarily filled in such manner and for such duration as the engineering department may authorize. Upon the expiration of such exception, the permittee or person who made the excavation shall refill and replace the surface as required under subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1965, §§ 20-306, 20-307; Code 1977, § 25-143) 
Sec. 36-179. - Manner and methods of work generally. 
    The person making an excavation or cut shall cause the same to be done with the least possible injury to the street, sidewalk or public place and shall place the removed paving material and excavated earth therefrom in such a manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the public and to permit uninterrupted passage of water along the gutters. The width of the cut or excavation shall be no greater than is necessary for doing the work. All curbing, paving, guttering and macadamizing shall be done by men who are experienced in such work and fully qualified to do the same in a proper and substantial manner. 
(Code 1965, § 20-309; Code 1977, § 25-144) 
Sec. 36-180. - Barricades and warning lights. 
    Every person who has undertaken the making of any excavation in, upon, under or adjoining any street, sidewalk or other public place, shall, where the work so undertaken renders the same impassable or dangerous to travel while such excavation is made or being made, place barricades and warning signs, advising the public that the excavated area is closed or is impassable or dangerous to travel. 
(Code 1965, § 20-310; Code 1977, § 25-145) 
State Law reference- Barricades and warning lights required, K.S.A. 68-2102. 
Sec. 36-181. - Unlawful to fail, neglect or refuse to make repairs, fill, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to obey the order or directions of the engineering department in filling any excavation, including the replacing of any pavement or sidewalk taken up or disturbed in making such excavation. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse, within 24 hours after receiving notice from the engineering department that the place where an excavation had been made is out of repair, to make such repairs. 
(Code 1965, § 20-311; Code 1977, § 25-146) 
Secs. 36-182-36-202. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NUMBERING STREETS AND BUILDINGS 

Sec. 36-203. - Dividing line established. 
    Walnut Street shall be the dividing line between all streets and alleys running north and south. First Street shall be the dividing line between all streets and alleys running east and west. 
(Code 1965, § 20-601; Code 1977, § 25-158) 
Sec. 36-204. - Manner of designating streets. 
    All the streets running east and west from Walnut Street shall be designated east or west; for example, East First Street, West First Street, East Second Street, West Second Street. All streets running north or south from First Street shall be designated north or south; for example, North Maple Street, South Maple Street, North Willow Street, South Willow Street. 
(Code 1965, § 20-602; Code 1977, § 25-159) 
Sec. 36-205. - Manner of numbering buildings. 
(a)  The number on all buildings on all streets running east and west shall originate from Walnut Street and shall be separately numbered from each other; for example, 101 East First Street, 101 West First Street. The number on all buildings on all streets running north and south shall originate from First Street and shall be separately numbered from each other; for example, 101 North Willow, 101 South Willow. 
(b)  The system of numbering shall be 100, each succeeding block commencing the succeeding hundred, the unit representing the number of the building in the block alternating the numbering of the buildings on both sides of the street. On streets extending west from Walnut Street, even numbers on north side of the street; on streets extending east from Walnut Street, even numbers on north side of the street. On streets extending north-south, even numbers on west side of the street and odd numbers on east side of the street. 
(Code 1965, §§ 20-603, 20-605; Code 1977, § 25-160) 
Sec. 36-206. - City engineering department to assign numbers to buildings. 
    The city engineering department shall assign numbers to all buildings in conformance with the requirements set forth herein. 
(Code 1965, § 20-604; Code 1977, § 25-161) 
Sec. 36-207. - City engineering department authorized to establish exceptions to numbering system. 
    The city engineering department is hereby authorized to establish such exceptions to the numbering system described in this article as may be made necessary by the regular routing of any street or avenue of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 20-606; Code 1977, § 25-162) 
Sec. 36-208. - Numbers to be affixed by owner or occupant of building; material, location of numbers. 
    All buildings facing streets, now or hereafter erected or relocated, shall be numbered, as herein provided, by the owner or occupant at his own expense. All such numbers or letters shall be of such kinds and materials as shall be approved by the city engineering department. All such numbers shall be placed on the front of the building, door or post so as to be easily seen from the street. Building or lot numbers may be located in the parking adjacent to the curbing, but only in addition to the number required to be placed on any building. 
(Code 1977, § 25-163) 
Chapter 38 - SUBDIVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Purpose, authority, jurisdiction and applicability. 
(a)  Purpose. 
(1)  Further promote and secure the health, safety and general welfare of the present and future citizens of the city. 
(2)  Provide for the location and width of streets, building lines, open spaces, for traffic, utilities, access for firefighting apparatus, recreation, light, and air, and to avoid congestion of population, including minimum width and area of lots. 
(3)  Provide the manner in which streets shall be graded and improved, and the extent to which water, sewers and other utility services shall be provided. 
(4)  Ensure logical community growth. 
(b)  Authority. The requirements and recommendations set forth herein are designed to encourage an orderly municipal growth for city through responsible land subdivision and are adopted under authority established by K.S.A. 12-749 and amendments thereto. 
(c)  Jurisdiction. These regulations shall apply to all subdivisions of land within the corporate limits of the city as presently exists or are hereafter established. These regulations may be extended to include any unincorporated territory lying outside of, but within three miles of, the nearest point of the city limits by an appropriate ordinance of the board of commissioners. 
(d)  Applicability. These regulations shall apply to the following forms of subdividing and redividing of land within the jurisdiction of the city planning and zoning commission: 
(1)  The subdivision of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, tracts or other division of land for the purpose of sale or of building development, whether immediate or future, including the resubdivision or replatting of land or lots. 
(2)  All plans, plats or replats of land laid out in building lots and the streets, alleys, or other portions of the same, intended to be dedicated for public use, or for the use of purchasers or owners of the lots fronting thereon or adjacent thereto, shall be submitted to the planning and zoning commission of the city for its approval, disapproval or modification of same, and if approved, such plans, plats or replats shall be given by the planning and zoning commission to the board of commissioners of the city for its approval, disapproval or modification of same. 
(3)  No plat of a subdivision of land shall be filed or recorded until it shall have been approved by the planning and zoning commission and the board of commissioners of the city. 
(4)  No subdivision within the city shall be effected, and no street, alley, sanitary sewer, water main, utility line or other facilities in connection therewith, shall be laid out, constructed, opened or dedicated for public use or travel or for the common use of occupants of buildings abutting thereon, except in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(5)  Vacation of streets or alleys. 
(e)  Exemptions. Division of land for agricultural purposes into tracts of three acres or more, and not involving any new streets, or easements of access, shall be exempt from the requirements of these regulations. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 1) 
Sec. 38-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a dedicated right-of-way for public use, giving secondary vehicular access to properties otherwise abutting a street. 
    Block means a series of lots entirely surrounded by public rights-of-way, railroad rights-of-way, parks, green strips and open land. 
    Common sewage disposal system means a sewage vault, septic tank and lateral field, sewage treatment plant, sewage lagoon or other sanitary means of disposing of waste materials, with the right of unrestricted use by two or more occupants of separate lots. 
    Common water supply means a well or other sanitary source of water for human consumption, with the right of unrestricted use by two or more occupants of separate lots. 
    Developer. See Subdivider . 
    Easement means a grant by the property owner to the public, a corporation, or persons of the use of a strip of land for specific uses. 
    Lot means a subdivision of a parcel of land intended for development or transfer of ownership, whether immediate or future. 
    Lot, corner, means a lot located at the intersection of land abutting on two or more streets. 
    Plat, final, means a map of land subdivision, prepared in a form suitable for filing of record, with necessary affidavits, dedications and acceptances, and with complete bearings and dimensions of all lines defining lots and blocks, streets, alleys, public areas and other dimensions of land. 
    Plat, preliminary, means a map of proposed land subdivision showing the character and proposed layout of the tract in sufficient detail to indicate the suitability of the proposed subdivision of land. 
    Street means any public right-of-way which affords the primary means of access to abutting property. 
    Street, arterial, means any major street or highway which is designated on the major street and/or highway plan. 
    Street, cul-de-sac, means a minor street having one end open to vehicular traffic and having one closed and terminated by a turn-around. 
    Street, limited access, means a minor street auxiliary to and located on the side of a major or arterial street for service to abutting properties and adjacent areas and for control of access. 
    Street, private, means any street not dedicated to the city or county as a public thoroughfare. 
    Subdivider means any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity, acting as a unit, subdividing or proposing to subdivide land as herein defined. 
    Subdivision means the division or redivision of land into two or more lots, tracts, sites or parcels for the purpose of transfer of ownership or development. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 9) 
Secs. 38-3-38-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROCEDURE 

Sec. 38-21. - Application procedure. 
(a)  Pre-application procedure. Previous to the filing of an application for conditional approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider is encouraged to avail himself to the advice and assistance of the city engineer. 
(b)  Application for subdivision approval. Any person desiring to subdivide land that is subject to the provisions of this chapter shall file with the secretary of the planning and zoning commission an application which states the name and address of the person making the application, identifies the location of land to be subdivided and describes the proposed subdivision in general terms, including the approximate number of proposed lots and typical lot widths and depths. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 2(a), (b)) 
Sec. 38-22. - Procedure for conditional approval of preliminary plat. 
    On reaching conclusions, informally as recommended above, regarding his general program and objectives, the subdivider shall cause to be prepared a preliminary plat, together with improvement plans and other supplementary material as specified in article III of this chapter. All preliminary plats and supplementary material specified shall be submitted at least 14 days prior to the next regular meeting of the planning and zoning commission, as follows: 
(1)  Twelve copies shall be submitted to the planning and zoning commission. 
(2)  Two copies shall be provided each company providing water, electric or gas service. 
(3)  Two copies shall be submitted to the city engineer. 
(4)  Two copies shall be provided each official, body, company or agency as may be directed by the planning and zoning commission. 
(5)  Following the review of the preliminary plat and other material submitted for conformity thereof to these regulations, the planning and zoning commission shall, within 60 days, act upon the submitted preliminary plan, and, if approved, the planning and zoning commission shall express its approval as conditional approval and state the conditions of such approval, if any, or, if disapproved, the subdivider shall be notified of the reason for such action and what requirements shall be necessary to meet the approval of the planning and zoning commission. The action of the planning and zoning commission shall be noted on three copies of the preliminary plan, referenced and attached to any conditions determined. One copy shall be returned to the subdivider and the other two retained by the planning and zoning commission. 
(6)  Conditional approval of a preliminary plat shall not constitute approval of the final plan, but rather it shall be deemed an expression of approval to the layout submitted on the preliminary plan as a guide to the preparation of the final plan, which will be submitted for approval of the planning and zoning commission and the board of commissioners, and for the recording upon fulfillment of the requirements of this chapter and the conditions of the conditional approval, if any. 
(7)  Prior to the approval of the preliminary plat, the planning and zoning commission may require due consideration by the subdivider, the dedication or reservation of suitable sites for schools, parks, playgrounds or other public recreational areas or open spaces. Any areas so dedicated or reserved shall conform as nearly as possible to the recommendations of the city planning and zoning commission in its master plan of the city. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 2(c)) 
Sec. 38-23. - Procedure for approval of final plat. 
    The final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat, as approved, and, if desired by the subdivider, it may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which he proposes to record and develop at the time, provided that such portion conforms with all the requirements of this chapter. Such final plat shall be prepared by a registered engineer or surveyor. 
(1)  One original final plat, and one reproducible final plat, which shall be clearly and legibly drafted in India ink upon Mylar, of good quality, and 18 prints thereof, shall be submitted to the planning and zoning commission at least 14 days prior to the meeting at which it is to be considered. 
(2)  The submission of the first section of the final plat shall be within a period of not more than six months from the time of approval of the preliminary plat. If not so submitted, the approval shall automatically expire, unless an extension of time is applied for, and for good cause, is granted by the planning and zoning commission. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 2(d)) 
Sec. 38-24. - Preliminary plat requirements. 
(a)  Preliminary plat. The scale of the preliminary plat shall not be smaller than 100 feet to one inch, on a sheet size of 24 inches by 36 inches. 
(b)  Information required. The following information shall be submitted: 
(1)  Name of proposed subdivision. 
(2)  Name and address of property owner, subdivider and engineer or surveyor, platting the tract and laying out the boundaries. 
(3)  Date, scale (written and graphic) and north point. 
(4)  An identification clearly stating that the plat is a preliminary plat. 
(5)  Boundary lines with bearing and distances and names of adjacent subdivisions. 
(6)  Name, location, purpose and dimensions of all proposed streets, alleys, sidewalks, easements, reserves, rights-of-way existing or proposed on or adjacent to the tract, whether public or private, and the conditions of such dedications, if any. 
(7)  Ground elevation with contours at vertical intervals not exceeding five feet in areas of 15 percent grade or more, and two feet in all other areas of lesser grade. Elevation marked on such contours shall be based on data approved by the city engineer. 
(8)  Location of existing bodies of water, waterway courses and physical structures, and areas subject to flooding. 
(9)  Preliminary plan of storm and sanitary sewer improvements and utilities. 
(10)  Any proposed restrictions or covenants. 
(11)  Proposed lot layout, building setback lines and their approximate dimensions. 
(12)  The preliminary plat shall include all land contemplated for the entire eventual subdivision. 
(13)  A key map showing the location of the proposed subdivision. 
(14)  Existing uses of the property including the location of all existing structures that will remain on the property after the final plat is recorded.
