(15)  The horizontal elevation to the nearest foot within the subdivision and of the adjoining streets and property of existing sanitary and storm water sewers, including flow lines, water mains, culverts, drain pipes, underground wiring and gas lines proposed to serve the property to be subdivided. 
(16)  Zoning on and adjacent to the tract, if any. 
(17)  Location, elevation and description of the bench mark controlling the vertical survey. 
(c)  Commission approval. Within 60 days, the planning and zoning commission shall take such action as outlined in section 38-23 or the preliminary plat shall be deemed approved. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 3) 
Sec. 38-25. - Final plat requirements. 
    The final plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn at a scale of one inch equals 100 feet on a 24 inch by 36 inch Mylar, in India ink. All information required with submission of the preliminary plat, plus the following information, shall be included on the final plat: 
(1)  The lines and names of all proposed streets, or other ways, or easements, and other open spaces intended to be dedicated for public use or granted for use of inhabitants of the subdivision; also lines of all adjoining streets. 
(2)  The length of all straight lines, deflection angles, and radii, arcs and central angles of all curves along the center line and the property lines of each street. All dimensions along the lines of each lot with the true bearings and angles of intersection which they make with each other, and also any other data necessary for the location of any lot line in the field; also, the location of all building setback lines on all lots and other sites. If more convenient, calculated bearings may be used instead of angles. 
(3)  Suitable primary control points, approved by the city engineer, or descriptions and "ties" to such control points to which all dimensions, angles, bearings, and similar data given on the plat shall be referred. All dimensions shall be shown in feet and decimals of a foot. 
(4)  Location and elevation of a permanent bench mark. 
(5)  The location of all permanent monuments with the distance between them and sufficient curve data plainly marked. These monuments shall be located at all block corners. 
(6)  Date of preparation, title, north point and scale shall be included. The title shall include the name of the subdivision under which it is to be recorded; the north point may indicate either the magnetic or true north and shall be so designated on the plat. 
(7)  The boundary of the subdivided tract, with courses and distances marked thereon which shall be determined by survey in the field, which shall be balanced and closed, by a qualified engineer or surveyor. 
(8)  An identification system for all lots and blocks. 
(9)  The certification of the engineer or surveyor making the plat, his seal and signature. 
(10)  The acknowledgment of a notary. 
(11)  A certificate of the planning and zoning commission showing its approval to the plat. 
(12)  The approval of the board of commissioners. 
(13)  The certificate of the registrar of deeds. 
(14)  A certificate of title, prepared by a competent attorney, showing the proposed subdivider owns all the property within the plat in fee, and that it is free from encumbrances and liens, but if encumbered, the mortgagee shall be required to consent to the plat. 
(15)  Statement by the owner dedicating streets, rights-of-way and any sites for public use. 
(16)  Such other certificates, affidavits, endorsements or deductions as may be required by the planning and zoning commission in the enforcement of this chapter. 
(17)  Purpose for which sites, other than residential lots, are dedicated or reserved. 
(18)  Marginal lines encircling the sheet. All lettering, signatures and seals shall be within this margin. 
(19)  Legal description of the subdivision. 
(20)  In addition to the final plat, cross sections and profiles of streets and drainage, showing grades approved by the city engineer, shall be submitted to supplement the plat. The profiles shall be drawn to city standard scales, and elevations shall be based on a datum plane approved by the city engineer. 
(21)  Upon acceptance of the final plat, the subdivider shall pay a fee of $1.00 per lot, or $75.00, whichever is lesser, but in no case shall the fee be less than $25.00. This fee shall be placed in the general fund of the city and shall be used to defray the expenses of the planning and zoning commission. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 4) 
Secs. 38-26-38-44. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 38-45. - General standards. 
    The following shall be considered as minimum requirements and will ordinarily be varied by the planning and zoning commission only under the conditions and circumstances set forth in this chapter: 
(1)  Land shall be suited to the purpose for which it is to be subdivided, and its proposed use shall be in accordance with the requirements of any zoning ordinance. Land subject to hazards to life, health or property shall not be subdivided for residential purposes until all such hazards have been eliminated or unless adequate safeguards against such hazards are provided by the subdivision plan. 
(2)  Proposed subdivisions shall be coordinated with existing nearby neighborhoods so that the community as a whole may develop harmoniously. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 5(a)) 
Sec. 38-46. - Streets. 
    The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public convenience and safety, and in their appropriate relation to proposed uses of the land served by such streets. The arrangement and design standards of streets shall conform to the provisions found herein: 
(1)  The arrangement of streets in a subdivision shall either provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing principal streets in surrounding areas, or conform to a plan for the neighborhood, approved or adopted by the planning and zoning commission, to meet a particular situation where topographical or other conditions make continuation or conformance to existing streets impracticable. 
(2)  When a new subdivision adjoins unsubdivided land susceptible of being subdivided, then the new streets shall be carried to the boundaries of the tract proposed to be subdivided. 
(3)  Streets that are obviously in alignment with others already existing and named shall bear the name of the existing streets. No street name shall be used which will duplicate or be confused with the name of any existing street in the city. Street names shall be subject to the approval of the planning and zoning commission. 
(4)  Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will be discouraged. 
(5)  Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right-of-way, the planning and zoning commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land, as for park purposes in residential districts, or for commercial or industrial purposes in appropriate districts. Such distances shall also be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations. 
(6)  All streets shall be platted in such a manner that all resulting lots may conform to the applicable zoning regulations. 
(7)  Streets should be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles, and no street should intersect any other street at an angle of 15 degrees more or less from 90 degrees. 
(8)  There shall be no reserve strips controlling access to streets, except where the control of such strips is definitely placed in the city under conditions approved by the planning and zoning commission. The subdividing of the land shall be such as to provide each lot, by means of either a public street or way, or permanent easement, with satisfactory access to an existing public highway or to a thoroughfare as shown on an official map. 
(9)  Street jogs with center line offsets of less than 150 feet shall be avoided. 
(10)  When connecting street lines deflect from each other, they shall be connected by a curve with a radius adequate to insure a sight distance of not less than 200 feet for minor and collector streets and of such greater radii as the planning and zoning commission shall determine for special cases. 
(11)  A tangent shall be provided between all reverse curves of a sufficient length as related to the radius so as to provide for a smooth flow of traffic. 
(12)  Clear visibility, measured along the center line of a street, shall be provided for at least 200 feet on all streets. 
(13)  Vertical curves are required for changes in grade. 
(14)  No street grade shall be greater than seven percent or less than five-tenths of one percent. 
(15)  Street rights-of-way and paved widths shall not be less than as follows: 
Street Type R.O.W. Paved Width Arterial 80 feet 53 feet B/B-No parking Collector 80 feet 40 feet B/B Minor 60 feet 31 feet B/B Cul-de-sac 60 feet 31 feet B/B  
In front of areas designated and zoned, or where a petition for a change in zoning is contemplated for commercial use, to permit such use, the street width shall be increased by such an amount on each side as may be deemed necessary by the planning and zoning commission to assure the free flow of through traffic without interference by parked or parking vehicles and to provide safe parking space for such commercial or business district. 
(16)  Half streets shall be prohibited, except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of these regulations, and where the planning and zoning commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever a half-street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other half of the street shall be platted within such tract. 
(17)  Dead-end streets (cul-de-sacs), designed to be so permanently, shall not be longer than 500 feet and shall be provided at the closed end with a turnaround having an outside roadway diameter of at least 100 feet. 
(18)  Except where land use shall justify same or in other unusual cases, no dead-end streets, other than cul-de-sac treatment, shall be approved unless such dead-end streets are provided to connect with future streets in adjacent land. 
(19)  There shall be no private streets platted in any subdivision. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 5(b)) 
Sec. 38-47. - Alleys. 
(a)  Alleys shall be provided in commercial and industrial districts, except that the planning and zoning commission may waive this requirement where other definite and assured provision is made for service access, such as off-street loading, unloading and parking, consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed. 
(b)  The minimum width of an alley shall be 20 feet. 
(c)  All alleys shall be graded to slope to the center line. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 5(c)) 
Sec. 38-48. - Easements. 
(a)  Easements with a right-of-way width of five feet shall be provided on each side of all rear lot lines, where alleys are not provided, and along certain side lot lines where necessary for utilities and drainage. 
(b)  Easements of greater widths may be required along or across lots where necessary for the extension of main storm and sanitary sewers and other utilities. 
(c)  Whenever any stream or important surface drainage course is located in an area that is being subdivided, the subdivider shall dedicate an adequate easement, as specified by the city engineer, along each side of the stream for the purpose of future widening, deepening, sloping, improving or protecting the stream, or for drainage, parkway or recreational use. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 5(d)) 
Sec. 38-49. - Blocks. 
(a)  Block length and width or acreage within bounding roads shall be such as to accommodate the size of lot required in the area by the zoning ordinance and to provide for convenient access, circulation control and safety of street traffic. 
(b)  Block dimensions may be subject to adjustment by the planning and zoning commission where topography, character of the proposed use or similar conditions justify lesser length or widths. 
(c)  Pedestrian crosswalks, not less than ten feet wide, shall be required where deemed essential to the planning and zoning commission to provide circulation or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation and other facilities. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 5(e)) 
Sec. 38-50. - Lots. 
(a)  All lots shall have a full frontage on a street. 
(b)  Lot dimensions and areas shall conform to the requirement of the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(c)  All side lot lines shall be at right angles to straight street lines and radial to curved street lines where practicable. 
(d)  Building or setback lines shall be shown on the preliminary plat and final plat for all lots in the subdivision and shall not be less than the building or setback lines required by the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(e)  Corner lots shall have such extra width as will permit the establishment of building lines on both streets. 
(f)  House numbers shall be assigned to each lot by the city engineer. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 5(f)) 
Sec. 38-51. - Acre subdivisions. 
    When the proposed subdivision involves lots of one acre or more in area, consideration should be given to any resubdividing that might take place with proper provisions being made for such street extension as may be necessary. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 5(g)) 
Sec. 38-52. - Public sites and open spaces. 
(a)  Where deemed essential by the planning and zoning commission, upon consideration of the particular type of development proposed in the subdivision, and especially in large scale neighborhood unit development, the planning and zoning commission may require the dedication or reservation of such other areas or sites of a character, extent and location suitable to the needs created by such development for schools, parks and other neighborhood purposes. 
(b)  The requiring of the dedication of public spaces, as provided in this requirement, shall not constitute an acceptance of the dedication by the city. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 5(h)) 
Sec. 38-53. - Neighborhood unit development. 
    Whenever a subdivision is developed as a neighborhood unit, wherein adequate park or recreational area is provided, through traffic is adequately cared for and the majority of streets are of the cul-de-sac type, the planning and zoning commission may vary the requirements of this chapter in order to allow the subdivider more freedom in the arrangement of streets and lots, but at the same time, protect the convenience, health, safety and welfare of the probable future residents of the subdivision, as well as the character of the surrounding property and the general welfare of the entire community. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 5(i)) 
Secs. 38-54-38-74. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 38-75. - General requirements. 
    The improvements listed in this article shall be installed prior to the issuance of any building permits for the subdivided area, except as hereinafter provided. In lieu of actual completion of such improvements, the subdivider may file with the board of commissioners a surety bond to secure to the board of commissioners the actual construction of such improvements in a manner satisfactory to the board of commissioners and within a period specified by the board of commissioners, but such period shall not exceed two years. Such bond shall be in the amount and with surety and conditions satisfactory to the board of commissioners and shall be accompanied by signed statements from the city engineer that the amount of the bond is adequate to cover the cost of the improvements; provided, however, that in lieu of actual completion of such improvements or the posting of a bond as provided for, the planning and zoning commission may require the subdivider to file with the board of commissioners a letter stating his intentions to complete the improvements as required herein as development takes place on his building sites. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 6(a); Ord. No. G-76-06, 6-23-1976) 
Sec. 38-76. - Vacation of plots. 
    Whenever no lots have been sold, the subdivider may request the vacation of the plat prior to the time that the improvements covered by the bond are installed, and when the plat is vacated, the bond shall be returned to the subdivider. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 6(b); Ord. No. G-76-06, 6-23-1976) 
Sec. 38-77. - Final plat approval. 
    The owner of the tract shall prepare and secure tentative approval of a final subdivision plat of the entire area and may install the above improvements only in a portion of such area, but the improvements must be installed in any portion of the area for which a final plat is approved for recording, or a bond actually posted, and the owner may sell or lease or offer for sale or lease lots only in the approved portion of said property; provided, however, that trunk sewers and sewage treatment plants shall be designed and built to serve the entire area, or designed and built in such a manner that they can be easily expanded or extended, as the case may be, to serve the entire area. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 6(c); Ord. No. G-76-06, 6-23-1976) 
Sec. 38-78. - Plans required. 
    The subdivider shall furnish the city engineer with plans and profiles of all streets, sanitary sewers and storm drainage in detail. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 6(d); Ord. No. G-76-06, 6-23-1976) 
Sec. 38-79. - Monuments. 
    Monuments shall be placed at all block corners, angle points of curves in streets, and at intermediate points, as shall be required by the city engineer. The monuments shall be of such material, size and length as may be approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 6(e); Ord. No. G-76-06, 6-23-1976) 
Sec. 38-80. - Streets. 
(a)  All streets shall be surfaced in accordance with applicable specifications set up by the city engineering department. Such construction shall be subject to inspection and approval by the city engineer. 
(b)  Curbs, gutters, drainage and drainage structures shall be provided in accordance with standard specifications prepared by the city engineer department. Such construction shall be subject to the inspection and approval of the city engineer. 
(c)  Concrete sidewalks shall be constructed along at least one side of every minor street shown on the plat in accordance with applicable standard specifications of the city engineering department, and concrete sidewalks shall be constructed along both sides of all arterial and collector streets. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 6(f); Ord. No. G-76-06, 6-23-1976) 
Sec. 38-81. - Sanitary sewer system. 
(a)  Where the sanitary sewer system of the city is reasonably accessible and within the city limits of the city, each lot within the subdivided area shall be provided with a connection thereto. All connections shall be subject to the approval of the city engineer, and any subdivided area not within the city limits shall not connect its sewers with the sanitary sewer system of the city unless granted approval by the board of commissioners. 
(b)  In subdivisions beyond the city limits in which the lots are less than one acre in area, and where plans for the installation of sanitary sewers in the vicinity of a subdivision have been prepared by the city engineer, the subdivider may be required to install sanitary sewers in conformity with such plans. In such cases, until a connection can be made with the public sanitary sewer system, the use of a sewage treatment plant will be permitted, provided such disposal facilities are approved by the city engineer. Where the installation of sanitary sewers is not required, and where the lots are more than one acre in area, the subdivider may install individual disposal devices for each lot at the time improvements are erected thereon. All such individual sewage disposal systems shall be subject to the approval of the city engineer. 
(c)  All new or replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of surface or flood waters into the drainage systems and discharges from the systems into flood waters. All on-site waste disposal systems shall be located to avoid impairment of them, or contamination from them, during flooding. 
(d)  All sanitary sewer plans and profiles shall be subject to the approval of the state board of health. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 6(g); Ord. No. G-76-06, 6-23-1976) 
Sec. 38-82. - Water supply. 
(a)  Where an approved public water supply is reasonably accessible or procurable, the subdivider shall contract with the city to make the water supply available for each lot within the subdivided area. 
(b)  In a proposed subdivision, pending accessibility of a public water supply, the subdivider may be required to construct wells or a private water supply system in such a manner that an adequate supply of potable water will be available to every lot in the subdivision at the time improvements are erected thereon. The adequacy, healthfulness and potability of the water supply shall be subject to the approval of the state board of health. The construction of the water supply system shall be subject to the approval of the city engineer. 
(c)  All new or replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of surface or floodwaters into the drainage systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters. 
(d)  The subdivider shall also contract with the city for the installation, maintenance and operation of fire hydrants in accordance with the city requirements. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 6(h); Ord. No. G-76-06, 6-23-1976) 
Sec. 38-83. - Public utilities and facilities. 
    All public utilities and facilities; i.e., electrical, gas, sewer and water systems, shall be located, elevated and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 6(i); Ord. No. G-76-06, 6-23-1976) 
Sec. 38-84. - Inspection. 
    All construction and installation shall be inspected by the city engineering department. The owner of the subdivision shall pay for inspection personnel furnished by the city, under the supervision of the city engineer, on all improvements constructed by such owner of such subdivision, as contractor or subcontractors. A schedule of fees shall be prepared by the city engineer. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 6(j); Ord. No. G-76-06, 6-23-1976) 
Sec. 38-85. - Building and other permits. 
    No building permit shall be issued for a building or structure on any lot of any subdivision that is subject to the provisions of any ordinance of the city until a certified copy of the duly recorded or registered plat of subdivision has been filed with the city engineer. No such permit shall be issued until there has been compliance with all of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 6(k); Ord. No. G-76-06, 6-23-1976) 
Secs. 38-86-38-106. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VARIATIONS AND EXCEPTIONS 

Sec. 38-107. - Variances. 
    When the subdivider can show that a provision of these standards would cause unnecessary hardship if strictly adhered to, and where, because of topographical or other conditions peculiar to the site, in the opinion of the planning and zoning commission, a departure may be made without destroying the intent of such provisions, the planning and zoning commission may authorize a variance. Any variance thus authorized is to be stated in writing in the minutes of the planning and zoning commission with the reasoning on which the departure was justified set forth. These variances shall never be authorized as a blanket variance for the entire subdivision. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 7(a)) 
Sec. 38-108. - Application. 
    Application for a variance shall be submitted in writing by the subdivider at the time when the preliminary plat is filed for the consideration of the planning and zoning commission. The petition shall state fully the grounds for the application and all the facts relied upon by the petitioner. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 7(b)) 
Sec. 38-109. - Conditions. 
    In granting variances and modifications, the planning and zoning commission may require such conditions as will, in its judgment, secure substantially the objectives of the standards or requirements so varied or modified. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 7(c)) 
Sec. 38-110. - Stage construction. 
    The developer may, after receiving approval of the preliminary plat, petition the planning and zoning commission to proceed with the subdivision by stages. The area may be subdivided into sections, and after the approval of the city planning and zoning commission, the installation of improvements as required in article IV of this chapter may be constructed. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 7(d)) 
Sec. 38-111. - City not obligated to expend funds. 
    The city, shall not be obligated for the expenditure of any funds whatsoever under and pursuant to the terms of these subdivision regulations, unless and until the board of commissioners shall have adopted such expenditure by a majority vote. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 7(e)) 
Secs. 38-112-38-132. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ADMINISTRATION AND AMENDMENT 

Sec. 38-133. - Notice of action taken. 
    The city planning and zoning commission shall determine its recommendation as to whether the subdivision plat shall be approved, with modification, or disapproved, and shall give written notice to the subdivider of its determination. If approved, the planning and zoning commission shall so note on the face of the plat and shall thereupon forward said plat to the board of commissioners notifying the subdivider of the action. If approved with modifications, or disapproved, the planning and zoning commission shall attach to the original plat a statement of the reasons for such action and shall return the original of said plat to the subdivider, together with one copy and retaining two copies for its records. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 8(a)) 
Sec. 38-134. - Official recording. 
(a)  No plat or description of subdivision shall be filed in the office of the Montgomery County Registrar of Deeds, Independence, Kansas, until same shall have been given final approval by the city board of commissioners as required by law. 
(b)  All final plats shall be filed within two years of the date of approval by the planning and zoning commission, and no lots shall be sold from any plat until same has been recorded as herein provided. Failure to record such approved plat within two years of the planning and zoning commission approval shall void all approvals thereto. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 8(b)) 
Sec. 38-135. - Agenda. 
    Each plat submitted for preliminary or final approval shall be placed on the planning and zoning commission's agenda only after fulfilling the appropriate requirements of these regulations. However, a plat not meeting all the requirements may be submitted, providing the subdivider presents with the plat a letter requesting the specific exception and enumerating in detail the reason therefor. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 8(c)) 
Sec. 38-136. - Amendment. 
    The city planning and zoning commission may, from time to time, amend and make public rules and regulations for the administration of these model subdivision regulations to the end that the public be informed and that approval of plats of subdivisions be expedited. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 8(d)) 
Sec. 38-137. - Violation and penalty. 
(a)  Every person, firm or corporation who shall neglect or refuse to comply with or who shall violate, or attempt to violate, any of the provisions of this chapter, or any amendments or additions hereto, whether as owner, agent, officer, employee, tenant, occupant, lessee, contractor or any other person who shall permit, take part in or assist in such violation or attempted violation, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, constituting a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which such violation is committed, continued, permitted or attempted, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 for each offense. 
(b)  The imposition of the penalties prescribed shall not preclude the city or any other interested person from instituting injunction, mandamus or other appropriate action or proceeding authorized by law to prevent, correct or abate such violation or to prevent the unlawful occupancy or use of the building or premises. 
(Code 1977, app. C, § 8(e)) 
Chapter 40 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 40-1. - Incorporation by reference of standard traffic ordinance. 
    There is hereby incorporated by reference, as provided by law, for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations governing traffic within the city, the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities, 2017 Edition, recommended by the League of Kansas Municipalities, Topeka, Kansas. The provisions of said standard traffic ordinance shall be controlling with respect to all subjects and matters therein contained with the city, and further supplemented by this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 21-101; Code 1977, § 15-1; Ord. No. G-120, §§ 1, 2, 8-25-1971; Ord. No. G-74-13, §§ 1, 2, 9-25-1974; Ord. No. G-76-07, § 1, 10-27-1976; Ord. No. G-81-09, § 1, 5-27-1981; Ord. No. G-82-15, § 1, 7-28-1982; Ord. No. G-82-26, § 1, 11-10-1982; Ord. No. G-85-03, § 1, 4-22-1985; Ord. No. G-86-06, § 4, 10-13-1986; Ord. No. G-88-06, § 4, 8-22-1988; Ord. No. G-92-12, § 1(15-1), 9-28-1992; Ord. No. G-93-15, § 1(15-1), 9-13-1993; Ord. No. G-95-04, § 1(15-1), 11-14-1995; Ord. No. G-96-07, § 1(15-1), 11-26-1996; Ord. No. G-05-04, § 1(15-1), 8-9-2005; Ord. No. G-09-05, § 1, 9-8-2009; Ord. No. G-11-02, § 1, 9-27-2011; Ord. No. G-12-04, § 1, 8-28-2012; Ord. No. G-13-05, § 4, 8-27-2013; Ord. No. G-15-04, § 1, 10-13-2015; Ord. No. G-17-02 , § 1, 7-11-2017) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt regulations by reference, K.S.A. 12-3009 et seq., 12-3302. 
Sec. 40-2. - Incorporating standard traffic ordinance. 
    For the purpose of regulating traffic within the corporate limits of the city, the board of commissioners has adopted by reference the "Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities," 2017 edition, published by the League of Kansas Municipalities, Topeka, Kansas. Not less than one copy of the standard traffic ordinance shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy as Adopted by Ordinance No. G-17-02," to which shall be attached a copy of this chapter, and filed with the city clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. The police department, municipal judge and all administrative departments of the city charged with enforcement of the ordinance shall be supplied, at the cost of the city, such number of official copies of the standard traffic ordinance similarly marked, as may be deemed expedient. 
(Ord. No. G-15-04, § 1, 10-13-2015; Ord. No. G-17-02 , § 2, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 40-3. - Traffic infractions and traffic offenses. 
(a)  An ordinance traffic infraction is a violation of any section of this article that prescribes or requires the same behavior as that prescribed or required by a statutory provision that is classified as a traffic infraction in K.S.A. 8-2118, as amended. 
(b)  All traffic violations which are included within this article, and which are not ordinance traffic infractions, as defined in subsection (a) of this section, shall be considered traffic offenses. 
(Ord. No. G-15-04, § 2, 10-13-2015) 
Sec. 40-4. - Penalty for scheduled fines. 
    The fine for violation of an ordinance traffic infraction, or any other traffic offense for which the municipal judge establishes a fine in a fine schedule, shall not be less than $10.00 nor more than $1,500.00. A person tried and convicted for violation of an ordinance traffic infraction, or other traffic offense for which a fine has been established in a schedule of fines, shall pay a fine fixed by the court not to exceed $1,500.00. 
(Ord. No. G-15-04, § 3, 10-13-2015) 
Sec. 40-5. - Incorporation of federal motor carrier safety regulations. 
(a)  There is hereby incorporated by reference, for the purpose of regulating traffic upon highways and streets of the city, those certain standard safety regulations known as Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations, parts 382, 383, 385, 387 and 390-399, prepared and published in book form by Mangan Communications, Inc., 315 West Fourth Street, Davenport, Iowa, 52801, 2013 edition (hereinafter the "FMCS Regulations"), save and except such articles, sections, parts, or portions as are hereafter omitted, deleted, modified, or changed. No fewer than one copy of the FMCS regulations shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy as Adopted by Ordinance No. G-13-07," and to which shall be attached a copy of this chapter, and filed with the city clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. The police department, municipal judge and all administrative departments of the city charged with enforcement of the ordinance shall be supplied, at the cost of the city, such number of official copies of the FMCS Regulations similarly marked, as may be deemed expedient. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of the FMCS regulations. The judge of the municipal court may, in the manner prescribed by K.S.A. 12-4305 or any amendments thereto, establish a schedule of fines for violations of any section of the FMCS regulations. Any person who violates the provisions of the FMCS regulations shall, upon conviction, be punished as set forth in the fine schedule. Any person who violates any provision of the FMCS regulations for which a fine is not scheduled shall, upon conviction, be punished as follows: 
(c)  A fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $2,500.00; 
(d)  Imprisonment for not more than one year; or 
(e)  Both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. G-13-08, §§ 1, 2, 9-10-2013) 
Sec. 40-6. - Rules for erection and placement of traffic control devices. 
    The board of commissioners shall have the authority to make such rules and regulations relative to traffic as are authorized by state law and to erect or place, or cause to be erected or placed, official traffic-control devices necessary for the enforcement thereof. 
(Code 1977, § 15-3) 
Sec. 40-7. - When person to be taken before municipal judge; when arrest authorized; traffic citation only in certain cases. 
(a)  When a person is stopped by a police officer for any violation of any provision of the uniform act regulating traffic on highways not amounting to a felony, the person shall be taken into custody and taken without unnecessary delay before the municipal court judge, as specified in K.S.A. 8-2106(d), and amendments thereto, if: 
(1)  Such person demands an immediate appearance before a judge; or 
(2)  Such person is to be charged with a violation of K.S.A. 8-1567 and 8-1568, and amendments thereto. 
(b)  When any person is stopped by a police officer for any violation of any provision of the uniform act regulating traffic on highways, which violation is a misdemeanor, and is not required to be taken before the municipal court judge as provided in subsection (a) of this section, the person, in the discretion of the police officer, may be taken into custody and taken without unnecessary delay before the municipal court judge, as specified in K.S.A. 8-2106(d), and amendments thereto. 
(c)  When any person is stopped by a police officer for any violation of any provision of the uniform act regulating traffic on highways, which violation is a traffic infraction, and is not required to be taken before the municipal court judge as provided in subsection (a) of this section, the person shall not be taken before the municipal court judge. 
(d)  When any person is stopped by a police officer and is to be charged with violation of any statute defining a traffic violation which is a felony, the person shall be taken without unnecessary delay before the judge of the district court as specified in K.S.A. 8-2106(d), and amendments thereto. 
(Code 1965, § 21-403; Code 1977, § 15-4; Ord. No. 5370, § 1, 3-24-1967; Ord. No. G-85-05, § 2, 6-24-1985) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 8-2104. 
Sec. 40-8. - Traffic citation; notice to appear; traffic infraction procedure; officer's choice on misdemeanors. 
(a)  A police officer may prepare and deliver to a person a written traffic citation on a form approved by the city, if the police officer stops the person for a violation of: 
(1)  The uniform act regulating traffic on highways, which violation is a misdemeanor or a traffic infraction; 
(2)  K.S.A. 8-262, 8-287, 8-2,144, 8-1599, 40-3104, 40-3106, 41-715, 41-724, 41-727, 47-607, 66-1,111, 66-1,129, 66-1,139, 66-1,140, 66-273, 66-1314, 66-1324, 66-1330, 66-1331, 66-1332, 68-2104, 68-2106 or 79-34,122(b), or 21-5607(a), 21-5810, 21-5815, 21-5816, 21-5817(a) or 21-6203, and amendments thereto; 
(3)  K.S.A. 31-155, and amendments thereto, involving transportation of bottle rockets; 
(4)  K.S.A. 66-1314 or 66-1328, and amendments thereto, and any rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto; 
(5)  Any rules and regulations adopted pursuant to K.S.A. 2-1212, 68-2001 or 31-146, and amendments thereto; 
(6)  Any rules and regulations adopted pursuant to K.S.A. 31-133, and amendments thereto, relating to transportation of materials or fuel; 
(7)  K.S.A. 8-1343 through 8-1347, and amendments thereto, relating to the Child Passenger Safety Act; or 
(8)  K.S.A. 8-2501 through 8-2507, and amendments thereto, relating to the Safety Belt Use Act. 
(b)  The citation shall contain a notice to appear in court, the name and address of the person, the type of vehicle the person was driving, whether hazardous materials were being transported, whether an accident occurred, the state registration number of the person's vehicle, if any, a statement whether the vehicle is a commercial vehicle, whether the person is licensed to drive a commercial motor vehicle, the offense charged, the time and place when and where the person shall appear in court, the signature of the police officer, and any other pertinent information. 
(c)  The time specified in the notice to appear shall be at least five days after the alleged violation unless the person charged with the violation demands an earlier hearing. 
(d)  The place specified in the notice to appear shall be before the municipal court judge within the county in which the offense is alleged to have been committed. 
(e)  Except in the circumstances to which K.S.A. 8-2104(a), and amendments thereto, apply, in the discretion of the police officer, a person charged with a misdemeanor may give written promise to appear in court by signing at least one copy of the written citation prepared by the police officer, in which event the police officer shall deliver a copy of the citation to the person and shall not take the person into physical custody. 
(f)  When a person is charged with a traffic infraction, the notice to appear shall provide a place where the person may make a written entry of appearance, waive the right to a trial and plead guilty or no contest. Such notice to appear shall contain a provision that the person's failure to either pay such fine and court costs or appear at the specified time may result in suspension of the person's drivers' license as provided in K.S.A. 8-2110, and amendments thereto. The notice to appear shall provide a space where the police officer shall enter the appropriate fine specified in the uniform fine schedule contained in K.S.A. 8-2118, and amendments thereto, for the violation charged and court costs in the amount provided by law. If the notice to appear does not do so, the police officer shall provide a person charged with a traffic infraction a form explaining the person's right to appear and right to a trial and the person's right to pay the appropriate fine and court costs prior to the appearance date. The police officer shall provide the person with the address of the court to which the written entry of appearance, waiver of trial, plea of guilty or no contest and payment of fine and court costs shall be mailed. 
(g)  Any officer violating any of the provisions of subsection (f) of this section is guilty of misconduct in office and shall be subject to removal from office. 
(Code 1977, § 15-5; Ord. No. G-85-05, § 3, 6-24-1985) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 8-2106 et seq. 
Sec. 40-9. - Traffic infractions and traffic offenses. 
(a)  An ordinance traffic infraction is a violation of any section of this chapter that prescribes or requires the same behavior as that prescribed or required by a statutory provision that is classified as traffic infraction in K.S.A. 8-2118, as amended. 
(b)  All traffic violations which are included within this chapter, and which are not ordinance traffic infractions as defined in subsection (a) of this section, shall be considered traffic offenses. 
(Code 1977, § 15-5.1; Ord. No. G-86-06, § 2, 10-13-1986; Ord. No. G-88-06, § 2, 8-22-1988) 
Sec. 40-10. - Penalty for scheduled fines. 
    The fine for violation of an ordinance traffic infraction or any other traffic offense, for which the municipal judge establishes a fine in a fine schedule, shall not be less than $10.00 or more than $1,000.00. A person tried and convicted for violation of an ordinance traffic infraction or other traffic offense for which a fine has not been established in a schedule of fines shall pay a fine fixed by the court not to exceed $1,500.00. 
(Code 1977, § 15-5.2; Ord. No. G-86-06, § 3, 10-13-1986; Ord. No. G-88-06, § 3, 8-22-1988) 
Sec. 40-11. - Code does not affect ordinances regulating traffic on specific streets. 
    Nothing in this Code, or the ordinance adopting this Code, shall be construed as repealing or otherwise affecting any ordinance of the city prescribing traffic regulations on specific streets in the city, such as, but not limited to, ordinances prescribing speed limits, establishing areas or spaces where parking is prohibited or limited, or designating one-way streets or alleys or intersections for the control of traffic by signs or signals, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1977, § 15-6) 
Secs. 40-12-40-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 40-41. - Truck routes. 
(a)  Designated routes . The following roadways in the city are, to the exclusion of all other roadways, hereby designated as truck routes for the use by truck traffic: 
(1)  All of East and West 11th Street/U.S. Highway 166; all of Northeast Street/U.S. Highway 166/169; and all of Walnut Street/U.S. Highway 169 south of 11th Street; 
(2)  Central Street north of 8th Street, and Hickman Street north of 11th Street/U.S. Highway 166; 
(3)  Buckeye Street south of 8th Street to its intersection with 14th Street, and 14th Street east of Buckeye Street to its intersection with Walnut Street/U.S. Highway 169; 
(4)  Spruce Street south of 14th Street to its intersection with Eldridge Street, and Eldridge Street east of Spruce Street to its intersection with Walnut Street/U.S. Highway 169; 
(5)  1st Street east of Central Street to its intersection with Sunflower Street, and Sunflower Street north of 11th Street; 
(6)  Patterson Boulevard north of 11th Street to its intersection with 8th Street; 8th Street east of Patterson Boulevard to its intersection with Santa Fe Street; 8th Street west of Buckeye to its intersection with U.S. Highway 166; Santa Fe Street north of 8th Street to its intersection with 4th Street; and 4th Street from Central Street to its intersection with Northeast Street/U.S. Highway 166/169; and 
(7)  All of Cline Street. 
(b)  Prohibition against travel on roadways other than truck routes . Except as expressly allowed under this article, no person shall operate any truck, truck tractor and semi-trailer, truck tractor and trailer combination, or truck and trailer combination, which is classified as a commercial vehicle having a gross vehicle weight loaded or unloaded of more than 18,000 pounds, on any roadway other than a designated truck route. 
(c)  Exemptions . The truck route limitations prescribed in this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Fire trucks or other emergency vehicles, whether or not they are responding to an actual emergency; 
(2)  Road repair, construction or maintenance vehicles owned and operated by a municipality or government, or any contractor while involved in the repair, construction or maintenance of a road; 
(3)  The operation of any truck, truck tractor and semi-trailer, truck tractor and trailer combination, or truck and trailer combination, which is classified as a commercial vehicle upon any officially established detour; 
(4)  Garbage service vehicles while involved in the provision of usual and contractual garbage and recycling services. 
(d)  Pick-ups, deliveries and service calls . The operation of any vehicle otherwise restricted to the truck route established herein is expressly prohibited on all non-truck routes unless making a delivery, pick-up or service call within the city by means of the shortest route from or to a truck route. A vehicle which is restricted to truck routes and which is being used to make pick-ups, deliveries or service calls in the city on roadways other than designated truck routes shall enter the city via a designated truck route and shall not be driven or moved on roadways other than truck routes, except when being used to make pick-ups, deliveries, or service calls within the city. Pick-ups, deliveries, and service calls shall, at all times, be made by utilizing the most direct route to and from a designated truck route. This section shall be interpreted as requiring all vehicles restricted to operating on a truck route to entering and leaving the city only on a truck route. 
(e)  Leaving or returning to place of business . Nothing herein contained shall prevent a vehicle otherwise restricted to a truck route from leaving or returning to the owner's storage or maintenance location in the city provided the most direct route to and from a designated truck route is utilized. 
(f)  Penalties. Every person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be punished for a first conviction thereof by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment for not more than one month or by both such fine and imprisonment; for a second such conviction within one year thereafter, such person shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for not more than six months or by both such fine and imprisonment; upon a third or subsequent conviction within one year after the first conviction, such person shall be punished by a fine of not more than $2,500.00 or by imprisonment for not more than one year or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1977, § 15-21; Ord. No. G-84-03, § 1, 8-27-1984; Ord. No. G-14-043, § 1, 7-8-2014) 
Sec. 40-42. - Regulation of motor vehicles upon private business premises. 
    No person shall drive a motor vehicle onto the parking lot or premises of any business or commercial property to complete a U-turn, or to return to the same street to drive in the opposite direction, or to effect a short-cut to another street. 
(Code 1977, § 15-22; Ord. No. G-90-4, § 1, 3-26-1990) 
Sec. 40-43. - Loud sound amplification systems in vehicles. 
(a)  Prohibition . No person operating or occupying a motor vehicle on a street, highway, alley, parking lot or driveway shall operate or permit the operation of any sound amplification system from within the vehicle so that the sound is audible at a distance of 100 or more feet from the vehicle. 
(b)  Definitions . The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Audible means any sound produced by a sound amplification system from within a vehicle which can be heard at a distance of 100 feet or more. Measurement standards shall be by the auditory senses, based upon direct line of sight. Words or phrases need not be discernible and bass reverberations are included. The motor vehicle may be stopped, standing, parked or moving on a street, highway, alley, parking lot or driveway. 
    Sound amplification system means any radio, tape player, compact disc player, loudspeaker, or other electronic device used for the amplification of sound. 
(c)  Defense to prosecution . It is an affirmative defense to a charge under this section that the operator of the vehicle was not otherwise prohibited by law from operating the sound amplification system, and that any of the following apply: 
(1)  The system was being operated to request medical or vehicular assistance or to warn of a hazardous road condition; 
(2)  The vehicle was an emergency or public safety vehicle; 
(3)  The vehicle was owned and operated by the city or a gas, electric, communications or refuse company, or operated as an ice cream truck; 
(4)  The system was used for the purpose of giving instructions, directions, talks, addresses, lectures or transmitting music to any persons or assemblage of persons in compliance with ordinances of the city; or 
(5)  The vehicle was used in authorized public activities, such as parades, fireworks, sporting events, musical productions and other activities which have the approval of the department of the city authorized to grant such approval. 
(d)  Penalty . Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section is guilty of an ordinance violation and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or by imprisonment of not more than six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day any violation of this section is found to exist, or continues to exist, shall be a separate offense and punishable as such under this section. 
(Ord. No. G-10-03, § 1, 9-8-2010) 
Secs. 40-44-40-74. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MICRO UTILITY TRUCKS 

Sec. 40-75. - Operation. 
    Micro utility trucks may be operated upon the public streets, roads and alleys within the corporate limits of the city, subject to the following: 
(1)  No micro utility truck shall be operated on any public street, road or alley, unless such truck complies with the equipment requirements under K.S.A. 8-1701 et seq., and amendments thereto. 
(2)  No micro utility truck shall be operated on any interstate highway, federal highway or state highway; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not prohibit a micro utility truck from crossing a federal or state highway. 
(3)  Every person operating a micro utility truck on the public streets, roads and alleys of the city shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to a driver of a vehicle imposed by law. 
(Ord. No. G-09-06, § 1, 10-13-2009) 
Sec. 40-76. - Valid driver's license required; penalty. 
    No person shall operate a micro utility truck on any public street, road or alley within the corporate limits of the city unless such person has a valid driver's license. Violation of this section is punishable by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for not more than six months or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. G-09-06, § 2, 10-13-2009) 
Sec. 40-77. - Definition. 
    The term "micro utility truck" means any motor vehicle which is not less than 48 inches in width, has an overall length, including the bumper, of not more than 160 inches, has an unladen weight, including fuel and fluids, of more than 1,500 pounds, can exceed 40 miles per hour as originally manufactured and is manufactured with a metal cab. The term "micro utility truck" does not include a work-site utility vehicle. 
(Ord. No. G-09-06, § 3, 10-13-2009) 
Sec. 40-78. - Penalty. 
    Unless specifically provided for herein, a violation of this division shall be deemed an ordinance traffic infraction. Upon an entry of a plea of guilty or no contest or upon being convicted of such violation, the penalty imposed shall be in accordance with the penalty provisions set forth in the standard traffic ordinance, and amendments thereto, or such other similar provision as the city may then have in effect. 
(Ord. No. G-09-06, § 4, 10-13-2009) 
Sec. 40-79. - Insurance required; penalty. 
(a)  Every owner of a micro utility truck shall provide liability coverage in accordance with section 200 of the standard traffic ordinance, and amendments thereto, and the Kansas Automobile Injury Reparations Act, K.S.A. 40-3101 et seq., and amendments thereto. 
(b)  All provisions of section 200 of the standard traffic ordinance, and amendments thereto, including penalty provisions, shall be applicable to all owners and operators of micro utility trucks. 
(Ord. No. G-09-06, § 5, 10-13-2009) 
Sec. 40-80. - Registration and license; fee; application; inspection; penalty. 
    Before operating any micro utility truck on any public street, road or alley within the corporate limits of the city, the vehicle shall be registered with the police department and display a valid registration decal affixed and displayed in such a manner as to be clearly visible from the rear of the vehicle. The application shall be made upon forms provided by the city and each application shall contain the name of the owner, the owner's residence address, or bona fide place of business and a brief description of the vehicle to be registered (including make, model and serial number, if applicable). Proof of insurance, as required in section 40-79 shall be furnished at the time of application for registration. The annual registration fee for a micro utility truck shall be $25.00. The full amount of the license fee shall be required regardless of the time of year that the application is made. The license issued hereunder is not transferable. 
(Ord. No. G-09-06, § 6, 10-13-2009) 
Secs. 40-81-40-103. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 

Sec. 40-104. - Parking of vehicles on non-paved surfaces. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or allow to be parked any vehicle or machinery within the front yard setback area of a residence or vacant lot unless the area used for parking is: 
(1)  Improved with at least four inches of paver brick, asphalt, concrete, or gravel over the entire parking area; or 
(2)  Meets the definition and requirements of a driveway as provided in chapter 36, article III. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subsection, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Front yard setback area means the area between the public right-of-way and the parallel front line of the building. In the case of a corner lot, the front yard setback shall be defined as the area between the public right-of-way and the parallel front lines of both sides of the building facing the street. The setback area in the case of a vacant lot, the front yard setback shall be defined as the area between the public right-of-way and the front line of the building on the adjacent lot. A drawing depicting the prescribed areas where vehicles and machinery are not allowed to be parked is attached hereto and marked "Attachment A." 
    Vehicle or machinery means a: 
(1)  Machine, other than a child's toy, propelled by power other than human power and designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runner or slides and which transports persons or property and shall include without limitation an automobile, racecar, truck, recreational vehicle, motorcycle, tractor (except lawn tractors with a 30 horsepower or smaller engine) or farm implement; 
(2)  Boat, jet ski, or other watercraft, whether motorized or not; and 
(3)  Trailer holding or containing, or designed to hold or contain one or more vehicles or machinery. 
(c)  The provisions of this article shall have no force or effect: 
(1)  On federal holidays; 
(2)  As to construction vehicles when such vehicles are being actively used in an on-site construction project; 
(3)  When the vehicle is temporarily parked for the purpose of and while actually engaged in receiving or discharging passengers or personal property; or 
(4)  As to any properly zoned mobile home or RV park. 
(d)  Any person convicted of violating this section shall be assessed a fine in the sum of $25.00. No court costs shall be assessed for a first offense. Upon a second conviction, the fine shall be $50.00. Upon a third or subsequent conviction, the fine shall be not less than $100.00 or more than $500.00. The standard traffic costs shall also apply to all second and subsequent convictions. 

(Ord. No. G-06-01, § 1, 4-11-2006; Ord. No. G-11-01, § 1(15-35), 9-27-2011) 
Secs. 40-105-40-121. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BICYCLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 40-122. - Disposition of bicycles found or recovered by police department. 
    When any bicycle or bicycle parts or accessories found or recovered by the police department have remained unclaimed for 90 days, the same may be disposed of by the police department after one week's notice published in the official newspaper. Any proceeds from the disposition thereof shall be turned over immediately by the chief of police to the city treasurer to be deposited in the credit of the general fund. 
(Code 1977, § 15-62; Ord. No. G-74-09, § 5, 8-15-1974) 
Secs. 40-123-40-142. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OPERATION 

Sec. 40-143. - Parking. 
    No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb, or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or curb in such manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. Any bicycle not so parked shall constitute a nuisance and shall be abated by the impoundment of such bicycle by the chief of police. 
(Code 1977, § 15-79; Ord. No. G-74-09, § 4(g), 8-15-1974) 
Secs. 40-144-40-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RAILROADS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority for city to regulate the operation of railway engines, street railways or cars in the city, K.S.A. 12-1633; railroads generally, K.S.A. 66-201 et seq. 

Sec. 40-170. - Flagmen or signal system required at certain crossings; duties of flagmen. 
(a)  In order to prevent accidents at crossings, it is the duty of every person, firm or corporation owning, controlling or operating a railroad system across any of the following named streets in the city to keep and maintain a capable person at said crossings as a flagman, whose duty it is to warn any person approaching such railway crossing, on foot or in a vehicle, of the approach of any train engine or car by use of plainly visible signaling device or red lantern or lamp, provided that it is not necessary to keep said flagman at said crossing from 9:00 p.m. until 6:00 a.m. of each day: 
(1)  14th Street, between Spruce Street and Atlantic Street. 
(2)  Buckeye Street, between 14th Street and 12th Street. 
(3)  East 1st Street, between Sycamore Street and Union Street. 
(4)  East 4th Street, between Santa Fe Street and Union Street. 
(5)  East 8th Street, between Santa Fe Street and Union Street. 
(6)  Elm Street, between 14th Street and 12th Street. 
(7)  Maple Street, between 14th Street and 12th Street. 
(8)  South Walnut Street, between 14th Street and 12th Street. 
(9)  Spruce Street, between 14th Street and 13th Street. 
(10)  Willow Street, between 14th Street and 12th Street. 
(b)  As an alternative to the keeping of such flagman as provided in subsection (a) of this section, any such person, firm or corporation so owning, controlling or operating a railroad system across said crossing may install and maintain proper and suitable automatic gates and lamps at said crossings that would prevent and warn vehicles approaching said crossing from entering and going upon said railway tracks when there is approaching said crossing, any train, engine or car. 
Sec. 40-171. - Unlawful for flagmen to neglect to perform duties. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person employed as a flagman to fail, neglect or refuse to perform any of the duties provided in this article for a flagman. 
(Code 1965, § 25-103; Code 1977, § 23-3) 
Sec. 40-172. - Running of a train through a crossing without a flagman. 
    It shall be unlawful for any engineer, conductor, brakeman or any other employee of any person, partnership, company or corporation owning, controlling or operating a line of railroad in the city to run or operate, or assist in running or operating, or to give any order to run or operate any car or train of cars or any engine across those portions of streets designated in section 40-170 without a flagman being at the crossings. 
(Code 1965, § 25-102; Code 1977, § 23-4) 
Sec. 40-173. - Lighting over street crossings. 
(a)  Whenever it shall be deemed necessary by the board of commissioners, every railway company shall be required to keep the streets across, over and along which they run to be properly and sufficiently lighted by erecting and maintaining electric lights of the same candlepower as now in use by the city for street lighting and known as arc lights. The poles upon which the wires are strung shall be of the size and height as those used by the city for such purposes. The lights shall be located at such points on the streets so occupied by such railway as may be designated by the board. 
(b)  Whenever it deems the placing of lights necessary, the board of commissioners shall, by resolution, designate the number of such lights and the place or places where the same are to be located, and thereupon the city clerk shall serve the agent of such railway company with a copy of such resolution. Such resolution shall fix a reasonable time within which the railway company shall comply therewith. 
(c)  From and after the expiration of the time fixed by the resolution of the board of commissioners for the erection and placing of any light as directed by the resolution, it shall be unlawful for any engineer, conductor, motorman or other person to run any engine or train over or along that part of a street so directed by the resolution to be lighted during any hour of the nighttime if such lights have not been properly installed. 
(d)  The failure to place lights in accordance with a resolution enacted pursuant to this section and each period of 30 days thereafter in which the resolution is not complied with shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, §§ 23-301-23-303; Code 1977, § 23-5) 
Sec. 40-174. - Blocking crossing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any engineer, conductor or other person having under his charge, control or management any railway engine, car or train to cause or permit the same to stand on or across or to obstruct any street in the city for a longer period than ten minutes at any one time. 
(Code 1965, § 25-202; Code 1977, § 23-7) 
State Law reference- Permitting trains, engines or cars to stand on public highways, K.S.A. 66-273. 
Secs. 40-175-40-201. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CONSTRUCTION OF TRACKS 

Sec. 40-202. - Grade of rails. 
(a)  Drainage required. Every railway company which operates on or controls any railway tracks that cross any public street in the city shall provide, at the intersection of its tracks with each street, drains sufficient to carry off the water which may run down such streets along the ditches or gutters thereof, and such railway company shall not obstruct such ditches or gutters so as to prevent the flow of water therein. 
(b)  Maintenance. It shall be the duty of every railway company controlling or operating any railroad within the city to construct and maintain suitable crossings over the tracks, and such crossings shall be maintained in a passable condition so that vehicles can cross such railroad tracks with ease and without difficulty. 
(c)  Crossings; paving required. It shall be the duty of any railway company whose railroad tracks crosses any public street of the city to pave between the tracks and between the rails of such railroad and for a distance of at least three feet outside of such rails, in any street upon which tracks are located, with the same kind and quality of material with which such street is paved or with such material as may be approved by the director of public works. 
(d)  Grade of rails. Every railway company which has heretofore constructed or shall hereafter construct or repair railway tracks upon, across or along any public street in the city, shall construct, repair or reconstruct such tracks so as to make the top of the rails of the same level with the grade of the street established by the city. 
(e)  Failure to comply; city may do work. In case any railway company shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with subsections (a) through (d) of this section, within 20 days after notice in writing so to do has been served upon the agent of the railway company by the director of public works, then such drains, maintenance, paving, repairing or leveling of tracks, rails or crossings may be done by the city, and the cost of such improvements shall be a lien upon the property of such railway company and may be assessed and taxed against the property of such railway company in the same manner as other taxes are levied against railway property. In addition thereto, if the board of commissioners so directs, such amounts due the city may be enforced and collected by suit in any court having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1965, § 25-405; Code 1977, § 23-24) 
Chapter 42 - UTILITIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - City's obligation; liability of city and department. 
(a)  The city shall exercise reasonable diligence and care to furnish and deliver a continuous supply of utility services to the customer, but will not be liable for interruption or shortage of supply due to accident or conditions beyond the city's control. In the event of such interruption or shortage, the city shall not be liable for any loss or damage occasioned thereby, nor shall such interruption or shortage constitute a breach of the utility service agreement. 
(b)  The city shall not be liable in case of damage to property, including, without limitation, appliances, or articles or materials in the process of being manufactured or developed, because of interruptions of service caused by high winds, storms, lightning, voltage surges, strikes, riots or other causes beyond the control of the department. 
(Code 1977, § 26-18; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-2. - Utility meters remain property of department subject to removal without notice. 
    All meters shall remain the property of the department and may be removed by the department from the customer's premises at any time, without notice, for the purpose of testing or repairing same or upon discontinuation of the service. 
Sec. 42-3. - Right of entry for inspection and maintenance. 
    Employees of the utility departments shall have the right to enter at any reasonable hour upon all premises served by the city for the purpose of reading meters, inspection of meters and utility lines, pipes and equipment, pipe and valves and for other purposes necessary to the proper maintenance of service. 
Sec. 42-4. - Notice of suspension of services for repairs; city not liable for damages. 
    When it becomes necessary to suspend delivery of utility services for the purpose of making repairs, connecting extensions or for any other reason, the department shall endeavor to notify the customers affected, but the department shall not be liable for any damages resulting from interruption of service whether notice of such interruption has or has not been given. 
(Code 1977, § 26-36; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-5. - Rules and regulations deemed part of utility service agreement; application of service. 
(a)  The rules and regulations herein contained shall constitute and be a part of the utility service agreement with every person, company or corporation who is supplied with utilities from the city. 
(b)  Every person, company or corporation (sometimes referred to as the "customer" herein), who accepts and uses utilities from the city, shall be held to have consented to be bound by the rates, rules and regulations herein contained, and no utilities shall be furnished by the utility departments except in accordance with this chapter. 
(c)  Applicants must apply in the city's customer service office. Applicants must show proof of identification, a driver's license or other photo identification card. If the applicant is leasing the property, a current lease must be provided. 
(d)  All applications for utility service shall be made in writing upon a utility service agreement blank furnished by the customer service office and shall contain all the information required by both the service department and the billing office, together with an agreement to comply with the provisions of this article, and any amendments thereto, as a part of the term of the utility service agreement between the applicant and the department of the city. 
(e)  All utility service agreements must be made in the name of the head of the household, firm or corporation using the established spelling of that person's or firm's name. Attempts to obtain service by the use of t other names, different spellings or by substituting other persons or firms will be considered an act of deceit and service will be denied. If service had been discontinued because of nonpayment of bills or any unpaid obligation, and service again has been obtained through an act of deceit, misrepresentation or fraud, that service will be promptly disconnected, and the whole or such part of the security deposit as may be necessary to satisfy the unpaid obligation shall be retained by the collector and credited to the proper account. Any person providing false information including a false name, address or credit rating to obtain service from the city shall be guilty of an offense against the city ordinances. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to draw, use or consume utility services from the city utility systems without proper authority as evidenced by a valid contract as provided for in this article. 
Sec. 42-6. - Rates incorporated. 
    There are hereby incorporated by reference, as if set out fully herein, certain rates for utility customers of the city, as adopted by separate ordinance. The provisions of said rate ordinances shall be controlling with respect to such utility customers. One or more copy of each of said rate ordinances shall be filed with the city clerk. 
Sec. 42-7. - Security deposits. 
(a)  At the time application is made for utility service the applicant must deposit with the department, as a security deposit, an amount as stated on the city's fee schedule. 
(b)  Residential customers who present confirmable written evidence of a good payment record, as provided herein, while customers of another electric utility in the United States, or with the city, for the most recent 12 consecutive months during the previous three years, will have the security deposit requirement waived for their residence. This letter of credit must state that the applicant had services for 12 consecutive months with no arrears, delinquencies, NSF checks or late payments for the entire 12 consecutive months. However, any customer with an outstanding collectible bill with the department shall not be granted the courtesy of using a letter of credit from another utility, nor shall their deposit be waived for a good paying record with the department. Before services are connected, the customer will be required to pay the outstanding uncollectible bill as well as the appropriate security deposit. Credit information must be received prior to connection of service. 
(c)  Residential security deposits shall be refunded, with interest, to the applicant after one year in good standing with the city, so long as the refund amount exceeds $5.00. Security deposits in the amount of $5.00 or less shall be transferred to the applicable utility funds. 
(d)  Commercial security deposits for new commercial service, including, but not limited to non-profit organizations and churches, shall be computed based on one-sixth of the estimated annual billing for each utility based on the usage as determined by the department. For established locations, the most recent 12 months' active billing history for the previous customer may be used and the deposit may be based on one-sixth annual billing for that previous customer, or, if the business or its mode of operation is, in the opinion of the department, substantially different from the previous customer, the deposit may be computed by the department for one-sixth of the estimated annual billing for the location. Any expansion or increase in estimated usage for an established location may result in an increase in the deposit equal to one-sixth of the estimated annual increase in billing for the location. The deposit shall be in accordance with the city's fee schedule. 
(e)  For commercial accounts, in lieu of any cash security deposit, the department may, at its discretion, accept a bond executed by the applicant, as principal, and a solvent surety company qualified to do business in the state, as surety, conditioned that the principal therein shall timely and faithfully pay to the department any and all sums due for the utility services. In addition, in lieu of a cash security deposit or a bond, the department may accept an irrevocable letter of credit from a bank or other financial institution qualified to issue such letters of credit. Upon expiration, said bond or letter of credit shall be renewed or a cash deposit made. Failure to do either will constitute grounds for discontinuance of services, or other action deemed necessary by the department. In no event shall a surety bond or letter of credit executed by a personal surety be permitted to substitute for the required security deposit. 
(f)  If the applicant has a delinquent utility debt with the city, payment of the delinquent amount, plus a double security deposit shall be required in order to establish service with the city. Double deposits shall not be refunded to the customer until utility service with the city is terminated. 
(g)  Interest shall be paid on all deposits annually in January as a credit on the January bill. Upon termination of utility service, the security deposit thus provided for, shall be applied to any remaining utility charges outstanding at the time of final customer disconnect. 
Sec. 42-8. - Meter reading, billing and collecting. 
(a)  Meters will normally be read each month. The day of the month for reading any meter will, as closely as practicable, be on the same day each month, but there will be a three-day allowance each way to take care of Saturdays, Sundays and holidays or other unusual conditions. 
(b)  The department will read meters at least once every four months where auto transportation is required for such readings. 
(c)  In the months when meters are not read, meter readings will be estimated by the department and bills will be rendered on the basis of these estimated readings. However, if a customer desires to submit the meter readings by postcard and will do so in time for billing, the department will provide the postcards for this purpose. Meter readings may also be submitted on the city's website. 
(d)  The department may estimate meter readings for fractional month's use and render bills on these estimated meter readings. 
(e)  The department may estimate meter readings where the meter reader is unable to gain access to the premises to read the meter on his regular meter trip. 
(f)  In the event an adjustment is due a customer as the result of a faulty meter, meter reading, or billing error, the department will limit the adjustment to the previous 180 days after the discovery of the error. 
(g)  Monthly bills will be rendered net, payable on or before the due date set forth on the bill. Cash payment may be required. 
(h)  Failure to receive a bill shall not excuse a customer from his obligation to pay within the time specified. Should the department be unable to bill a customer for utilities used during any month, the billing next made shall include the charges for energy used during the unbilled month. A "month" shall be considered as that period of approximately 30 days. 
(i)  All bills must be paid prior to customers transferring service to another location. A transfer fee shall be charged to customers transferring service from one address to another, in accordance with the city's fee schedule. 
(j)  Service shall not be established at a property rented or leased to another if the owner of the property has a past due utility bill with the city, until such time as such past due utility bill is paid in full. For all utility bills for the previous month's service not paid when due, a late charge of five percent will be added to the bill. 
(k)  The right to discontinue service for default may be exercised whenever and as often as default shall occur and neither delay nor omission on the part of the department to enforce this rule at any one or more times shall be deemed a waiver of its rights to enforce the same at any time, so long as the default continues. 
Sec. 42-9. - Same; delinquent notice; hearing and termination. 
(a)  When any utility account shall become delinquent as herein provided, the utility office shall cause a notice of such delinquency to be sent to the customer by regular or electronic mail, or by text message, to the customer's address, email address, or mobile device number on file, stating: 
(1)  The amount due on the unpaid balance. 
(2)  Notice that service will be terminated if the account is not fully paid by the date stated in the notice. 
(3)  If service is terminated, service will not be reinstated without payment of the entire past due amount. Re-connection is also subject to payment of a re-connection fee in accordance with the city's fee schedule, which must be paid prior to the re-connection. 
(4)  Once the serviceman appears at the residence or business to disconnect service, arrangements cannot be made with the serviceman at that time to continue service. The service will be cut and the past due amount must be paid in full along with the re-connect charge. Arrangements can only be made through the customer service office for continuance of service, and this must be done prior to disconnection. 
(5)  A customer may request a payment extension if he is unable to pay a past due bill by the cutoff date. If the customer fails to request an extension and complete the necessary paperwork by the cutoff date, service shall be disconnected without further notice. Any extension made under the low income energy assistance program (LIEAP) should be only for the amount of the LIEAP payment. The amount of LIEAP payment and the date of receipt shall be confirmed. Only one extension shall be allowed per calendar quarter.
