No extension shall be allowed on an extension, and no customer who is already a party to a utility payment contract with the city shall be permitted to have a payment extension. In no case will extensions be given when the past due bill is already more than 30 days past due. 
(6)  Only one extension shall be allowed per calendar quarter. No extension shall be allowed on an extension. If more than 30 days past due, no extension will be made. 
(b)  In the case of fraudulent use or unauthorized reconnection of services, the department may discontinue service without notice, and the city shall impose a tampering fee in accordance with the city's fee schedule. 
Secs. 42-10-42-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ELECTRIC 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Department means the city electric department. 
    Director means the director of the electric department designated by the city manager to administer the power plant and electric distribution and transmission systems, or his designee. 
    National Electrical Code means the current version of the National Electrical Code adopted by the city. 
Sec. 42-32. - General rules and regulations. 
(a)  In general. 
(1)  Any person using electrical energy from the department without paying therefor, or who breaks the seal of any meter or switch without authority from the city to do so, or who shall install wiring, make connections, or attach wires or any electrical devices or appliances to wires in a manner so that electrical energy may be used without being supplied under the terms of this article, shall be guilty of an offense against the city ordinances. 
(2)  No person shall extend or make use of electric wires from one property to another. A violation of this ordinance shall constitute a public offense. 
(3)  Any person who engages in any act of defacing, injuring or destroying, or in any manner limiting the use or availability of any pole, wire, insulator, fixture, lamp, meter or any property of the electric department of the city, or who shall erect signs on the property of the department without permission, shall be guilty of an offense against the city ordinances. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any person to draw, use, or consume electrical energy from the electrical system of the city without proper authority as evidenced by a valid utility service agreement as provided for in this chapter. 
(b)  The department will run its service wires for electrical light and power at or near the closest point of any customer's buildings. A connection fee shall be paid by the customer in accordance with the city's fee schedule. No person shall make any connections of or to the department's wires without authority from the director. 
(1)  The rates of the department are based upon the supply of service to the entire premises through a single delivery location as required by the National Electrical Code. Any existing separate supply for the same customer at any other point will be separately metered and billed. 
(2)  When a utility customer requests temporary removal of service, a charge shall be applied in an amount established by the city's fee schedule. 
(3)  When a utility customer requests a meter be tested, a fee for testing shall be charged to the customer in accordance with the city's fee schedule. If it is determined the meter is within the margin provided by the American National Standards Institute, no charge shall be made. 
(4)  When a utility customer requests a service be moved, for customer's convenience, a fee not to exceed the actual cost of labor and overhead shall be charged. 
(c)  Customers shall not be permitted to dispose of the power taken under their utility service agreement by resale to any other party or to the general public. There shall be no submetering for resale, or allocation of energy cost. 
(d)  Service may be supplied to customers not coming within the scope of the regular rate schedules of the department; provided, that such service shall be covered by separate contract and approved by the city commission. 
(Code 1977, § 26-17; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-33. - Cold weather policy. 
(a)  During the period December 1 through March 1, the city shall not discontinue electric service to any residential customer if the local temperature is forecast to go below 32 degrees Fahrenheit (0 degrees Celsius) within the following 24-hour period, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. 
(b)  The customer shall be deemed to be in breach of the good faith test if: 
(1)  Documentation by the city shows that a diversion or theft of service has occurred and that the customer benefited from such diversion or theft. A breach resulting from such diversion or theft may be cured by full payment by the customer for the value of the diverted service, such value to be determined by an estimate based, if possible, on the historic use of the customer at that location at the applicable rate. 
(2)  The customer has defaulted on a payment plan in the most recent cold weather period and remains in default. The customer may cure such default by making the initial payment set forth hereof, payment of all disconnect and reconnect charges incurred as a result of such default, and compliance with all other provisions of the good faith test. 
(c)  This policy shall not prohibit the city from discontinuing electric service in case of fraudulent or unauthorized connection or use. 
(d)  The city shall not disconnect a customer's service during the cold weather period when the local National Weather Service office forecasts the temperature will drop below 32 degrees Fahrenheit within the following 24-hour period. 
(e)  The city shall not assess the customer an additional security deposit as a criterion for qualification under this rule; however, the requirement of a deposit under the general provisions of this chapter, regarding delinquent notice; hearing and termination, and in conjunction with the cold weather rule is appropriate if amortized over a six-month period. 
(f)  In addition to the notice provisions regarding disputed bills contained in the general provisions of this chapter, during the cold weather period, the city shall also inform the customer of the formal and informal complaint procedure prior to any termination of the customer's service. 
(g)  Upon mutual agreement between city, customer and any interested third party, the city will notify such third party when customer's bill becomes delinquent. The purpose of this agreement is to afford customer all available methods to maintain the account balance on a current basis and retain city service. Other than the notice, the city has no responsibility to the third party and likewise, the third party is not obligated to pay the delinquent bill. 
(h)  In the case of fraudulent use of service, the department may discontinue service without notice. 
(Code 1977, § 26-22; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-34. - Customer's obligation; balancing of current. 
(a)  In order to prevent damage to the department's equipment and impairment of its service, the customer shall give the department notice before making any additions that will result in an increase of the customer's connected load of more than ten percent of the customer's average use, so that the department, at its option, may provide such facilities as may be necessary for the furnishing of increased service. Such additions include, but are not limited to, electric heating. 
(b)  Current in-phase wires of services shall be balanced as closely as practical with installed equipment. Installation of equipment causing large unbalances will be subject to approval of the director. 
(Code 1977, § 26-19; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Secs. 42-35-42-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SERVICE AND METER REGULATIONS 

Sec. 42-56. - Service regulations. 
(a)  The availability of service for the equipment to be used shall be determined from the department before proceeding with the wiring or the installation of equipment. The department shall have the right, but shall not be obligated, to inspect electrical installations at any time, and it reserves the right to reject any wiring or equipment not in accordance with its standards. Such inspection, or failure to inspect, or to reject, shall not render the department, its agent or employees liable or responsible for any loss, damage or accident resulting from defects in the customer's installation of any electrical equipment, or for any violation of the application or utility service agreement of which these conditions are a part. The customer shall permit the entrance on his premises to identified employees of the department at all reasonable hours for all purposes related to department business. 
(b)  Overhead service conductors will be run and attached to the building by the department, except that anchor bolts to which the service drops will be attached on brick, brick veneer, to concrete, masonry or metal buildings will be furnished and installed by the customer. The point of service attachment on the buildings shall be at least 12 feet above finish grade and meet the requirements of the National Electrical Code. Where necessary, approved structures to support service conductors and for reinforcement of a building structure to provide adequate anchorage for service drop conductors shall be provided by the contractor or owner. 
(c)  All new services shall be underground in all underground subdivisions. If the applicant desires underground service, it shall be the applicant's responsibility to furnish trenching, backfill and installation of conduit. The department shall furnish conduit and conductor at the cost set out in the city's fee schedule. All services over 100 feet shall have steel sweep 90-degree bends. The 200-amp single phase service will require 21/2-inch conduit. The 100-amp single phase service will require two-inch conduit. The 200 amp three phase service will require three-inch conduit. The department shall furnish and install conduit going up at pole location. The department shall furnish and install all conductors to meter location. Fault location and conductor repair or replacement shall be furnished by the department. The cost of any material in excess of that described herein shall be paid by the customer. 
(Code 1977, § 26-20; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1(a)-(c), 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-57. - Location of service. 
    The applicant shall determine from the department the location of the service entrance and metering equipment for all electric services either underground or overhead, and any wiring installed without first determining entrance and/or meter locations as covered above is done at the risk of having to change the service location to conform to the requirements of the department. 
(1)  All service entrances will be located so that the service wires installed by the department will reach the service entrance by attachment at one location only on the building. 
(2)  All service entrance conductors must be installed in rigid conduit or electrical metallic tubing, or as approved by the National Electrical Code. 
(3)  No service connection will be made if any of the following conditions are present, until the proper corrections have been made or advanced approval shall have been secured in writing from the proper electrical inspection authority: 
a.  If service wires are not color coded as required by the National Electrical Code; 
b.  If there are water pipes or water pipe fittings in the service entrance; 
c.  If the service entrance is too low; 
d.  If fused and unfused conductors are installed in the same raceway, neutral conductors excepted; 
e.  If the service switch is not of a type approved for this purpose; 
f.  If the service switch is exposed to the weather and not enclosed in a rain-tight factory-made cabinet; 
g.  If unused openings in the meter base or enclosure are not properly closed with non-tamperable plugs; 
h.  If a building is moved to a new location and the service entrance and/or provisions for metering do not comply with the applicable wiring codes and these regulations; 
i.  If any other conditions exist which the department deems unsafe. 
(4)  No service connection will be made unless the contractor's or owner's wiring is approved by the proper electrical inspection authority. 
(5)  Not more than one set of service entrance conductors, installed in one conduit or raceway, will be connected to any one service drop except by special permission from the director. For commercial and industrial service, the customer shall take service at transformer or metering location. 
(6)  Where the service entrance conduit is extended through the roof and used as an anchorage for the service drop to secure the required ground clearance for service drop conductors, a minimum of two-inch rigid steel conduit shall be used. Service mast for residential single-family occupancy shall extend not less than 18 inches from the roof to the top of the weather head. The customer shall consult with the director for requirements on service masts for commercial or industrial service. 
(Code 1977, § 26-20; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1(d), 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-58. - Meter bases or enclosures. 
    Meter bases or meter enclosures shall be located at such height that the center of the meter when installed will not be more than six feet or less than five feet from the ground or accessible permanent platform or landing. Meters of a special nature may be installed at a height of less than five feet when approved by the director. 
(1)  Meters or metering equipment shall be placed in such location that allows free access for installing, removing, testing and reading. 
(2)  Meters will not be installed in locations subject to vibrations, condensations, where live steam or hot liquids are used, or where similar conditions exist which would adversely affect such devices. Metering equipment shall not be installed over open pits, moving machinery, accessible wells or hatchways, and there shall be at least three feet of unobstructed space between the nearest point of the metering equipment and any such openings, obstructions or safety hazards. Metering equipment shall not be located as to be in the path of water from eaves, rain spouts, etc. 
(3)  There shall be a minimum of four inches' clearance between the meter base and service switch enclosure and/or any other obstruction which might interfere with the installation of the meter or use of a test jack in the meter base. Where more than one socket is installed, the space between sockets will not be less than three inches. 
(4)  Metering for residential loads shall, in all cases, be on the outside of the building and shall not be installed under any type porch, breezeway, shelter, or in an enclosure that can be locked preventing access. 
(5)  Metering equipment for commercial and industrial service shall be installed on the outside of the building, except where prior approval by the department has been granted. 
(6)  Where a subdivision of the service requires the use of more than one meter, the meters shall be grouped. 
(7)  Secondary circuits of instrument transformers will not be run in the same conduit or raceway with any other circuits. 
(8)  When any changes, alterations or additions are made on the customer's premises that violate these requirements, the customer shall pay the cost of relocating the metering equipment. 
(9)  Any inaccessible meter shall have equipment installed which will enable the meter readers to read the meter and the cost of this equipment and installation shall be paid by the customer in whose name the meter is recorded. 
(Code 1977, § 26-20; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1(e), 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-59. - Single- and three-phase meters. 
    All single-phase and three-phase meters will be of the socket type. All meter sockets shall be UL approved, furnished by the customer and approved by the department. 
(1)  Single-phase. 
a.  Single-phase circuits of 200 amperes or less connected load, serving residential single-family occupancy will be metered with self-contained socket-type meters. For circuits requiring conductor size larger than No. 2 A.W.G. copper, an approved 200-ampere rated socket will be required. For loads in excess of 200 amperes connected, or for circuits serving multiple occupancy structures, consult the department for metering requirements. 
b.  Single-phase circuits of 320 amperes or less connected load, and under 300 volts serving commercial or industrial customers, will be metered with self-contained socket-type meters. For circuits requiring conductor sizes larger than No. 2 A.W.G. copper, an approved 320-ampere rated socket will be required. For loads in excess of 200 amperes connected, consult the department for metering requirements. All sockets for single-phase meters will be of a type approved by the department. Any transformer rated instrument meter sockets will be furnished by the department. A current transformer cabinet is furnished by the city and installed by the contractor. 
(2)  Three-phase. All three-phase loads, at normal secondary voltages under 300 volts at 200 amperes or less will be metered through self-contained meters. Loads in excess of 200 amperes or utilizing potential transformers will be metered through instrument transformers, and the applicant shall consult the department for metering requirements. All sockets for three-phase meters will be of a type approved and furnished by the department. A current transformer cabinet is furnished by the city and installed by the contractor. 
(Code 1977, § 26-20; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1(f), 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-60. - Metering equipment. 
(a)  All instrument transformer enclosures for meter wiring will be furnished by the department and installed by the contractor. All metering equipment shall be installed on the line side of the service equipment except: 
(1)  When the subdivision of the service equipment and metering is such that a main disconnection means is required, the connection of each meter to the main disconnecting means shall then be made direct or through a bus; and 
(2)  When meters are installed in a special factory-built switchboard, the department shall be consulted for metering requirements for each installation. 
(b)  No wiring shall be attached to the department-owned poles except by special permission from the department, and any wiring thus attached shall be done strictly in accordance with the department drawings and specifications. 
(c)  All meter loop wiring and all other wiring on the line side of the metering equipment, except the service drop, shall be entirely enclosed in rigid metal enclosures or rigid conduit, and all such enclosures or raceways shall be provided with a suitable device for sealing, or as approved by the National Electrical Code. 
(d)  No meter enclosure shall be used as a wire way, terminal block or junction box for subfeed or branch circuit conductors. 
(Code 1977, § 26-20; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1(g), 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-61. - Department rules and regulations. 
(a)  Nothing in these rules shall be construed as placing upon the department any responsibility for the condition of the main entrance of the customer's wiring, current-consuming devices or other equipment, and the department shall not be held liable for any loss or damage resulting from the defects in the customer's installation and shall not be held liable for damage to persons or property arising from the use of the service on the premises of the customer. 
(b)  The department shall have the right to refuse electric service to any electrical customer with a single-phase 110/120-volt socket type or "A" type service, "A" type three-phase 120/240 or 240/480-volt service, or three-phase three-wire 240 or 480-volt service. 
(Code 1977, § 26-20; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1(k), (l), 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-62. - Characteristics of service. 
    Service provided will be alternating current at a regulated frequency of 60 cycles. 
(1)  The character of service available at any particular location should be ascertained by inquiry at the department's office. 
(2)  Single-phase service is supplied at a normal 120/240 volts through three wires. Single-phase loads, when supplied at 120/240 volts, must be reasonably balanced as between the two sides of the service with respect to the neutral wire. 
(3)  The department will supply service at primary voltages only when, in its opinion, the size or special character of the load, or the location thereof, warrants the supplying of such service at primary voltages. 
(4)  The department shall be consulted concerning the availability of four-wire and whether delta or wye for each and every location requiring such service. 
(5)  The character of service to be supplied must be in agreement with the availability clause and other clauses of the applicable rate schedule. 
(6)  Any motor causing objectionable voltage fluctuations which operates on a service which also supplies lighting shall be changed to operate on a higher voltage or other suitable means employed to reasonably reduce the objectionable voltage fluctuations. 
(Code 1977, § 26-21; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Secs. 42-63-42-84. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - NET METERING 

Sec. 42-85. - Net metering policy and procedures. 
    The board of commissioners has adopted the net metering policy and procedures for customer-owned renewable energy resources, as defined in said policy. No fewer than one copy of the net metering policy and procedures shall be on file in the office of the city clerk and kept available for inspection by the public at all reasonable hours. 
Sec. 42-86. - Interconnection standards for parallel installation and operation of customer-owned electric generating facilities. 
    The board of commissioners has adopted the interconnection standards for parallel installation and operation of customer-owned electric generating facilities, as defined in said standards. No fewer than one copy of the interconnection standards shall be on file in the office of the city clerk and kept available for inspection by the public at all reasonable hours. 
Sec. 42-87. - Net Metering requirements. 
    All net metering customer generators must meet all requirements of the city's interconnection standards for parallel installation and operation of customer-owned electric generating facilities, in addition to all requirements of the net metering policy and procedures. 
Secs. 42-88-42-121. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER 

Sec. 42-122. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Department means the city water department. 
    Director means the director of the public works designated by the city manager to direct the administration of the water treatment plant and distribution systems or his designee. 
    Engineer means the city engineering department or other designated official of the city. 
    EPA means the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
    KDHE means the Kansas Department of Health and Environment. 
    Private fire protection refers to standpipes, automatic sprinkling systems or fire hydrants located on the customer's premises and used exclusively for fire protection. 
    Water meter means a water volume measuring and recording device, furnished or installed by the city or furnished and installed by a user and approved by the city. 
Sec. 42-123. - Location of water service pipes and meters; service connection fees. 
(a)  All water service pipes shall be laid by the water distribution department from the main supply line into the parking in front of the premises to be serviced or to the closest point on the customer's premises as designated by the director, and for all connections, other than private fire protection, the customer desiring water service shall pay a service connection in accordance with the city's fee schedule. 
(b)  For all connections to supply water for private fire protection, the customer desiring such service shall pay the actual cost of making such connection, including replacement of any paving and/or sidewalk removed for the connection. Such actual cost is to be as determined by the director. 
(c)  All meters shall be located in an accessible place on the outside of buildings, except where otherwise directed by the director. 
(d)  Every meter located outside of a building shall be placed only in a meter box furnished and installed by the department, except that a customer may construct his own reinforced concrete meter box with cast-iron lid upon approval of the director. When any customer is permitted to construct his own meter box, he will receive a credit on his service connection fee as determined by the director. 
(e)  A temporary service from a fire hydrant may be provided only when and where approved by the director and shall be subject to the payment of a security deposit and fees in accordance with the city's fee schedule. 
(f)  When a utility customer requests a water service be moved or reduced in size, a fee shall be charged in accordance with the city's fee schedule. 
(g)  Connections for water service shall be made only by the water distribution department on city-owned mains adjacent to the property to be served and that the meter shall be set at this point; provided, however, that in cases where city-owned mains are not adjacent to the property to be served, the connection shall be made on an existing city-owned main at the closest point to the property to be served and the meter shall be set at this point. 
(h)  After the water meter is set, responsibility for service lines and connections extending from the water meter shall rest solely with the customer requesting the service, or his successors or assigns. With the exception of state-authorized rural water districts or municipal water suppliers selling water to customers within their certified service territory or legal boundaries, customers shall not be permitted to re-sell water to any other party or to the general public. No master metering shall be allowed except in cases of apartment buildings, mobile home courts, RV parks, or properties which had master meters in lawful use upon adoption of this code. The responsibility for service lines and connections extending from a master meter shall rest solely with the customer requesting service, or his successors or assigns; provided, however, only one party shall be responsible to the city for water billed through the master meter. 
(i)  The cost of main extensions to existing or new developments, including KDHE approval of plans and specifications, shall be the responsibility of the customer or developer requesting such extensions. The extensions shall be a minimum size of eight inches in residential areas and a minimum of 12 inches in all other areas; provided, however, the board of commissioners may, by resolution, deviate from these minimum requirements for economic development or other compelling reasons deemed to be in the best interests of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 26-39; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992; Ord. No. G-92-03, § 1, 2-24-1992) 
Sec. 42-124. - Customers to maintain pipes and fixtures; claims against city for damages. 
    Water customers shall keep their own pipes and fixtures in good repair and free from leaks at their own expense. No claim for damages shall be made against the city resulting from the breaking or leaking of any valve or service, nor will any credit or allowance be made to any customer for any leaks or water wasted after passing through the meter. 
(Code 1977, § 26-43; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-125. - Customer's responsibility for damage to water meter. 
    The water customer shall be responsible for any damage to the water meter installed for his service resulting from any cause other than ordinary wear and tear. 
(Code 1977, § 26-44; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-126. - Persons authorized to do plumbing work. 
    Only persons who hold a current city plumber's license shall do plumbing work in connection with the water system of the city as herein provided, except that this section shall not apply to persons: 
(1)  Employed by the city or state; or 
(2)  Who perform work under the direction of the director. 
(Code 1977, § 26-45; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-127. - Private fire protection. 
    The pipe for supplying fire protection, except automatic sprinkling systems, shall be provided with a suitable valve in an accessible location, which shall be kept closed at all times except in cases of fire. 
(Code 1977, § 26-46; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-128. - Submetering. 
    No submetering of water meters shall be permitted within the city. 
(Code 1977, § 26-47; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-129. - Extension of pipe from one property to another. 
    No plumber, customer or other persons shall extend water pipes from one property to another. 
(Code 1977, § 26-48; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-130. - Stopcocks. 
    There shall be a stopcock placed in the service pipe and located in front of each and every premises supplied with water, and customers shall not allow any meter boxes to be covered with dirt, but shall keep same within view and aboveground at all times. No stopcock shall be turned on or off by anyone except when a pipe, hydrant or fixture breaks, leaks or gets out of order, when it shall be the duty of the customer promptly to turn off the water, have the necessary repairs made, and have the water turned on. 
(Code 1977, § 26-49; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-131. - Tampering with, injuring, etc., waterworks or water supply. 
    Unless proper and legal permission has been procured, it shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously open, close, cover or remove any fireplug, hydrant, stopcock, valve or valve box or to remove from or affix to or adjust or change any part of the city water distribution system, or to willfully or maliciously cut, break or injure any machinery, pipe or fixture belonging to or being a part of such system, or to willfully or maliciously place or throw into any well, reservoir or source of water supply any foreign or deleterious substance or thing calculated to, or which would, render impure the city water supply. 
(Code 1977, § 26-50; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-132. - Unlawful acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person: 
(1)  Without proper authority to draw or take away any water from the city water system; 
(2)  To perform any work upon the water pipes or appurtenances of the city's water treatment or distribution system beyond a private property line, unless such person is employed by the city and authorized to perform such work; 
(3)  To make connections with any extension of the water supply pipes of any customer without written permission to do so having been first obtained by the director or his designee; or 
(4)  To remove, handle, or otherwise damage or disturb any water meter, meter lid, cutoff, or any other appurtenances to the water system of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 26-51; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Secs. 42-133-42-164. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SEWERS AND DRAINS 

Sec. 42-165. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act or the Act means the Federal Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq. 
    Approval authority means the environmental protection agency (EPA), or if the pretreatment program has been formally delegated to the state department of health and environment (KDHE), it means the director of the division of environment of KDHE. 
    Authorized representative of industrial user . 
(1)  If the industrial user is a corporation, authorized representative means: 
a.  The president, secretary, treasurer, or a vice-president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or decision-making functions for the corporation; 
b.  The manager of one or more manufacturing, production, or operation facilities employing more than 250 persons or having gross annual sales or expenditures exceeding $25,000,000.00 (in second-quarter 1980 dollars), if authority to sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures; 
(2)  If the industrial user is a partnership, or sole proprietorship, an authorized representative means a general partner or proprietor, respectively; 
(3)  If the industrial user is a federal, state or local governmental facility, an authorized representative means a director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation and performance of the activities of the government facility, or his designee; 
(4)  The individuals described in subsections (1) through (3) of this definition may designate another authorized representative if the authorization is in writing, the authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company, and the written authorization is submitted to the city. 
    Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Categorical standards means National Categorical Pretreatment Standards as promulgated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, in accordance with sections 307(b) and (c) of the Act which apply to a specific category of industrial users and which appear in 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter N, sections 405-471. 
    Certified laboratory means a laboratory currently certified by the state department of health and environment to both the method and parameters in accordance with procedures found in 40 CFR 136. All categorical compliance or industrial self-monitoring shall be done by a certified laboratory. 
    Chlorine requirement means the amount of chlorine, in milligrams per liter, which must be added to sewage to produce a specified residual chlorine content. 
    Color means the optical density at the visual wave length of maximum absorption, relative to distilled water. One hundred percent transmittance is equivalent to zero optical density. 
    Combined sewer means a sewer receiving both stormwater and sanitary sewage. 
    Composite sample means the sample resulting from the combination of individual wastewater samples taken at selected intervals based on an increment of either flow or time. 
    Contributor means any person responsible for the production of sanitary sewage or industrial waste which is directly or indirectly discharged into the city's sewer system. 
    Control authority means the city. 
    Cooling water means the water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
    Direct discharge means the discharge of treated or untreated wastewater directly to the waters of the state. 
    Director means the director of public works designated by the city manager to direct the administration of the water treatment plant, the wastewater treatment plants, the water distribution and wastewater collection systems, and who is charged with certain duties and responsibilities by this article, or his designee. 
    Engineer means the city engineer or other designated official of the city or his duly authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    Environmental protection agency or EPA means the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, or where appropriate, the term may also be used as a designation for the administrator or other duly authorized official of the agency. 
    Existing source means any source of discharge the construction or operation of which commenced prior to the publication of proposal categorical pretreatment standards that will be applicable to such source if the standard is thereafter promulgated in accordance with section 307 of the Act. 
    Garbage means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    Grab sample means a sample that is taken from a waste stream on a one-time basis without regard to the flow in the waste stream and without consideration of time. 
    Holding tank waste means any waste from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailer, septic tanks, and vacuum pump tank trucks. 
    Indirect discharge means the discharge or the introduction of nondomestic pollutants from any source regulated under section 307(b) or (c) of the Act (33 USC 1317), into the treatment works (including holding tank waste discharged into the system). 
    Industrial pretreatment program or pretreatment program means the activities of the city necessary to effectively administer the provisions of this article governing nondomestic sewage. 
    Industrial user means a source of indirect discharge which does not constitute a "discharge of pollutants" under regulations issued pursuant to section 402, of the Act (33 USC 1342). 
    Industrial user charge means a charge levied on industrial users. 
    Industrial waste means the liquid wastes from industrial processes as distinguished from sanitary sewage. 
    Inspector means the person or persons duly appointed by the city to inspect and approve the installation of building sewers and their connection to the public sewer system and to monitor such sewage as may be discharged therefrom. 
    Instantaneous maximum allowable discharge limit means the maximum concentration (or loading) of a pollutant allowed to be discharged at any time, determined from the analysis of any discrete or composited sample collected, independent of the industrial flow rate and the duration of the sampling event. 
    Interference means a discharge which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources: 
(1)  Inhibits or disrupts the POTW, its treatment processes or operations or its sludge processes, use or disposal; and therefore 
(2)  Is a cause of a violation of the city's NPDES permit or of the prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal in compliance with any of the following statutory/regulatory provisions or permits issued thereunder (or more stringent state or local regulations): section 405 of the Clean Water Act; the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA), including Title II commonly referred to as the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA); any state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to Subtitle D of the SWDA; the Clean Air Act; the Toxic Substances Control Act; and the Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act. 
    Kansas Department of Health and Environment or KDHE means the state regulatory agency empowered by the State of Kansas to administer state and federal environmental laws, regulations, and rules. 
    Medical waste means isolation wastes, infectious agents, human blood and blood byproducts, pathological wastes, sharps, body parts, fomites, etiologic agents, contaminated bedding, surgical wastes, potentially contaminated laboratory wastes and dialysis wastes. 
    National Pollution Discharge Elimination System or NPDES Permit means a permit issued pursuant to section 402 of the Act (33 USC 1342). 
    National Prohibitive Discharge Standard or prohibitive discharge standard means any regulation developed under the authority of section 307(b) of the Act, 40 CFR, chapter I, subchapter N, sections 405--471. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    New source means: 
(1)  Any building, structure, facility or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under section 307(c) of the Act which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that: 
a.  The building, structure, facility or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; 
b.  The building, structure, facility or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source; or 
c.  The production or wastewater generating process of the building, structure, facility or installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source, should be considered. 
(2)  Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility or installation meeting the criteria of subsection (1)b or c of this definition but otherwise alters, replaces, or adds to existing process or production equipment. 
(3)  Construction of a new source as defined under this section has commenced if the owner or operator has: 
a.  Begun, or caused to begin as part of a continuous on-site construction program: 
1.  Any placement, assembly, or installation of facilities or equipment; 
2.  Significant site preparation work including clearing, excavation, or removal of existing buildings, structures, or facilities which is necessary for the placement, assembly, or installation of new source facilities or equipment; or 
b.  Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. 
    Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering, and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this section. 
    Normal sewage means sewage which contains not more than 240 mg/l suspended solids and not more than 250 mg/l of BOD and which does not contain any of the materials or substances listed in section 42-190(a) in excess of allowable amounts specified in the section. 
    Operation and maintenance means all expenditures during the useful life of the treatment works for materials, labor, utilities, and other items which are necessary for managing and maintaining the treatment works to achieve the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. 
    Pass through means a discharge that exits the POTW into the waters of the United States in quantities or concentrations which, above or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, is a cause of a violation of the POTW's NPDES permit (including an increase in the magnitude or duration of the violation). 
    Person means any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. This definition includes all federal, state or local governmental entities. 
    pH means the negative logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. It is used to indicate the concentration of free acid and alkali. 
    Pollutant means any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, medical wastes, chemical wastes, industrial wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, rock, sand, wrecked or discharged equipment and industrial, municipal and agricultural wastes and the characteristics of the wastewater (i.e., pH, temperature, TSS, turbidity, color, BOD, chemical oxygen demand (COD), toxicity, odor). 
    Pretreatment or treatment means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater prior to or in lieu of introducing such pollutants into the POW. The reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, or process changes, or by other means, except by diluting the concentration of the pollutants unless allowed by an applicable pretreatment standard. 
    Pretreatment requirements means any substantive or procedural requirements related to pretreatment, other than a pretreatment standard imposed on an industrial user. 
    Pretreatment standards means National Categorical Standards, general and specific prohibited discharge standards, and local limits. 
    Private sewage disposal system means a self-contained system which provides both treatment and disposal of sewage on an individual lot. 
    Prohibited discharge standards or prohibited discharges means absolute prohibitions against the discharge of certain substances; these prohibitions appear in section 42-190(a). 
    Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and which is controlled by a public authority. 
    Publicly owned treatment works or POTW means a "treatment works" as defined by section 212 of the Act (33 USC 1292), which is owned by the state or municipality. This definition includes any devices or systems used in the collection, storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of sewage or industrial wastes and any conveyances which convey wastewater to a treatment plant. The term "POTW" also means the municipal entity having jurisdiction over the industrial users and responsibility for the operation and maintenance of the treatment works. 
    Replacement means expenditure for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement. 
    Residential contributor means any contributor to the city's treatment works whose lot, parcel of real estate, or building is used for domestic dwelling purposes only. 
    Roof drain means a conduit for conveying storm or rain water from a roof. 
    Sanitary sewage means sewage discharging from the sanitary conveniences of dwellings (including apartment houses and hotels), office buildings, factories or institutions, which is free from storm, surface water and industrial wastes. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sanitary sewage and industrial wastes and into which stormwaters, surface waters, and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Septic tank waste means any sewage from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, and septic tanks. 
    Sewage means human excrement and gray water (e.g., household showers, dishwashing operations). 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Sewer service charge means the basic assessment levied on all users of the public sewer system whose wastes do not exceed in strength the concentration values established as representative of normal sewage. 
    Significant industrial user means: 
(1)  Any industrial user subject to categorical pretreatment standards under 40 CFR 403.6 and 40 CFR Chapter 1, Subchapter N, as amended; and 
(2)  Any other industrial user that: 
a.  Discharges an average of 25,000 gallons per day or more of process wastewater to the POTW (excluding sanitary, non-contact cooling and boiler blowdown wastewater); 
b.  Contributes a process wastestream that makes up five percent or more of the average dry-weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW treatment plan; or 
c.  Is designated as such by the control authority on the basis that the industrial user has a reasonable potential to adversely affect the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
    Significant noncompliance means: 
(1)  Chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits, defined here as those in which 66 percent or more of wastewater measurements taken during a six-month period exceed the daily maximum limit or average limit for the same pollutant parameter by any amount. 
(2)  Technical review criteria (TRC) violations, defined here as those in which 33 percent or more of wastewater measurements taken for each pollutant parameter during a six-month period equals or exceeds the product of the daily maximum limit or the average limit multiplied by the applicable criteria (1.4. for BOD, TSS, fats, oils and grease, and 1.2 for all other pollutants except pH); 
(3)  Any other discharge violation that the city believes has caused, alone or in combination with other discharges, interference or pass through (including endangering the health of city personnel or the general public); 
(4)  Any discharge of pollutants that has caused imminent endangerment to the public or to the environment, or has resulted in the city's exercise of its emergency authority to halt or prevent such a discharge; 
(5)  Failure to meet, within 90 days of the scheduled data, a compliance schedule milestone contained in a wastewater discharge permit or enforcement order for starting construction, completing construction, or attaining final compliance; 
(6)  Failure to provide within 30 days after the due date, any required reports, including baseline monitoring reports, 90-day compliance reports, periodic self-monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules; 
(7)  Failure to accurately report noncompliance; 
(8)  Any other violation that the city determines will adversely affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program. 
    Slug load means any discharge at a flow rate or concentration which could cause a violation of the prohibited discharge standards in section 42-190(a) or any discharge of a non-routine, episodic nature, including, but not limited to, an accidental spill or a non-customary batch discharge. 
    Standard industrial classification (SIC) Code means a classification pursuant to the Standard Industrial Classification Manual issued by the Executive Office of the President, Office of Management and Budget, 1972. 
    Standard methods means the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the most recent edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water, Sewage, and Industrial Wastes" published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and Federation of Sewage and Industrial Wastes Associations. 
    Storm sewer or storm drain means a pipe, conduit, open ditch or creek which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial wastes; it may, however, carry cooling water and unpolluted water. 
    Stormwater means any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation, and resulting therefrom, including snowmelt. 
    Suspended solids (SS) means the total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is suspended in, water, wastewater, or other liquids and which is removable by laboratory filtering, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Toxic pollutant means any pollutant or combinations of pollutants listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency under the provision of section 307 (33 USC 1317) of the Act. 
    Treatment plant effluent means any discharge of pollutants from the POTW into waters of the state. 
    Treatment works means any devices and systems for the storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of municipal sewage, domestic sewage or liquid industrial wastes. These include intercepting sewers, outfall sewer, sewage collection systems, individual systems, and pumping, power and other equipment and their appurtenances; extensions improvement, remodeling, additions and alterations thereof; elements essential to provide a reliable recycled supply, such as standby treatment units and clear well facilities; and any works, including site acquisition of the land that will be an integral part of the treatment process or is used for ultimate disposal of residues resulting from such treatment; or any other method or system for preventing, abating, reducing, storing, treating, separating or disposing of municipal waste or industrial waste, including waste in combined stormwater and sanitary sewer systems. 
    Useful life means the estimated period during which the POTW will be operated. 
    User means any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of wastewater into the POTW. 
    User charge means that portion of the total wastewater service which is levied in a proportional and adequate manner for the cost of operation, maintenance and replacement of the POTW. 
    Wastewater means liquid and water-carried industrial wastes, and sewage from residential dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial and manufacturing facilities, and institutions, whether treated or untreated, which are contributed to the POTW. 
    Wastewater treatment plant or treatment plant means that portion of the POTW designed to provide treatment of sewage and industrial waste. 
    Water meter means a water volume measuring and recording device, furnished or installed by the city or furnished and installed by a user and approved by the city. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
    Waters of the state means all streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, watercourses, waterways, wells, springs, reservoirs, aquifers, irrigation systems, drainage systems and all other bodies or accumulations of water, surface or underground, natural or artificial, public or private, which are contained within, flow through, or border upon the state or any portion thereof. 
(Code 1977, § 26-73; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-166. - Abbreviations. 
    The following abbreviations shall have the designated meanings: 
BOD Biochemical oxygen demand CFR Code of Federal Regulations COD Chemical oxygen demand EPA U.S. Environmental Protection Agency gpd Gallons per day l liter mg Milligrams mg/l Milligrams per liter NPDES National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System O&M Operation and maintenance POTW Publicly owned treatment works RCRA Resource Conservation and Recovery Act SIC Standard industrial classifications SWDA Solid Waste Disposal Act (42 USC 6901, et seq.) TSS Total suspended solids USC United States Code  
(Code 1977, § 26-74; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-167. - Administration. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, the director shall administer, implement and enforce the provisions of this article. Any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the director may be delegated by the director to other city personnel. 
(Code 1977, § 26-72; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Secs. 42-168-42-187. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SEWER USE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-188. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other private wastewater disposal system or facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater or sewage. When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to the sewer within 60 days and the private wastewater disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bank-run gravel or dirt. 
(b)  Connection to POTW required. All persons and property owners of dwelling houses or buildings within the city, which buildings are, or shall be, located near a sewer, or in a block within any sewer district through which a sewer extends, shall make such connections with the sewer as may be necessary in the judgment of the city for the protection of the health of the public, and for the purpose of disposing of all substances from any such building affecting the public health which may be lawfully and properly disposing of all substances from any such building affecting the public health which may be lawfully and properly disposed of by means of the sewer. If any such person shall fail, neglect or refuse to so connect any building with the sewer system. as required for more than ten days after written notification by the city, the city may cause such building to be connected with the POTW, or may advertise for bids for the construction and making of such sewer connection and may contract therefor with the lowest responsible bidder or bidders, and may assess the costs and expense thereof against the property and premises so connected in the manner provided by law. All such sewer connections as ordered by the city in accordance with the provisions of this section shall be in full compliance with the requirements of the provisions of the city plumbing code. 
(Code 1977, § 26-75; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-189. - Private sewage disposal systems. 
(a)  When authorized . Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 42-188, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Permit required; application; approval by governmental agencies . Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the person shall first obtain a written permit signed by the director. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and 
other information as is deemed necessary by the engineer. Before such permit is issued by the city, the applicant must obtain approval of any state, federal or other local agency which has jurisdiction over the operation and construction of such system. The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facility in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. 
(Code 1977, § 26-76; Ord. No. G-153, § 21, 11-28-1973; Ord. No. G-83-14, § 3, 7-27-1983; Ord. No. G-86-01, § 5, 2-24-1986; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-190. - General sewer use requirements. 
(a)  Prohibited discharge standards . No person shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the POTW any pollutant which causes pass through or interference. These general prohibitions apply to all users of the POTW whether or not they are subject to categorical pretreatment standards or any other National, state or local pretreatment standards or requirement. Furthermore, no user may contribute the following substances to the POTW: 
(1)  Pollutants which create a fire or explosive hazard in the municipal wastewater collection and POTW, including, but not limited to, waste streams with a closed-cup flashpoint of less than 140 degrees Fahrenheit (60 degrees Celsius) using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21. 
(2)  Any wastewater having a pH less than 5.5 or more than 9.5, or otherwise causing corrosive structural damage to the POTW or equipment, or endangering city personnel. 
(3)  Solid or viscous substances in amounts which will cause obstruction of the flow in the POTW resulting in interference, such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, whole blood, paper and plastic dishes, cups and milk containers. 
(4)  Any wastewater containing pollutants, including oxygen demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.), released in a discharge at a flow rate or pollutant concentration which, either singly or by interaction with other pollutants, will cause interference with either the POTW; or any wastewater treatment or sludge process, or which will constitute a hazard to humans or animals. 
(5)  Any wastewater having a temperature greater than 150 degrees Fahrenheit (65 degrees Celsius), or which will inhibit biological activity in the treatment plant resulting in interference, but in no case wastewater which causes the temperature at the introduction into the treatment plant to exceed 104 degrees Fahrenheit (40 degrees Celsius). 
(6)  Petroleum oil, non-biodegradable cutting oil, or products of mineral oil origin, in amounts that will cause interference or pass through. 
(7)  Any pollutants which result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors or fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and safety problems. 
(8)  Any trucked or hauled pollutants, except at discharge points designated by the city in accordance with section 42-222. 
(9)  Any noxious or malodorous liquids, gases, solids or other wastewater which, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, are sufficient to create a public nuisance, a hazard to life, or to prevent entry into the sewers for maintenance and repair. 
(10)  Any wastewater which imparts color which cannot be removed by the treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions, which consequently imparts color to the treatment plant's effluent thereby violating the city's NPDES permit. Color (in combination with turbidity) shall not cause the treatment plant effluent to reduce the depth of the compensation point for photosynthetic activity by more than ten percent from the seasonably established norm for aquatic life. 
(11)  Any wastewater containing any radioactive wastes or isotopes except as specifically approved by the director in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
(12)  Stormwater, surface water, groundwater, artesian well water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, swimming pool drainage, condensate, deionized water, noncontact cooling water, and unpolluted industrial wastewater, unless specifically authorized by the director. 
(13)  Any sludges, screenings, or other residues from the pretreatment of industrial wastes. 
(14)  Any medical wastes, except as specifically authorized by the director in wastewater discharge permit. 
(15)  Any wastewater causing the treatment plant's effluent to fail a toxicity test. 
(16)  Any wastes containing detergents, surface active agents, or other substances which may cause excessive foaming in the POTW. 
(17)  Any discharge of fats, oils, or greases of animal or vegetable origin is limited to 100 mg/l. 
(18)  Any discharge of oils and greases of petroleum based origin is limited to 150 mg/l. 
    Wastes prohibited by this subsection shall not be processed or stored in such a manner that they could be discharged to the POTW. All floor drains located in process or materials storage area must discharge to the industrial user's pretreatment facility before connecting with the POTW. 
(b)  Stormwater discharge . No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process water to any sanitary sewer. Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to sewers specifically designated as storm sewers or to a natural outlet approved by the city. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, upon approval by the city, and KDHE, to a storm sewer or to a natural outlet. 
(c)  KDHE requirements . KDHE requirements and limitations on discharges shall apply in any case where they are more stringent than federal requirements and limitations or those in this article. 
(d)  City requirements . 
(1)  The city shall have the authority to determine and implement, by ordinance, local limits for prohibited discharge if its investigations demonstrates that they are needed. If a local limit on a discharge exists and the local limit is more stringent those found in corresponding federal categorical standards, the more stringent local limit shall apply to the industrial user. 
(2)  If the city determines that separate local limits are not necessary, it shall so demonstrate such to KDHE or EPA, upon request of either agency. 
(e)  Dilution prohibited . No person shall ever increase the use or process water or, in any way attempt to dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with limitations unless expressly authorized by an applicable pretreatment standard or requirement. The director may impose mass limitations on industrial users that are using dilutions to meet applicable pretreatment standards or requirements, or in other cases when the impositions of mass limitations is appropriate. 
(Code 1977, § 26-77; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992; Ord. No. G-02-04, 11-26-2002) 
Sec. 42-191. - Capping or plugging a service line. 
    The owner of any structure connected to the sanitary sewer service line shall cause the sewer service line to be capped or plugged by a licensed plumber, at or near the owner's property line, within seven days after the demolition or removal of such structure, or the abandonment of any existing sewer service line, and if the owner fails to do so, the city may proceed to cap or plug such sewer service line and, in that event, the owner shall pay a capping/plugging service fee in accordance with the city's fee schedule. If the fee is not paid within 30 days from the date of invoicing, the city may cause an assessment to be made against the property, in accordance with law. 
Sec. 42-192. - Use of sewers and drains for removing sewage and waste from outside city. 
(a)  The use of the sewers and drains of the city for the purpose of removing sanitary sewage and industrial waste from property situated outside the city limits is hereby declared to be a privilege granted to the owner of such property upon recommendation of the approved authority and upon payment of all fees and charges as hereinafter set out. 
(b)  Whenever a property adjoining the city limits must, due to health requirements, tap into a sewer line within the city limits, the tap shall be made only by the sewer department of the city, and shall comply with all city code requirements as if the property were located within the city limits. 
(Code 1977, § 26-78; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-193. - City's options upon discharge of certain prohibited waters or wastes. 
    If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged, to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in section 42-190(a), and which, in the judgment of the city may have a deleterious effect upon the treatment works, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the city may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharges; 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added cost of sample testing, handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes, sewer service charges, sewer surcharges or industrial user charges; and 
(5)  Exercise any and all remedies set forth in section 42-252. 
(Code 1977, § 26-79; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-194. - City's right of revision. 
    The city reserves the right to establish, by ordinance or in wastewater discharge permits, more stringent standards or requirements on discharges to the POTW if deemed necessary to comply with the objectives presented in section 42-216 or the general and specific prohibitions in section 42-190(a). 
(Code 1977, § 26-80; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-195. - Pretreatment of wastewater. 
(a)  Federal categorical pretreatment standards . The national categorical pretreatment standards found at 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter N, parts 405-471 are hereby incorporated. 
(b)  Pretreatment . 
(1)  Users shall provide necessary wastewater treatment as required to comply with this article, and shall achieve compliance with all categorical pretreatment standards, local limits and the prohibitions set out in section 42-190(a) within the time limitations specified by the EPA, the state or the city, whichever is more stringent. 
(2)  All records relating to compliance with pretreatment standards shall be available to officials of the EPA or KDHE, upon request. 
(Code 1977, § 26-81; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-196. - Treatment of sewage by contributor for reduction of excess suspended solids or bod. 
    Any contributor may treat so as to reduce either the excess suspended solids, or BOD, or both, to normal levels before discharging such sewage into the public sewers. If it is believed such wastes may be deleterious to the treatment works or have an adverse effect upon the sewage treatment process or the receiving stream, the city may require treatment to reduce either the suspended solids and BOD, or both, to levels closer to normal sewage before discharging the wastes into the POTW. 
(Code 1977, § 26-82; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Secs. 42-197-42-215. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INDUSTRIAL USERS 

Sec. 42-216. - Purpose and policy. 
    The provisions of this division set forth requirements for industrial users of the wastewater collection and POTW for the city and enables the city to comply with applicable state and federal laws, including the Clean Water Act (33 USC 1251 et seq.) and the general pretreatment regulations (40 CFR part 403). The objectives of this division are: 
(1)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW that will interfere with the operation of the POTW; 
(2)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW which will pass through the POTW, inadequately treated, into receiving waters or otherwise be incompatible with the POTW; 
(3)  To ensure that the quality of the wastewater treatment plant sludge is maintained at a level which allows its use and disposal in compliance with applicable statutes and regulations; 
(4)  To protect POTW personnel who may be affected by wastewater and sludge in the course of their employment and to protect the general public; 
(5)  To improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewater and sludge from the POTW; 
(6)  To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of operation, maintenance and improvement of the POTW; and 
(7)  To enable the city to comply with its NPDES permit conditions, sludge use and disposal requirements and any other federal or state laws to which the POTW is subject. 
(Code 1977, § 26-83; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-217. - Applicability. 
(a)  This division shall apply to all industrial users of the POTW. This division authorizes the issuance of wastewater discharge permits; authorizes monitoring, compliance and enforcement activities; establishes administrative review procedures; requires industrial user reporting; and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein. 
(b)  This division shall apply to persons who are, by permit with the city, users of the POTW. Except as otherwise provided herein, the director shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this section. All compliance monitoring or self-monitoring data must be provided by a laboratory that has a current KDHE certification. 
(Code 1977, § 26-84; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-218. - Industrial pretreatment. 
    Upon the promulgation of national pretreatment standards for a particular industrial subcategory, the pretreatment standard, if more stringent than limitations imposed under this division for sources in that subcategory, shall immediately supersede the limitations imposed under this division. The city shall notify all affected industrial users of the applicable reporting requirements contained in nation pretreatment standards, including requirements outlined in 40 CFR 403.12. 
(Code 1977, § 26-85; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-219. - Pretreatment facilities. 
    Any facilities required to pretreat wastewater to a level acceptable to the city shall be provided, operated, and maintained at the industrial user's expense. Detailed plans showing the pretreatment facilities and operating procedures shall be submitted to the city for review, and shall be acceptable to the city before construction of the facility. The review of such plans and operating procedures will in no way relieve the industrial user from the responsibility of modifying the facility as necessary to produce an acceptable discharge to the city under the provisions of this division. Any subsequent changes in the pretreatment facilities or method of operation shall be reported to, and acceptable to the city prior to initiation of the changes. 
(Code 1977, § 26-86; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-220. - Accidental discharge/slug control plans. 
    The director may require any industrial user to develop and implement an accidental discharge/slug control plan. At least once every two years, the director shall evaluate whether each significant industrial user needs such a plan. Any industrial user required to develop and implement an accidental discharge/slug control plan shall submit a plan which addresses, at a minimum, the following: 
(1)  Description of discharge practices, including non-routine batch discharges. 
(2)  Description of stored chemicals. 
(3)  Procedures for immediately notifying the POTW of any accidental or slug discharge. Such notification must also be given for any discharge that would violate any of the prohibited discharges in section 42-190(a). 
(4)  Procedures to prevent adverse impact from any accidental or slug discharge. Such procedures include, but are not limited to, inspection and maintenance of storage areas; handling and transfer of materials, loading and unloading operations, control of plant site runoff, worker training, building of containment structures or equipment, measures for containing toxic organic pollutants (including solvents), and measures and equipment for emergency response. 
(5)  Confidentiality of information. Information and data on an industrial user obtained from reports, questionnaires, monitoring programs and inspection and maintenance of storage areas, handling and transfer of materials, loading and unloading operations, control of plant site runoff, worker training, building of containment structures or equipment, measures for containing toxic organic pollutants (including solvents), and measures and equipment for emergency response. 
(Code 1977, § 26-87; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-221. - Tenant responsibility. 
    When an owner of property leases premises to any other person as a tenant under any rental or lease agreement, if either the owner or the tenant is an industrial user, either or both may be held responsible for compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1977, § 26-88; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-222. - Hauled wastewater. 
(a)  Septic tank waste may be accepted into the POTW at a designated receiving structure within the treatment plant area, and at such time as are established by the director, provided such wastes do not violate section 42-190 or any other requirements established or adopted by the city. Wastewater discharge permits for individual vehicles to use such facilities shall be issued by the director. 
(b)  The discharge of hauled industrial wastes as "industrial septage" requires prior approval and a wastewater discharge permit from the city. The director shall have authority to prohibit the disposal of such wastes, if such disposal would interfere with the treatment plant operation. Waste haulers are subject to all other sections of this division. 
(c)  Fees for dumping septage will be established as part of the pretreatment fee system as authorized in section 42-285. 
(Code 1977, § 26-89; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-223. - Vandalism. 
    No person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, tamper with or prevent access to any structure, appurtenance or equipment, or other part of the POTW. Any person found in violation of this section shall be subject to the sanctions set out in section 42-252. 
(Code 1977, § 26-90; Ord. No. G-92-02, § 1, 1-27-1992) 
Sec. 42-224. - Wastewater discharge permit eligibility. 
(a)  Wastewater survey . When requested by the director all industrial users must submit information on the nature and characteristics of their wastewater by completing a wastewater survey prior to commencing their discharge. The director is authorized to prepare a form for this purpose and may periodically require industrial users to update the survey. Failure to complete this survey shall be reasonable grounds for terminating service to the industrial user and shall be considered a violation of this division. 
(b)  Wastewater discharge permit requirement . 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any significant industrial user to discharge wastewater in the city's POTW without first obtaining a wastewater discharge permit from the director. Any violation of the terms and conditions of a wastewater discharge permit shall be deemed a violation of this division and subjects the wastewater discharge permittee to the sanctions set out in section 42-252. Obtaining a wastewater discharge permit does not relieve a permittee of its obligation to comply with all federal and state pretreatment standards or requirements or with any other requirements of federal, state and local law. 
(2)  The director may require other industrial users, including liquid waste haulers, to obtain wastewater discharge permits as necessary to carry out the purposes of this division. 
(c)  Wastewater discharge permitting existing connections .
